entry.sense: [The twenty-sixth letter of the alphabet; called haMCN: it is one of the class termed Haloqiy-apN (or guttural), and is a radical letter, except when written with two dots, p; for which, and for the pronominal values of h, &c., see the Supplement.]
[As a numeral it denotes five.]

R. Q. 1. haOohaOa biAlUibili, (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. hiyhaMCN and haOohaMCN, (Ḳ,) the latter extr., (TA,) [see ZaOoZaOa,] He called the camels to food, or provender, by the cry hiYo hiYo: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he chid them, (zajarahaA), by the cry haOohaOo. (Ḳ.) [See also arts. jO and jyO.]
haOohaOa, inf. n. haOohaMCN, He chid a dog. (TA.)
He called a dog. (TA.)
haOohaOa, inf. n. haOohaMCN, He laughed loud and long: [a word imitative of the sound]. (Ḳ, TA.)

hiIoCN, subst. from haOohaOa, [A call to camels to food, or provender]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) hiIoCN and jiIoCN are said to be thus written by Az's own hand, with kesr: and are thus written in the Jáme' [of Ḳz]. (L.) [See arts. jO and jyO.]
haOohaON and haOohaMCN One who laughs loud and long. (Ḳ, TA.)
jaAriyapN haOohaOapN A damsel who laughs loud and long. (Lḥ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. hab-ati Alr-iyHu, (Ṣ, &c.,) aor. tahub-u, (M, &c.,) contr. to analogy; for all reduplicate triliteral verbs that are intrans. have kesr in the aor., except twenty-eight, of which this is one; (Lb;) inf. n. hubuwbN and habiybN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hab-N; (Ḳ;) but this last is not of high repute; (IDrd;) The wind blew; rose; was in a state of commotion. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.)
It is also said of a foul, or stinking, odour. (Mṣb, in art. qwH.)
yawomN tahub-uhu Aln-akobaMCu is for tahub-u fiyhi [A day in which the wind called AlnkbAC blows]. (TA, art. HS.)
hab-a † It (a star) rose: (TA:) [and in like manner, the dawn: see EuTaAsN.]
hab-a UilaI AlS-alaApi He arose, or went, or betook himself, to prayer. (ISh, from a trad.)
hab-a, inf. n. hab-N, ‡ He was brisk; lively; sprightly. (TA.)

hab-a, inf. n. hab-N and hubuwbN and hibaAbN, He (any person or animal marching or journeying) was brisk, lively, or sprightly, and quick: (Ḳ:) or hab-a, aor. yahib-a, with kesr, inf. n. hab-N and hubuwbN, he (any such person or animal) was brisk, lively, or sprightly: and hab-a, [aor. yahub-u,] inf. n. hubuwbN and hibaAbN, he (the same) was quick, and brisk, &c.: ex. hab-ati Aln-aAqapu, aor. tahub-u, with damm, inf. n. hibaAbN, The she-camel was quick in her march, or pace: (TA:) and hab-a AlbaEiyru, inf. n. hibaAbN, The camel was brisk, lively, or sprightly, in his march, or pace. (Lḥ, Ṣ, TA.) See also R. Q. 1.
hab-a, aor. yahub-u, (Ṣ,) inf. n. hab-N and hubuwbN (Ḳ) and habiybN; (TA;) and habohaba↓, inf. n. habohabapN; (Ḳ;) † He awoke, or became roused, from his sleep. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hab-a yafoEalu kacaA ‡ He began to do so; set about doing so; i. q. Tafiqa. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

[You say] mino Oayona hababota † Whence hast thou come? (Ḳ;) as though you said mn Ayn jiYota; i. e., mn Ayn Qnotabahota lanaA Whence hast thou been roused [to come] to us. (Ṣ.) [And] Oayona habibota Ean-aA, with kesr, (in some copies of the Ḳ, Han-aA is put for Ean-aA; but this is a mistake; TA;) Where hast thou absented, or hidden, thyself, from us? or, rather, where hast thou been absent, or hidden, from us? (Yoo, Ḳ.)
hab-a ‡ He was absent a long time. (Yoo, Ḳ.)

hab-a, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yahib-u, (Mṣb,) or yahub-u, (Az, TA,) inf. n. hab-apN (Ṣ) [and, app., hib-apN,] and hab-N, (TA,) It (a sword, Ṣ, Ḳ, and a spear, Ṣ,) shook, or quivered, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and penetrated into the thing struck with it. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
hab-ahu, (aor. yahub-u, TA,) inf. n. hab-N and hab-apN and hib-apN; and Ahtb-h↓; (Sh,* Ḳ;) It (a sword, Sh,) cut him, or it; or cut it off. (Sh, Ḳ.)
hab-a He was routed, or put to flight, in battle. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

hababotu bihi I called him (a goat, TA) ad initum; ut femellam conscenderet. (Ḳ.) [F observes, that J's giving hababotuhu in this sense is a mistake: but MF remarks, that what J says is habohabotuhu↓, he (MF) having examined many copies of the Ṣ and found them all alike in this case, and that this is correct; and this is the reading that I find in both of M. Fresnel's copies of the Ṣ: see also tahabohaba, given in the Ṣ as quasi-passive of habohabotuhu SM, however, states in the TA, that the reading found by him in a copy of the Ṣ in the handwriting of Yákoot, the author of the Moajam, collated with the copy of Aboo-Zekereeya Et-Tebreezee and that of Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee, is hbbt bh, as in the Ḳ; and this, he says, is the genuine reading.]

entry.sense: 2. hb-bh He tore it, or rent it, much. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. Ahb- Alr-iyHa, and Asthb-hA↓, [He (God) caused the wind to blow; to rise; to be in a state of commotion]. (A.)

Ahb-h † He awoke him, or roused him, from his sleep. (Ṣ.) hab-ahu↓ is said to signify the same; and in proof thereof is adduced a reading in the Ḳur, deviating from that which is universally received as correct; mano hab-anaA min m-aroqadinaA, instead of mano baEavanaA, Who hath roused us from our sleeping-place? [ch. xxxvi., v. 52;] but IJ rejects this reading, unless it be elliptical, for hab-a binaA. (TA.)
Ahb- Als-ayofa He shook the sword; or made it to quiver. (Lḥ, Sh.)

entry.sense: 5. thb-b ‡ It (a garment) became worn out, or ragged. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
8: see 1.

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. habohabotuhu: see hababotu bihi.
habohaba, inf. n. habohabapN, He was quick, or swift. (Ḳ.) See also 1.
habohaba, inf. n. habohabapN, It (the saraAb, or mirage,) glistened, or shone; syn. taraqoraqa; (Ḳ;) i. e., lamaEa. (TA.)

habohaba, inf. n. habohabapN, He urged, or checked, [app. the former,] with his voice; syn. zajara; (Ḳ;) by saying habo. (R, as cited by MF,) or habo habo: [so I understand from the TA, where it is said wAlfEl mnh habo habo; for which it is evident that we should read waQsomu AlfiEoli mnh Alx; meaning “its” (imperative) verbal a, &c.:] accord. to some, used specially with reference to a horse: see hAb [in art. hyb]. (TA.) You also say habohaba bihi. (TA.)
habohaba, inf. n. habohabapN, He slaughtered [a beast]. (Ḳ.)
R. Q. 2. tahabohaba He (a goat, TA, called ad initum, Ṣ) shook himself; syn. tazaEozaEa. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See hababotu bihi.
jayoXN yatahabohabu An army of which one part presses upon another. (TA, art. jEb.)

entry.sense: hibabN, pl. of hib-apN: see vawobN habaAYibu.
Alhub-apu The wind. (TA, voce kub-ap.)
hab-apN (Ṣ) and hib-apN↓, (Ḳ,) both of which forms are correct, (TA,) ‡ The penetration of a sword. (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or spear, into the thing that is struck with it, and its shaking, or quivering. (Ṣ.)
cuw hb-pK A sword that shakes, or quivers, and penetrates into the thing struck with it: (Ṣ:) and, that falls with vehemence. (TA.)
hab-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hib-apN↓, (Ḳ,) or the latter only, (TA,) † An hour, or a short time, (sAEp,) remaining before dawn. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hab-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hib-apN↓, (Ḳ,) or the latter only, (TA,) ‡ An indefinite period of time; syn. HiqobapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a long time; syn. dahorN. (Az.) Ex. EiXonaA bicelika hb-pF mina Ald-ahori We lived therein, or in that [state], some time, [or a long time]: like the saying sab-apF. (AZ, Ṣ.)
[You say] raOayotuhu hab-apF I saw him once (Ḳ) in life. (TA.)
qado jaACaniI hab-apF He has come [in] to me once. Occurring in a trad.; said by a woman in allusion to her husband's having once come in to her: (TA:) i. q. waqoEapF. (Mṣb.) See art. Esl in the Mgh.

hom.sense: hib-apN: see hab-apN throughout.

A state, or condition: [or perhaps the meaning intended is the state of being brisk, lively, or sprightly, and quick]. (Ḳ.) Ex. Uin-ahu laHasanu Alhib-api Verily he is in a good state, or condition, &c. (TA.)
hib-apN The state of a stallion when excited by desire of the female. (Ṣ.) See 1.
hib-apN A piece of a garment, or the like: (Ḳ:) pl. hibobN, (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a piece of rag. (TA.)
See vawobN habaAYibu.

entry.sense: hab-I mentioned on the Nawádir of Th, and said to be from hubuwbu Alr-iyHi, but not of established authority: [unexplained]. (TA.)
habohabN A wolf that is light, or active, and quick, or swift, of pace. (Ḳ.) See habohabiI-N.
A certain valley of hell, the place of abode of tyrants, oppressors, and the like. (TA, from a trad.)
habohabiI-N Quick, or swift: as also habohabN↓ and habohaAbN↓. (Ḳ.)
A light, or active, camel: fem. with p {habohabiy-apN}. (Ḳ.)
habohabiI-N One who serves well; a good servant. (Ḳ.)
Any one who does well a small thing: accord. to some, specially, a cook, and a roaster of meat. (TA.)
A butcher; syn. qaS-aAbN, [from habohaba “he slaughtered”]. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
habohabiI-N One who signs well to camels, to urge, or excite, them. (Ḳ.)
habohabiI-N A pastor: (Ṣ:) or a pastor of sheep or goats: or the he-goat of a flock. (Ḳ.)
habaAbN i. q. habaACN [Dust, &c.: see habuwbu]. (Ḳ.)
habuwbN and habuwbapN↓ and habiybN↓ A wind that [blows violently, and] raises the dust. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
habuwbpN: see habuwbN.
habiybN: see habuwbN.

hom.sense: habohaAbN: see habohabiI-N.
Clamorous; a bawler. (Ḳ.)
habohaAbN The saraAb, or mirage. (M, Ḳ.)
habohaAbN A certain game of children, (Ḳ,) of the children of El-'Irák, (TA,) or of the children of the Arabs of the desert. (T.)

entry.sense: vawobN habaAYibu, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also xabaAYibu, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) and OahobaAbN↓, and hibabN↓, (Ḳ,) ‡ A garment rent in pieces, ragged, or tattered. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
riyHN haAb-apN [A wind blowing; rising; in a state of commotion.] (A.)
vawobN OahobaAbN: see vawobN habaAYibu.
[mahab-N A place of blowing of the wind.]

mihobaAbN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and muhotab-N↓ (Ṣ) and muhab-abN↓, of the same measure as muEaZ-amN, (L,) ‡ A he-goat that is much excited with lust: or that rattles much, and is much excited by desire of the female: or that rattles much when so excited: see 1. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
muhab-abN and muhotab-N: see mihobaAbN.

1. habatahu, aor. _i {yahobitu}, (inf. n. habotN, TA,) He beat, struck, or smote, him (A, ʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ) with a sword. (Sh.) Ex. habtuwhumaA Hat-aI faraguwA minohumaA They smote them both with swords until they slew them (TA, from trad.)

habatahu, aor. _i {yahobitu}, He, or it, lowered him, syn. habaTahu and TaOoTaOahu and HT-ahu. (Ḳ,) with respect to station, rank, or dignity (TA:) and abased him; debased him; rendered him abject, vile, despicable, or ignominious. (L.) Ex. habatahu Almawotu EinodiI mnozlapF Death lowered him in my estimation with respect to rank, or dignity, because he died upon his bed. and did not die a martyr. From a trad. (Fr.)
hubita He was lowered with respect to rank, station, or dignity. (Fr.)
hubita (like EuniIa, [i. e. pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] Ḳ,) He (a man) was cowardly, and his intellect quitted him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he was without intellect. (TA.)
habotN Softness; laxity. (L.)
Stupidity, foolishness, stupefaction. (TA.)

habotapN Weakness (Ṣ, Ḳ) in intellect. (Ṣ.) Ex. fiI Eaqolihi hbtpN There is a weakness in his intellect. (Ṣ.) fyh hbtpN There is a stroke of stupidity in him: or there is in him what resembles heedless ness, and unsoundness of intellect: (TA:) or habotapN signifies loss of reason. (TA in art. xlE.)

maA tasoOalu Eano XayoxK nawomuhu subaAtN walayoluhu hubaAtN Dust thou not inquire respecting an old man, whose sleep is that of a sick person, or of one far advanced in years, or whose sleep is light, (TA, art. sbt,) [and whose night is one of languor.] From a trad. hbAt. here, is from habotN, as signifying “softness, and laxity.” (TA.)
habiytN One in whom is sudden fright, or terror. and a shrinking (talab-uc) [by reason of fear]. (L.)
habiytN and mahobuwtN↓ A cowardly man, whose intellect is quitting him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a man without intellect. (TA.)

In the saying of a poet, naXowatuhaA habiytu, quoted, limit not expl., by Th, hbyt is thought by ISd to be of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN. and to signify, XaIoCN yahobitu, i. e. A thing that stupefies, or renders foolish, and confounds, perplexes, or amazes, and thus stills, or quiets and causes to sleep. The poet says,
turiyka qacFI bihaA Uino kaAna fiyhaA
buEayoda Aln-awomi naXowtuhaA habiytu
[he is app. describing clear and strong wine, and says, It will show thee a mote in it, if it be therein: a little after sleep, (even,) the intoxication (which is the result) thereof is a thing that stupefies, &c.]. (TA.)

hom.sense: mahobuwtN Confounded; perplexed; amazed; i. q. mahofuwtN. (TA, art. hft.) mahobuwtu AlfuWaAdi A man of a cowardly heart, without intellect. (Ṣ.) See habiytN
mahobuwtN Lowered with respect to rank, station, or dignity. (Fr.)
mahobuwtu Alt-araAqiI Having depressed, deficient, collar-bones, or clavicles. (Fr.)
mahobuwtN A bird that is sent forth at random; without being rightly directed; [without being let fly at some other particular bird]. Thought by IDrd to be a post-classical word in this sense. (TA.)

entry.sense: 1. hbv maAlahu, aor. _u {yahobuvu}, inf. n. habovN, He scattered, or squandered, his property. (L.)
Q. Q. 1. hanobava: see hanobavapN.
hanobavapN A severe, difficult, or afflictive, affair: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. hanaAbivu: the n is an augmentative letter. (TA.) The pl. also signifies calamities: and confused affairs and news. (TA.)
Also, Confusion in speech, or, in what is said: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [probably an inf. n, of which the verb is hanobava].
1. habijN, aor. _a {yahobaju}, inf. n. habajN; (L;) and thb-j↓ He, or it [a camel's udder], became swollen; or had a tumour [or habaj]. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
habija It (a man's face) became swollen, and contracted: (L:) [and so thb-j↓, in the Ḳ, art. rhl: see its part. n.]

habajahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yahobaju}, (Ḳ,) or _i, [which is more probably right,] (L,) inf. n. habojN, (Ṣ, L,) He beat him, or struck him, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with a staff, or stick: like HabaHahu (Ṣ) [and xabajahu]: or, with uninterrupted blows, but not violently: or, with a piece of wood, like as one beats a dog in killing him: or he beat him in any part of him that he saw. (TA.)
2. hb-jhu, inf. n. tahobiyjN, It caused him, or it, [a camel's udder], to become swollen; or to have a tumour [or habaj]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hb-j wajohahu [It rendered his face swollen: see habija:] said of much sleep. (TA, in art. rhl.)
hb-j He killed a dog, [app. by beating]. (L.)
5: see 1.
habajN A thing like a tumour, in a she-camel's udder: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it is a tumour, or swelling, of the slightest kind. (TA.)
habijN: see what follows.
muhab-ajN A man swollen; or affected with a tumour. (TA.) A swollen face of a man; (A;) as also habijN↓, (L,) and mutahab-ij↓. (A.)
A man heavy, or dull, in spirit; syn. vqiylu Aln-afosi. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mutahab-ijN: see muhab-ajN.

1. habada Alhabiyda, aor. _i {yahobidu}, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. habodN, (L,) He broke habiyd, (Lth, L, Ḳ,) i. e. colocynths: (Lth, L:) or (in the Ḳ, and) he cooked habiyd [i. e., colocynths or their seeds]: (L, Ḳ:) or (in the Ḳ, and) he gathered habiyd [i. e. colocynths]; (L, Ḳ;) as also thb-dhu↓ and Ahtbdhu↓; (Ḳ;) or thb-d↓ and Ahtbd↓; which are said of an ostrich and of a man: and these two verbs signify he (an ostrich or a man) extracted habiyd [or colocynth-seeds] to eat: (L:) you say of an ostrich huwa yatahab-adu↓ he extracts the seeds of the colocynth to eat them: and thb-d↓ signifies he took a colocynth, or colocynths, and broke it, or them: (Ṣ, L:) or he (an ostrich) broke a colocynth, or colocynths, and ate its, or their seeds: (A:) and he gathered colocynths and macerated them in water: (L:) and Ahtbd↓ he [an ostrich] pierced colocynths with his beak, and ate their seeds: (T, L:) and he took the seeds of dry colocynths, and put them in a place, and poured upon them water, and rubbed and pressed them with the hand, then poured off from them the water, and did this for some days, until their bitterness was gone; after which they are bruised, or brayed, and cooked: (Ṣ, L:) or he prepared for food (EaAlaxa) the pulp of colocynths. (AHeyth, L. [See an ex. in a verse cited voce rAjlp.])
Also habadahu, (aor. as above, L,) He fed him (namely a man, Ḳ) with habiyd. (L, Ḳ.)
5: see 1.
8: see 1.
habodN: see habiydN.

habiydN The colocynth; as also habodN↓: (L, Ḳ:) or the seeds of the colocynth; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) as also habodN: (L, Ḳ:) n. un. of the former, [which is a coll. gen. n.,] with p {habiydapN}: (L:) or the pulp of the colocynth. (AHeyth, L.)
[See barowaqN]

Also, A certain food, which is eaten in cases of necessity, made by breaking colocynths, and taking forth their seeds, and macerating these in water, that their bitterness may go, and then cooking them: (Nh, L:) or colocynths macerated for some days in water, then washed, and, after their upper rind has been thrown away, cooked; to which is added some flour; and sometimes EaSiydap is made of it: (AA, L:) or a food made by macerating in water the seeds of dried colocynths, and heating this water until its bitterness has gone, then pouring upon it some grease, and sprinkling upon it a little flour, after which it is supped. (L.)
rajulN haAbidN A man who gathers colocynths: (TA:) and hawaAbidu [pl. of haAbidapN] women who gather colocynths. (Ḳ.)
[1. habara, &c.: see Supplement.]
DarobN haborN: see saEorN.

hiboriyapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hubaAriyapN↓ (TA) [Scurf on the head;] what is in the hair of the head, resembling bran; (Ṣ;) the dirt of the head, that clings to the lower part of the hair, resembling bran; (Ḳ;) as also UiboriyapN (TA) and tiboriyapN. (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ, in art. tbr.)

Also, [↓both words,] What flies about, of, or from, feathers, (Ḳ, TA,) and the like: (TA:) and the former, what flies about, of, or from, the down of cotton: (Ḳ:) or the fine down that flies about from cotton: (L:) and what becomes scattered about, and compacted, of, or from, canes, or reeds, and the barodiI- [or papyrus]: (Yaạḳoob:) pl. of the former, hiboriyaAtN. (TA.)
hubaAriyapN: see above, in two places.
hab-uwrN Barley growing, or growing forth; in the Nabathaean language. (Saʼeed ibn Jubeyr, TA, art. ESf.)

1. habaXa, aor. _i {yahobiXu}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. haboXN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He collected a thing; (TA;) as also habiXa, aor. _a {yahobaXu}: (ISk, ISd:) he collected; and gained or earned, or sought sustenance; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also thb-X↓: (Ṣ, A:) or he practised some art or trade, to procure sustenance; and he exercised art, craft, cunning, or skill, in the management of his affairs: (TA:) and AhtbX↓ and thb-X↓ he gained or earned, or sought sustenance; and collected; and exercised art, craft, cunning, or skill, in the management of his affairs: (ISd, TA:) and hb-X↓, inf. n. tahobiyXN, he collected much; syn. jm-E. (Ḳ.) You say, huwa yahobiXu liEiyaAlihi He collects; and gains or earns, or seeks sustenance; for his family, or household; (Ṣ;) as also yatahab-aXu↓: (Ṣ, A:) or practises some art or trade, to procure sustenance for them; exercises art, craft, cunning, or skill, in the management of his affairs, for them. (TA.) [See also HabaXa.]
habaXotuhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) I obtained it, (Ḳ, TA,) by collecting and gaining or earning. (TA.) And AhtbX↓ minohu EaTaMCF He obtained from him a gift. (Ḳ.)
habaXa Alganama, inf. n. as above, [app. meaning He roused and scared the sheep or goats, and drove and collected them to some person or place,] is like najaXa AlS-ayoda. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)
2: see 1.

hom.sense: 5. thb-X: see 1, in three places.

Also, and AhtbX↓, It became collected; or it collected itself: or the former, it became collected, or it collected itself, from several places: syns. tajam-aEa and UijotamaEa. (Ḳ.) And thb-X Alqawomu The company of men became collected as an army, or a military force; or collected itself into an army, or a military force. (TA.)
8: see 1, in two places:
and see 5.

entry.sense: hubaAXapN i. q. HubaAXapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. What is collected, of men, and of property: (Ṣ, TA:) a company, or body, of men, not of one tribe: (TA, in art. HbX:) and what one gains or earns, and collects, of property: pl. hubaAXaAtN. (TA.)

hab-aAXN One who collects; and who gains, or earns, or seeks sustenance: (Ṣ:) or who does so much: (Lth, Ḳ, TA;) and who exercises art, craft, cunning, or skill, in the management of his affairs, for his family, or household. (Lth, TA.)
mahobuwXN Collected; and gained or earned. (Ṣ,* TA.)

hom.sense: 1. habaTa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yahobiTu} and _u {yahobuTu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) but the latter is of rare occurrence, (Mṣb,) inf. n. hubuwTN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of that whereof the aor. is _i, and of that whereof the aor. is _u; (TA;) or of the latter only, that of the former being haboTN; (Mṣb;) He, or it, (said of water, &c., Mṣb,) descended: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and thb-T↓ he descended, or went down, or went down a declivity; and it sloped down; syn. UinoHadara; (TA;) and AnhbT↓ signifies the same as this last; or † he became lowered, or degraded; syn. UinoHaT-a; (Ḳ;) being quasi-pass. of OahobaTahu↓, (Ṣ, TA,) and it may be also of habaTahu, as is said in the M. (TA.) You say, habaTonaA fiI HaduwrK SaEobapK [We descended a difficult declivity]. (A, in art. Hdr.) And habaTa AlwaAdiIa, (Bḍ, ii. 58, and Mṣb,) [as though it were trans., for fiI AlwaAdiI,] inf. n. hubuwTN, (Mṣb,) We descended into the valley. (Bḍ, Mṣb.) And habaTa minohu He came forth from it. (Bḍ, ubi supra.) It is said in the Ḳur, ii. 58, UihobiTuwA miSorFA Descend ye into Misr: (Bḍ:) accord. to one reading, OuhobuTuwA. (Bḍ, TA.) You say also habaTa balada kacaA He entered such a town or country. (Ḳ.) And habaTotu mino mawoDiEK UilaI mawoDiEK I removed him from a place to a place. (Mṣb.)

haboTN also signifies ‡ The falling into evil: (Ḳ, TA:) and ‡ the being, or becoming, low, abject, mean, or vile: (TA:) and ‡ the suffering loss, or diminution. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, habaTa mino manozilatihi ‡ He fell from his honourable station. (TA.) [See also 7, mentioned above.] And habaTa fulaAnN ‡ Such a one became low, abject, mean, or vile. (TA.) And habaTa mina AlxaXoyapi ‡ He became mean, or abject, and lowly, or submissive, from fear (TA.) [See Ḳur, ii. 69.] And habaTa Alqawomu, aor. _i {yahobiTu}, ‡ The people, or company of men, became in a state of abasement and diminution. (TA.) Whence the trad., (TA,) Oall-ehum-a gaboTFA laA haboTFA, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. nasoOaluka AlgiboTapa wanaEuwcu bika mino Oano nahobiTa Eano HaAlinaA [‡ O God, we ask of Thee a good state, or condition, and we put our trust in Thee for preservation that we may not become brought down from our state]: (Ṣ.) mentioned [and explained] before, in art. gbT, q. v. (TA.) [But in this instance, haboTFA may be regarded as the inf. n. of the trans. v. to be mentioned below.] You say also, habaTato UibiliI waganamiI, aor. _i {yahobiTu}, inf. n. hunuwTN, † My camels, and my sheep, or goats, suffered loss, or diminution: and in the same sense habaTa is said of flesh, and of fat, and of fatness. (TA.) And habaTa vamanu Als-iloEapi ‡ The price of the commodity, or article of merchandise, became diminished, or lessened, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) below its former full rate; (Mṣb;) became lowered, or abated. (TA.) And habaTa AlEidolu † The counterpoising portion of the load became adjusted or arranged, made even, or made easy, upon the camel. (TA.)

habaTahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb. Ḳ.) aor. _u {yahobuTu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. haboTN, (Ṣ,) He made him, or it, (namely water., &c., Mṣb,) to descend: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [he sent, or east, him, or it, down;] as also AhbThu↓. (Ḳ.) You say, OahobaTatohumu↓ Als-anapu UilaI AlOamoSaAri [The year of dearth, or drought, caused them to go down to the cities, or great towns]. (A, in art. Hsr.) And habaTahu balada kacaA He, or it, caused him to enter such a town or country. (Ḳ.) [And habaTa bihi EalaI makaAnK He, or it, made him to alight upon a place: see an ex. voce zaH-a.]

‡ He lowered him, or degraded him, from his state, or condition; (Fr;) as also AhbThu↓; (Fr, Ṣ;) i. e., God did so; (Fr;) or a man: (Ṣ:) it (time, or fortune,) caused his wealth, and his goodness or beneficence, to go away, after he had abounded therein. (TA.)
habaTa AlmaraDu laHomahu ‡ The disease rendered him lean; emaciated him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or diminished his flesh. (TA.)

habaTa vamana Als-iloEapi, (Ṣ, Ḳ.) inf. n. haboTN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He (God, Ḳ, or a man, Ṣ) diminished, or lessened, the price of the commodity, or article of merchandise; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he lowered, or abated, it; (TA;) as also AhbThu↓, said of a man: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M:) or habaTa mina Alv-amani † he diminished somewhat from the price; and sometimes AhbThu↓ is used in this sense. (Mṣb.)
habaTa AlEidola † He adjusted or arranged, made even, or made easy, the counterpoising portion of the load upon the camel (TA.)
habaTa fulaAnFA He beat, or struck, such a one. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see habaTahu, in five places.
5: see habaTa, first sentence.
7: see habaTa, first sentence.
haboTapN A low, or depressed, piece of land or ground; (Mgh, Ḳ;) contr. of SaEodapN. (Mgh.)
habuwTN A declivity, or declinal place, a place of descent, or by which one descends, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a place which brings one down from a higher to a lower place. (Az, TA.)

haAbiTN [act. part. n. of 1, both intrans. and trans.] The rájiz says,
maA raAEaniI Uil-aA janaAHN haAbiTaA
EalaI Albuyuwt qawoTahu AlEulaAbiTaA
[Nothing surprised me but the wolf sending down upon the tents his flock of sheep, or goats, fifty or more in number]: he means muhobiTFA qawoTahu: so says ISd: or he may mean haAbiTFA EalaI qawoTihi [descending upon his flock,, &c.]; making hAbTA trans by ellipsis: (TA:) jnAH, in this verse, is the name of a wolf. (TA, in art. jnH.)
See also habiyTN.
mahobiTu AlwaHoIi [The place of descent of revelation;] a name of Mekkah. (Mṣb, TA)
mahobuwTN ‡ A man whose state, or condition has become unsound. (TA.)
See also habyTN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. hat-a, aor. _i {yahotitu}, inf. n. hatiytN, He (a bakor, or young camel,) uttered a sound resembling a squeezing of the voice (Xbh AlESr llSwt): you say, of a bkr, observes Az, yahit-u, inf. n. as above; then, yakiX-u, inf. n. kaXiyXN then yahodiru, inf. n. hadiyrN. (L.)
hat-a Alhamozapa,, aor. _u {yahotutu}, inf. n. hat-N, He uttered the letter hemzeh. (L.) [See mahotuwtN.]
ht, aor. _u {yahotutu}, inf. n. hat-N, He uttered, recited, or repeated, a speech or the like, with uninterrupted fluency; syn. sarada (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and taAbaEa. (L.)

[Hence] hat-ato gazolahaA, aor. _u {yahotutu}, inf. n. hat-N, She spun her thread one part immediately after another: (TA:) she spun her thread continuously: (Az:) hat-N signifies a woman's spinning thread continuously. (Ḳ.)

hat-a, aor. _u {yahotutu}, inf. n. hat-N; and hatohata↓, inf. n. hatohatapN; He broke a thing, (Ḳ,) so that it became reduced to small fragments, or particles: (TA:) he stamped upon a thing vehemently, so that he broke it. (TA.)
hat-a, aor. _u {yahotutu}, inf. n. hat-N, He rent clothes. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
Also, † He rent the reputation of another. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
hat-a, aor. _u {yahotutu}, inf. n. hat-N, He removed the leaves of a tree [by rubbing or scraping the branches]; syn. Hat-a; (Ḳ [in the CK, hat-, is put for Ht-;]) i. e. he took them. (TA.)
hat-a, aor. _u {yahotutu}, inf. n. hat-N, He poured out, or forth, [water, &c.] (Ḳ.)
hat-a AlmazaAdapa He poured out, or forth, [the contents of] the mzAdp. (TA.)
hat-a XayoYFA He poured out, or forth, one part or portion of a thing immediately after another. (TA.)
Als-aHaAbapu taHut-u AlmaTara The cloud pours forth the rain continuously. (TA.)
hat-a, aor. _u {yahotutu}, inf. n. hat-N, he lowered (HaT-a) a person with respect to rank, or dignity, in [the manner of] paying honour [to him]. (IAạr, Ḳ.) [Comp. hbt.]

entry.sense: R. Q. 1. hatohata He urged a camel (zajarahu) on the occasion of drinking, by the cry hato hato. (AHeyth, Ḳ.) See hato, below.
hatohata, inf. n. hatohatapN; as also tahotaha; He twisted, or distorted, his tongue in speaking. (Az.)
Also htht; (and hat-a↓, TA, [aor. _i {yahotitu}?];) He was quick, or rapid, in his speech. (Ḳ.)
See hat-a.

hom.sense: hato, (TA,) or hato hato, (Ḳ,) A cry by which a camel is urged (yuzojaru) on the occasion of drinking. (Ḳ.)

UicaA waq-afota AlbaEiyra EalaI Alr-adohapi falaA taqulo lahu hato; or, as some say, falaA tuhatohito bihi; [When thou hast made the camel to stand over the hollow in the rock in which the rain-water has collected, say not to him hato]. A proverb; meaning, accord. to AHeyth, when thou hast shewn a man his right course of conduct, do not urge him. (TA.)
hat-u qawaAYimi AlbaEiyri The sound of the falling of the camel's feet [upon the ground]. (L.)
tarakahumo hat-FA bat-FA [He left them routed, or broken asunder, and cut off;] he broke them asunder: or he cut them in pieces. (L.)
hatiytN A sound. Occurring in a trad. as signifying a sound made by wine poured out upon the ground. (L.)
hatiytN and mahotuwtN↓ A thing broken so as to be reduced to small fragments, or particles: stamped upon vehemently, so as to be broken. (TA.)

entry.sense: hat-aAtN: see mihat-N.
rajulN mihat-N, and hat-aAtN↓, A man quick and voluble in speech; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) incorrectly, and vainly, or frivolously, loquacious; a great babbler. (TA.)
mahotuwtN: see hatiytN.

Alhamozapu SawotN mahotuwtN fiI OaqoSaI AlHaloqi [Hemzeh is a sound uttered (after a suppression of the breath) in the most remote part of the throat]. (Kh, L.) Sb applied the term Almahotuwtu to the letter h, because of its weakness and lowness. (L.)
OasoraEu mina Almuhatohitapi Quicker than the quick-speaking woman. (IAạr.)
1. hataOa, aor. _a {yahotaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. hatoCN, (TA,) He beat a person (Ḳ) with a staff or stick. (TA.)
hatiYa, aor. _a {yahotaOu}, He was bent, or crooked. (Ḳ.)
5. tht-O It (a garment) became ragged, and worn out. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

maDaI mina All-ayoli hatoCN, and hitoCN↓, (ISk, Ḳ,) and hatiIoCN↓, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) and hatiI-N↓, (Lḥ,) and hitaACN↓, and hiytiYN↓ (same measure as ziborijN, as in the TA), or hitoyaMCN↓, (as in the CK and a MṢ. copy) and hiytaMCN↓, (Ḳ,) and hatoOapN↓, (AHeyth, Ḳ,) A portion of the night elapsed (Ḳ, &c.)
maA baqiIa mino ganamihimo Uil-aA hitoCN There remained not, of their sheep, or goats, save a part, less than the part that had gone away. (TA.)
hitoCN: see hatoCN.
hataON and hutuwoCN↓ A rent. (Ḳ.)
A swelling: syn. nutuw-N, (TA.)
hatoOapN: see hatoCN.
hitaMCN: see hatoCN.
hatiIoCN: see hatoCN.
hatiI-N: see hatoCN.
hutuwoCN: see hataON.
hitoyaMCN: see hatoCN.
hiytaMCN: see hatoCN.
hiytiYN: see hatoCN.
OahotaOu Humpbacked. (Ḳ.)

1. hatarahu, aor. _i {yahotiru}, (Ḳ, TA,) like yaDoribu, (TA [in the CK, _?, but this is evidently a mistake,]) It (old age, Ḳ, TA, and disease and grief, TA), made him to be such as is called muhotarN; [i. e., made him to lose his reason, or intellect: or to be addicted to, or fond of, speaking of a thing: which latter signification seems to be particularly indicated in the lexicon from which this is taken; but the former seems the more appropriate.] (Ḳ.)

3. hAtrhu, [inf. n. muhaAtarapN and hitaArN,] He encountered him with mutual reviling, saying what was false: (Ḳ,* TA:) so says IAmb, on the authority of AZ; but, says Th, accord. to others, AlmuhaAtarapu signifies the saying [that] whereof one part contradicts, or annuls, another: and hence one says, daEi AlhitaAra [leave the saying that whereof one part contradicts another]. (TA.)

4. Ouhotira He became disordered in his intellect: (A, TA:) or he became so by reason of old age: (Ṣ:) or he lost his reason from old age, (AZ, AʼObeyd, Ḳ,) as also Uisotahotara↓, (AZ, TA,) or from disease, or grief; as also Oahotara. (Ḳ.) See also 10, in two places.
5. tht-r He was, or became, stupid, and ignorant. (Ḳ: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.)
6. thAtrA They accused each other falsely. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And hence, thAtrt Albay-inaAtu, (Mṣb,) and AlX-ahaAdaAtu, (A, Mgh,) The testimonies, or evidences, became null: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or belied one another. (A.)
10. Uisotahotara: see 4.
He was, or became, much given to false, or vain, sayings, or actions. (TA [but this seems rather to be Ousotuhotira: see its part. n., below.])
† He followed his own natural desire, not caring what he did. (Mṣb [but this also seems to be in the pass. form.])

Ousotuhotira bikacaA ‡ He became addicted to, or fond of, such a thing, (Ḳ, TA,) not talking of any other thing, (TA,) nor caring what was done to him, (Ḳ, TA,) nor how he was reviled: (Ḳ:) he became addicted to, or fond of, such a thing, not talking of, nor doing, any other thing: and he became fascinated by such a thing, and lost his reason on account of it, and his strong determination became turned towards it, so that he talked much and vainly respecting it. (TA.)

Uisotahotara bifulaAnapa, [or Ousotuhotira,] and Oahotara↓ bihaA, [or Ouhotira,] ‡ He [became attached, or devoted, to such a woman so that he] cared not what was said of him on her account, nor how he was reviled: (A, TA:) and Ouhotira↓ also signifies † he became addicted or given to, or fond of, speaking of a thing. (Ḳ.)
hutorN The loss of reason from old age or disease or grief. (Ḳ.)

hitorN An error in speech. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, jaMCa bihitorK mina Alqawoli He uttered an error of speech. (A.)
And hitorN haAtirN↓ A great error of speech. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
A falsehood; a lie. (Ḳ.) You say, qawolN hitorN A false saying (TA.)
haAtirN: see hitorN.

tahaAtiru Testimonies, or evidences, that belie one another: as though pl. of tahotarN: (Ḳ:) or any evidences, or testimonies, that are not legal proofs (Mgh [but in my copy of that work written tahAtur.])

muhotarN Disordered in his intellect, (Ṣ,) or having lost his reason, (AZ, AʼObeyd, Ḳ,) from old age. (AZ, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or from disease, or grief: (Ḳ:) if from Oahotara, it is anomalous. (Ḳ, TA,) like muHoSanN, &c. (TA.)
† Addicted or given to, or fond of, speaking of a thing (Ḳ.) See also musotahotarN.
muhotirN Erring in his speech. (TA.)

musotahotarN Much given to false, or vain, sayings, or actions: (Ḳ:) or one who says what is false or erroneous: or one who cares not what is said of him, nor how he is reviled: or † attached, or devoted, (musotahotarN,) to the world (IAth, TA)

musotahotarN biXaIoCK ‡ Addicted to, or fond of, a thing, (Ḳ, TA,) or fascinated by it, (A,) not talking of any other thing, (TA,) nor caring what is done to him, (A, Ḳ, TA,) nor how he is reviled, (Ḳ,) having lost his reason; (A.) as also muhotarN↓. (A.) You say, fulaAnN musotahotarN biAlX-araAbi ‡ Such a one is addicted to, or fond of, drink, not caring what is said of him. (Ṣ.)
1. hav-a, [aor. _u {yahovuvu},] inf. n. hav-N, He mixed a thing, one part with another. (M.)
hav-a,, [aor. _i {yahovivu},] inf. n. hav-N, He lied. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. havohava, inf. n. havohavapN, He mixed, or confounded; like mavomava. (TA.) hvhv Oamorahu He confounded his affair. (TA.)
havohava, inf. n. havohavapN, It was mixed, or confounded. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
havohava, (inf. n. havohavapN, Ḳ,) He (a magistrate, Ṣ) acted unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hvhv Aln-aAsa He (a magistrate) acted unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, towards the people. (TA.)
havohava, inf. n. havohavapN, It sent forth quickly: (Ḳ:) [ex.] havohavati Als-aHaAbapu biquTorihaA wavalojihaA The cloud sent forth quickly its rain and its snow. (Ṣ.)
havohava, inf. n. havohavapN (and hvhAv, TA) He trod, or trampled, vehemently. (Ḳ.)
It (a pasturing herd or flock) trod the fresh green pasture until it was destroyed, HtI ywtI [So in the L, app. Hat-aI yuWutiIa].

entry.sense: hav-N and havohavapN↓ and hvhAv↓ A confusion of sounds, noises, or voices, in war or a raising of a loud cry, or clamour, or confused noise (M,) [App. inf. n., of which the verbs are hav-a and havohava]
havohavapN and havohaAvN↓ A word imitative of somewhat of the speech of how who has the vitious kind of pronunciation termed luvogap (TA.) See hav-N
havohaAvN Quick (Ḳ) rain (TA.)
havohaAvN Confused, confounded: (Ḳ,) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)
havohaAvN A town, or district, abounding with dust. (Ḳ)
hivohaAvN: see hav-N.
hav-aAvN and havohaAvN↓ A liar, (Ḳ.)
Also, the latter, A man who tells unmixed lies. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. haj-ati Aln-aAru aor. _i {yahojiju}, inf. n. hajiyjN and haj-N; (L;) The fire burned fiercely, or intensely; or flamed, or blazed. or burned without smoke, fiercely, or intensely or, made a noise, or sound: hajiyju Aln-aAr being the same as OajiyjuhaA, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) like as haraAqa is the same as OaraAqa (Ṣ, L,) or, burned, and caused a sound, or noise, to be heard by its burning. (L.)
See art. Eaj-a, last para.

entry.sense: 2. hj-j Aln-aAra He made the fire to burn fiercely, or intensely; or to flame, or blaze, or burn without smoke, fiercely, or intensely: or, to make a noise, or sound, or to burn so as to cause a sound, or noise. to be heard by its burning. (L.)
hj-j He (a camel) had his eyes sunk in his bead by reason of hanger or thirst or fatigue; not by their natural formation. (Lth, Aṣ.)

haj-ajato EayonuhN [so in three copies of the Ṣ, and in the L; not haj-ato, as Golius seems to have found it written in a copy of the Ṣ;] His eye became sunk in its socket, (Aṣ, Ṣ) In the saying of the daughter of El-Khuss, when she was asked how she knew a she-camel to be pregnant, OaraI AlEayona haAj-o waAls-anaAma raAj-o watamoXiI fatufaAj-o [I see the eye to have become sunk, and the hump to have shaken, or moved to and fro, and she walks, and straddles in doing so], hAj- may be [an act. part. n.] formed from haj-ato, although this form of the verb be not used; and she makes AlEyn masc., meaning thereby AlEuDow or AlT-arof; for properly she should have said haAj-ap: or hAj- is used [instead of haj-aj-ato] in im-cation of rAj- [and tfAj-]. (L.)
3. hAj- fiI hadiyrihi He (a camel) made his braying to reciprocate. (L.)
4: see Eaj-a last paragraph
8. Ahtj- fiyhi He persevered (tamaAdI) in it, Ḳ. i. e., in his judgment, not listening to the counsel of any one. (TA.)
10. Asthj- He followed his own judgment. (Ḳ,) whether erring or taking a right course, without consulting any one. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. hajohaja bAls-aboEi (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Als-aboE, (L,) He cried one to the lion or others beasts of prey, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and chid him, in order that he ought refrain, forbear, or abstain (Ṣ) [See haji.]

hajohaja biAlojamali He chid the camel, saying to him hiyj; (Ḳ; [in the CK. hiyja, see art hyj;]) or hyjo; (accord. to the TA;) [but it occurs in a verse written hyj] and in like manner bAln-aAqapi, the she-camel (L.)
hajohaja fiI hadiyrihi, said of a stallion-camel, (Ṣ) He make a vehement noise in his braying. (L.)

hajK and hajo, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like as one says naxK and baxo, (Ṣ,) or hijiI. as related by Lḥ, (L,) and hajA (Ḳ,) or hajK hajK and hajo hajo and hajaA hajaA. (Az,) Cries by which one chides a dog. (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a lion, and a wolf, &c., to quiet him: (Az:) and sometimes one says hajaA hajaA (ISd,) and, if he please, hajA, once, (Az) to chide camels (ISd, Az) and hajo, or haj at the end of a verse is a cry by which a she-camel is chidden. (L.) For hajo hajo, one also says jaho jaho, by transposition. (L.)
hajohajo, (Ḳ,) and hajohaja, (Ṣ,) but the latter is only used by poetic licence, (Ḳ,) A cry by which sheep or goats (and a dog, Az,) are chidden, or checked, or urged, (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hajohajapN A word imitative of the cry of a man when he cries out to a lion. (Lth) [See haj]
hajaAjN One in whom is no good. (L, art. Eaj-aAj.)

hajaAjayoka, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also hadaAcayoka, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) in the dual number. like dawaAlayoka and HawaAlayok, (TA,) supposing [it to be addressed to] two [persons], (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or hjAjyk humunaA wahuhunaA i. e., Refrain thou! or forbear thou! or abstain thou! (TA;) said to people when one desires their refraining, or forbearing, or abstaining, from a thing: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and to a lion, and a wolf, &c., to quiet him. (Lḥ.)

rakiba hajaAja, (indecl., Ṣ,) and hajaAji, [in form], like qaTaAmi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or rkb mino Oamorihi hjAj, and rkb hajaAjayohi, in the dual. form, (TA,) He went at random, or heedlessly, without any certain aim, or object; or went his own way, without consideration, not obeying a guide to the right course; or pursued a headlong, or rash, course. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hajiyjN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and UihojiyjN↓ (Ḳ) A deep valley: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or deep, as an epithet, applied to a valley: of the dial. of El-Yemen: pl. [of the former] huj-aAnN. (TA.)

hajaAjapN, (Ḳ,) without the art. Al, (TA,) or rajulN hajaAjapN, (Ṣ,) and hajohaAjN↓ and hajohaAjapN↓, (Ḳ,) A stupid, or foolish, man; one of little sense: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the first, one who consults not any one, but follows his own judgment whether he err or take a right course: (Sh:) or without heart and without intellect or intelligence: (AA in TA, art. rE:) and the second, a rude, coarse, or churlish, and stupid, or foolish, man: (Ḳ:) and the third, a man of much evil, or mischief, and of little understanding: or, accord. to AZ, of no understanding, and of no judgment. (TA.)
hajohaAjN A camel that brays vehemently. (Ḳ.) A word imitative of the sound which a stallioncamel makes in his braying. (TA.)
hajohaAjN Wont to take fright, and to run away. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See hajaAjapN.
hajohaAjapN: see hajaAjapN.
EayonN haAj-apN, (Ṣ, L,) and muhaj-ijapN↓, (L,) An eye sunk in its socket. (Ṣ, L.) [See 2.]
muhajohijN and muhajohijapN A person chiding a lion by a cry. (L.) [See hijK.]
muhaj-ijapN: see haAj-apN.
1. hajaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yahojaOu}, inf. n. hajoCN and hujuwoCN, (Ḳ,) It (his hunger) became appeased, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and departed, or ceased. (Ḳ.)
hajaOa He ate food. (Ḳ.)
hajaOa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. hajoCN, (TA,) He filled his belly. (Ḳ.)
hajaOa and AhjO↓ He stayed, or restrained, camels (Ḳ) or sheep or goats, (TA,) that they might pasture. (Ḳ, TA.) hajiYa, aor. _a {yahojaOu}, He had raging hunger. (Ḳ.)
4: see 1.
AhjO juwEahu, inf. n. UihojaACN, It (food) appeased his hunger; or caused it to depart, or cease. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AhjOhu Haq-ahu, (Ḳ,) and AhjI, (TA,) He paid him his due. (Ḳ.)
AhjOhu XayoYFA He gave him a thing to eat. (Ḳ.)
5. thj-O AlHarofa i. q. thj-I. (Ḳ.)
hajaON Any state, or case, in which one has been, and which has ceased. (Ḳ.) It also occurs without C, hajFA (TA.)
hujaOapN Foolish; stupid. (Ḳ.)
1. hajaba, aor. _u {yahojubu}, inf. n. hajobN, He drove, or urged along. (Ḳ.)
Also, He beat with a stick, or staff. (Ḳ.)
Also, hajaba, inf. n. as above, He was quick, or swift, (Ḳ,) in his pace, &c. (TA.)
This art. is omitted by most of the lexicographers, because not regarded by them as of established authority. (TA.)

1. hajada, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yahojudu}, (L, Mṣb,) inf. n. hujuwdN; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and thj-d↓, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Ahjd↓, (L, Ḳ,) and hj-d↓; (IAạr, L;) He (a man, L) slept: (L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or slept in the night: (IAạr, Ṣ, A, L:) or, in the latter part of the night. (L.)

Also hajada and thj-d↓ (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ [in some copies, of the last of which the former verb is written hj-d↓ and so in the TA]) He remained awake, or was sleepless or wakeful in the night: (Ṣ, A, L:) and hence the praying in the night is called tahaj-udN: (Ṣ, L:) or he awoke from sleep (Ḳ) to pray, or for some other purpose: (TA:) or he prayed in the night; (Mṣb;) as also hj-d↓: (IAạr, L:) thus these verbs bear two contr. significations: (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and thj-d↓ he relinquished sleep for prayer: (A:) so in the Ḳur, xvii., 81. (Beyd.)
2: see 1, in three places.
Also hj-dhu, inf. n. tahojiydN, He made him, or caused him, to sleep; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also Ahjdhu↓. (Ibn-Buzurj, L, Ḳ.)
Also, He awoke him from sleep. (Ibn-Buzurj, L, Ḳ.) Thus it bears two contr. significations. (Ḳ.)
See also 4.
4: see 1: and 2.
Also Ahjdhu He found him (namely a man, Ḳ) sleeping. (L, Ḳ.)

And Ahjd He (a camel) laid the fore-part of his neck (the part called jiraAn) upon the ground; (ISk, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also hj-d↓, (IḲṭṭ, El-Basáïr, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK hajada]) inf. n. tahojiydN. (IḲṭṭ, El-Basáïr, TA.)
5: see 1, in three places.
hajido, (as in some copies of the Ḳ,) or hijodo, (accord. to others and the TA,) A cry by which a horse is chidden. (Ḳ.)
hajuwdN: see haAjidN.
haAjidN Sleeping: (T, L, Mṣb:) pl. hujuwdN and huj-adN. (Mṣb.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce murim-N, in art. rm.]

Also, (L,) and hajuwdN↓ (L, Ḳ) and mutahaj-idN↓ (T, L) Praying in the night: (T, L, Ḳ:) pl. of the first, (L,) or second, (L, Ḳ,) hujuwdN and huj-adN. (L, Ḳ.) hujodN and huj-adN are also fem. pls. [app. in both of the above senses]. (A.)
mutahaj-idN: see haAjidN.

hom.sense: 1. hajarahu, (Ṣ, A, &c.,) aor. _u {yahojuru}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. hajorN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and hijoraAnN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) He cut him off from friendly or loving, communion or intercourse; contr. of waSalahu: (Ṣ, Mgh:) he forsook, or abandoned, him; syn. qaTaEahu: (Mṣb, TA:) he cut him; meaning, he ceased to speak to him, or to associate with him; syn. Saramahu, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and qaTaEa kalaAmahu. (Mgh.) It is said in the Ḳur, [iv. 38,] waQhojuruwhun-a fiI AlmaDaAjiEK, i. e., [And cut ye them off from loving intercourse] in the sleeping-places, in order to obtain their obedience. (Mṣb.) See also 3.

He left it; forsook it; relinquished it; abandoned it; deserted it; quitted it: abstained from it: neglected it: shunned or avoided it; was averse from it: syn. tarakahu; (A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and rafaDahu; (Mṣb;) and faAraqahu: (B:) and Oagofalahu: and OaEoraDa Eanohu: (TA:) namely, a thing to which it was necessary for him to pay frequent attention: (Lth, TA:) as also Oahojarahu↓; (Ḳ;) which latter is of the dial. of Hudheyl: (TA:) and hujira he, or it, was left;, &c. (IḲṭṭ.) hijoraAnN may be with the body and with the tongue and with the heart or mind: it is with the first in the passage of the Ḳur cited above: it may be with any of the three in the Ḳur, [lxxiii. 10,] where it is said, waQhojurohumo hajorFA jamiylFA [And avoid thou them, i. e., avoid the associating with them in person, or speaking to them, or entertaining friendship for them in thy heart, with an avoiding of a becoming kind]: and it is with all the three in the following ex. in the Ḳur, [lxxiv. 5,] waQlr-ijoza faQhojuro [And idolatry avoid thou]. (B.) You say also, hajara AlX-iroka, inf. n. hajorN and hijoraAnN, [He abstained from, or avoided, polytheism, or the associating of others with God,] hijorapF HasanapF [with a good manner of abstaining, or avoiding]. (Lḥ, Ḳ.) And it is said in a trad., walaA yasomaEuwna AlquroMna Uil-aA hajorFA, meaning, [And they hear not the Ḳur-án save] with neglect of it, and aversion from it: the reading Al-A hujorFA, mentioned by IḲt, and his explanation of it, save with foul speech, are both said by El-Khaṭṭábee to be erroneous. (TA.)
hajara, [aor. _u {yahojuru},] inf. n. hajorN, He (a man) went, removed, retired, or withdrew himself, to a distance, far away, or far off. (TA.)
hajara fiI AlS-awomi, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yahojuru}, inf. n. hijoraAnN, (TA,) He abstained from sexual intercourse in fasting. (Ḳ.)

hajara, (Lth, Fr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) or hajara fiI kalaAmihi, (Mṣb,) aor. _u {yahojuru}, (Lth, Fr, Ṣ, &c.,) inf. n. hajorN, (Lth, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) with fet-ḥ, (Mgh,) or hujorN, with damm, (Ḳ,) and hij-iyraI, (A, Ḳ,) or this is a simple subst., (Lth,) and UihojiyraI, (Ḳ,) [or this and that which immediately precedes it are intensive inf. ns.,] He (a sick man, Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, or one having the disease termed birosaAm, AʼObeyd, A, or having a fever, AʼObeyd, and one sleeping. Fr, Ḳ) talked nonsense; talked irrationally or foolishly or deliriously, (Lth, Fr, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and confusedly: (Mṣb:) or hij-iyraI signifies the talking much, and saying what is evil. (Sb.) In the Ḳur, [xxiii. 69,] instead of tahojuruwna, in the phrase saAmirFA tahojuruwna, [Holding discourse by night, talking irrationally or foolishly,] I’Ab reads tuhojiruwna from Oahojara↓, [q. v.,] from Alhujoru. (TA.)
See also 4.
hajara bihi, aor. _u {yahojuru}, inf. n. hajorN, He dreamed of him or it; or saw him or it in sleep: or he did so and talked foolishly or deliriously. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. hj-r, (Lth, A, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. tahojiyrN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He journeyed in the time called the haAjirap; (Lth, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ;) as also thj-r↓; (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and Ahjr↓: (Ḳ:) or he went forth in that time: (Az, TA:) or he was (SaAra) in that time: (Mṣb: [but in my copy of that work, SAr is perhaps a mistake for saAra:]) or Ahjr↓ has this last signification; (Lth, TA;) or signifies he entered upon that time; like AZhr (A.)
It (the day) attained to the time called he haAjirap. (Ṣ, TA.)

3. hAjrhu, (A,) inf. n. muhaAjarapN; (B;) and Ahtjrhu↓; (A;) He cut him off from friendly, or loving, communion or intercourse, being so cut off by him; or he cut him, or ceased to speak to him, being in like manner cut by him: and he forsook, or abandoned, him, being forsaken, or abandoned, by him: (A,* B:) this is the primary signification of the former. (B.)

hAjr, (T, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. muhaAjarapN (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb) and hijorapN, (A,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mgh, Mṣb,) He (an inhabitant of the desert) went forth from his desert to the cities or towns: this is the primary acceptation, with the Arabs, of the verb [when intrans.]: also, he (any one) left his place of abode, emigrating to another people: (Az:) he departed, or went forth, from one land to another, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or from one country, or district, or town, to another: (Mṣb:) and, as used in the Ḳur, ii. 215, [and in many other instances in the same and other books,] he went forth [or emigrated] from the territory of the unbelievers to the territory of the believers [or to any place of safety or refuge on account of religious persecution, &c.] (B.) See an ex. voce tahaj-ara; and see hijorapN.

hom.sense: 4. Ahjrhu: see hajarahu.
Ahjr bihi He mocked, or scoffed, or laughed at him, derided him, or ridiculed him, and said respecting him what was foul, evil, bad, abominable, or unseemly. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
See also 2, in two places.

5. thj-r He affected to be like the muhaAjiruwn [or emigrants from the territory of the unbelievers to that of the believers]. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) Hence the trad., haAjiruwA↓ walaA tahaj-aruwA, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, A,) i. e., Perform ye the hijorap with sincerity towards God, and affect not to be like those who do so without your being really such as do so: said by ʼOmar. (AʼObeyd, TA.)
See also 2.

entry.sense: 6. thAjrwA [They cut one another off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse; or they cut, or ceased to speak to, one another: they forsook, or abandoned, one another: as also AhtjrwA↓] (A.) You say also humaA yatahaAjaraAni, and yahotajiraAni↓, i. e., yataqaATiEaAni [They two cut each other off, &c.]: (Ḳ:) tahaAjurN is syn. with taqaATuEu. (Ṣ.)
8: see 3 and 6; the latter in two places.
[He journeyed in the time of the HaAjirap: see 8 in art. EXw.]

hom.sense: hajorN: see hujorN:
and see also haAjirapN.

entry.sense: hujorN, a subst. from Oahojara; (Ṣ, Mgh;) or from its syn. hajara; (Mṣb;) Foul, evil, bad, abominable, or unseemly, language, or talk; (Aṣ, Ks, T, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also hajoraMCu↓; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) and haAjirapN↓; of which last the pl. is hawaAjiru, incorrectly said by IJ to be an irreg. pl. of hujorN; or haAjirapN↓ may be an inf. n., like kaAcibapN, &c. (IB.) You say, qaAla hujorFA wabujorFA, and hajorFA↓ wabajorFA, [He said] a foul [and a wonderful] thing: hajorN↓ is an inf. n., and hujorN is a simple subst. (L, TA.) And ramaAhu biQlohaAjiraAti↓ He assailed him with foul words: hAjrAt being a word of the same class as laAbino and taAmirN. (A, Mṣb.) And ramaAhu bihaAjiraAtK↓, and bimuhojiraAtK↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or biQlohaAjiraAti, (A,) and biQlomuhojiraAti, (A, Mṣb,) He accused him of evil things that exposed him to disgrace: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or of foul, or evil, actions. (A, Mṣb.) And takal-ama biQlomahaAjiri↓ (in the CK bAlmuhAjiri) He spoke foul, or evil, language. (L, Ḳ.)
hijir-N: see hijorapN.
hujorapN: see hijorapN.

hijorapN, a subst. from hajarahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also hijoraAnN↓, (Mṣb,) signifying The cutting another off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse: (Ṣ:) cutting one; or ceasing to speak to him: (Ḳ:) forsaking, abandoning, deserting, or shunning or avoiding, one. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., laA hijorapa baEoda valaAvK [There shall be no cutting off from friendly communion after three nights with their days,]: the meaning is, hajorN as contr. of waSolN; i. e., such anger as exists between Muslims, or a failing, or falling short, with respect to the duties of society, exclusively of what relates to religion: but the hijorap of those who follow their own natural desires [in matters of religion], and of innovators [in religion], should continue even as long as they do not repent, and return to the truth. (TA.)
[Also, A mode, or manner, of cutting another off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse:, &c. See 1, where an ex. occurs.]

Also, A removal from the desert to the towns or villages: this was its [primary] acceptation with the Arabs: and the forsaking of his country, or district, or the like, by an inhabitant of the desert, or by an inhabitant of a town, or village, or cultivated district, and taking up his abode in another country or district, or the like, an emigration; (TA;) the forsaking of one's home and removing to another place; (Mgh;) the forsaking of a country, or district, or the like, and removing to another; (Mṣb;) the going forth from one land to another; as also hujorapN↓. (Ḳ:) [and an emigration from the territory of the unbelievers to the territory of the believers, or to any place of safety or refuge on account of religious persecution, &c.: see 3, last signification:] a subst. from haAjara. (Mṣb, TA.)

[AlhijorapN, peculiarly, The emigration, or flight, (for it was really a flight,) of Moḥammad, from Mekkeh to Yethrib, which latter was afterwards called El-Medeeneh. Hence, taOoriyxu Alhijorapi The era of the Hijreh, or Flight. The epoch of this era is not the date of the Flight itself, as some have imagined, (for this took place on an uncertain day, most probably the first or second, of the third lunar month of the Arabian year,) but is the first day of the Arabian year in which the Flight happened: and as I believe that all European writers who have attempted to fix it, prior to M. Caussin de Perceval, have erred respecting it, the true date, as shown by him, (see his “Essai sur l'Histoire des Arabes,”, &c., in the places referred to in the index to that work,) I think it important here to mention. The first year of the Flight was the two hundred and eleventh year of a period during which the Arabs made use of a defective luni-solar reckoning, making every third year to consist of thirteen lunar months; the others consisting of twelve such months. This mode of reckoning was abolished by Moḥammad in the twelfth month of the tenth year of the Flight, at the time of the pilgrimage; whence it appears that the first year of the Flight commenced, most probably, on Monday, the nineteenth of April, A. D. 622; or perhaps on the eighteenth; for the actual appearance of the new moon properly marked its commencement, and, as the new moon happened about sunset on the sixteenth, it may perhaps have been seen on the eve of the eighteenth. According to M. Caussin de Perceval, the first ten years of the Flight commenced at the following periods.]
1st. [Mon.] Apr. 19, 622
2nd. [Sat.] May 7, 623
3rd. [Th.] Apr. 26, 624
4th. [Mon.] Apr. 15, 625
5th. [Sat.] May. 3, 626
6th. [Th.] Apr. 23, 627
7th. [Tu.] Apr. 12, 628
8th. [Mon.] May. 1, 629
9th. [Fri.] Apr. 20, 630
10th. [Tu.] Apr. 9, 631
[Thus it appears that the first and fourth and seventh years were of thirteen lunar months each; and the seventh was the last year that was thus augmented: therefore, with the eighth year commenced the reckoning by common lunar years; and from this point we may use the tables which have often been published for finding the periods of commencement of years of the Flight. We must not, however, rely upon the exact accuracy of these tables: for the commencement of the month was generally determined by actual observation of the new moon; not by calculation; and we often find that a year was commenced, according as the place of observation was low or high, or to the east or west of the place to which the calculation is adapted, or according as the sky was obscure or clear, a day later or earlier than that which is indicated in the tables; and in some cases, even two days later. The twelfth day of the third month of the first year of the Flight, the day of Moḥammad's arrival at Kubà, was Monday: therefore the first day of the year was most probably the nineteenth of April, as two months of thirty days each, or twenty-nine days each, seldom occur together. But the tenth day of the first month of the sixty-first year, the day on which El-Hoseyn was slain at Kerbelà, was Friday: therefore the first day of that year, at that place, must have been Wednesday, the third of October, A. D. 680; not the first of October, as in most of the published tables above mentioned. (For the principal divisions of the Arabian year when the luni-solar reckoning was instituted, see zamanN)]. AlhijorataAni means [The two emigrations, or flights; namely,] the hijorap to Abyssinia and the hijorap to El-Medeeneh. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And cuw Alhijoratayoni He (of the SaHaAbap [or Companions of Moḥammad] TA) who emigrated, or who has emigrated, to Abyssinia and to El-Medeeneh. (Ḳ.)
hajoraMCu: see hujorN.
hijoraAnN: see hijorapN.
hijoriy-aA: see hij-iyrN.

hom.sense: hajiyrN Left; forsaken; relinquished; abandoned; deserted; quitted: abstained from: neglected: shunned or avoided. (TA.)
See also haAjirapN, in three places.

entry.sense: hajiyrapN: see haAjirapN.

hij-iyrN Custom; manner; habit; wont: state; condition; case; syn. daOobN, (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and EaAdapN, (Ṣ, TA,) and dayodanN, (TA,) and XaOonN: (T, A, Ḳ:) and the speech, or language, of a man; [or what one is accustomed to say;] syn. kalaAmN: (T, TA:) as also hij-iyraI↓, (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and UihojiyraI↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and UihojiyraMCu↓, and OuhojuwrapN↓, and hijoriy-aA↓, (Ḳ,) and Uijoriy-aA, and Uijoriy-aMCu. (Ṣ.) You say, maA zaAla celika hij-iyrahu, (A, Ḳ,* TA [in the CK, hecaA hij-iyratuhu,]) and hij-iyraAhu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and UihojiyraAhu, &c., (Ḳ,) That ceased not to be his custom,, &c. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.*) And maA lahu hij-iyraI↓ gayoruhaA He has no custom, &c., other than it. (TA, from a trad.)
hij-iyraI: see hij-iyrN.
haAjirN, act. part. n. of 1, q. v.
Talking nonsense; talking foolishly or deliriously. (Ṣ, TA.) See 1, last signification but one.

hom.sense: haAjirapN: see hujorN, in four places.

AlhaAjirapu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and hajiyrN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and hajiyrapN↓, (A, Ḳ,) and hajorN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Midday when the heat is vehement: (Ṣ:) or midday in summer, or in the hot season: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or the period from a little before noon to a little after noon in summer, or in the hot season, only: (En-Naḍr, ISk:) or from the time when the sun declines from the meridian: (Aboo-Saʼeed:) or midday, when the sun declines from the meridian, at the Zuhor: or from its declining until the EaSor: because people [then] shelter themselves in their tents or houses; as though they forsook one another (tahaAjaruwA): (Ḳ:) or the vehemence of the heat (Ḳ, TA) therein: (TA:) and Alhuwayojirapu [dim. of AlhAjrp] the period a little after the haAjirap: (EsSukkaree:) [pl. of the first, hawaAjiru.] You say, Tabaxatohu AlhawaAjiru [The vehement midday heats affected him with a hot, or burning, fever]. (A.) And SalaApu Alhajiyri↓ The prayer of noon; as also Alhajiyru, elliptically. (TA.) See also ZahiyrapN.

entry.sense: OuhojuwrapN: see hij-iyrN.
UihojiyraI: see hij-iyrN.
UihjiyraMCu: see hij-iyrN.
OatayonaA OaholanaA muhojiriyna We came to our family in the time of the haAjirap. (Ṣ.)
muhojiraAtN and mahaAjiru: see hujorN.
halo muhaj-irN kamano qaAla Is one who journeys in the haAjirap like him who stays during the time of midday? (TA, from a trad.)

hom.sense: mahojuwrN Cut off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse; forsaken, or abandoned: cut, or not spoken to. (Mgh, Mṣb.) In like manner mahojuwrFA is used in the Ḳur, [xxv. 32,] signifying avoided, or forsaken, with the tongue, or with the heart or mind. (B.) [But see what here follows.]

Talk, or language, uttered irrationally or foolishly or deliriously. It is related by Aboo-ʼObeyd, on the authority of Ibráheem, that the words of the Ḳur, Uin-a qawomiI Qt-axacuwA hecaA QloquroMna mahojuwrFA, [xxv. 32,] mean, Verily my people have made this Ḳur-án a thing of which they have said what is not true: because the sick man, when he talks irrationally or foolishly or deliriously, says what is not true: and the like is related on the authority of Mujáhid. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: muhaAjarN A place to which one emigrates. (Mṣb.)

muhaAjirN Any one, whether an inhabitant of the desert [as in the primary acceptation of the epithet] or an inhabitant of a town or village or cultivated district, who emigrates; or who forsakes his country or district or the like, and takes up his abode in another country or district or the like. Hence AlmuhaAjiruwna applied to The emigrants to El-Medeeneh: because they forsook their places of abode in which they were reared, for the sake of God, and attached themselves to an abode in which they had neither family nor property, when they emigrated to El-Medeeneh. (TA.)

1. hajasa AlX-aIoCu fiI qalobihi, (A,) or fiI Sadorihi, (Ḳ,) or biAlqalobi, (Mṣb,) aor. _i {yahojisu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ, MṢ, TA,) or _u, (Mṣb,) inf. n. hajosN, (Mṣb, TA,) The thing fell into, or occurred to, or bestirred itself in, his mind, or the mind; or occurred to his mind, or the mind, after having been forgotten; syn. waqaEa and xaTara; (Mṣb;) or, of the phrase in the A and that in the Ḳ, xaTara bibaAlihi, (A, Ḳ,) and waqaEa fiI xaladihi: (TA:)
or hajosN signifies [the thing's] talking, or suggesting something, to the person's mind, in his bosom; expl. by the words Oano yuHad-iva nafosahu fiI Sadorihi; like wisowaAsN: (Ḳ,* TA:) and hence the phrase in a trad., wamaA yahojisu fiI AlD-amaAYiri, meaning, and what falls into, or occurs in, and bestirs itself in, the minds, (yaxoTuru bihaA,) and revolves therein, of matters of discourse, and of thoughts: (TA:) or hajasa fiI SadoriI XaIoCN signifies i. q. Hadasa [app. meaning a thing came at random into my mind]: (Ṣ, L:) and you say also, hajasa fI nafosiI [it fell into, or occurred to, my mind:, &c.] (TA.)
5. tahaj-asa I. q. OaqaAma. (T, art. ErS.)
hajosN A low voice, or sound, (naboOapN,) which one hears but does not understand. (Ṣ.)
See also haAjisN.

haAjisN A thing, or an idea, or object of thought, or an opinion, coming at random into, falling into, occurring to, or bestirring itself in, the mind; (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb;) syn. xaATirN: (Ṣ, TA:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst predominates: (TA:) and hajosN↓ also signifies anything falling into, or occurring to, the mind; (Lth, Ḳ:) pl. of the former, hawaAjisu. (A, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. had-a, aor. _u {yahodudu}, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) inf. n. had-N (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and huduwdN, (L, Ḳ,) He demolished a a building; (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:*) threw it down; (TA;) pulled it down to the ground: (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, L:) demolished it with violence: (L, Ḳ:*) demolished it at once, with a vehement noise. (Mṣb.)
[Hence you say,] maA hacuhu kacaA † Such a thing did not break him, or it. (Ṣ, L.)

had-aniI AlOamoru, and had-a rukonI, † The thing distressed, and broke, or crashed, me. And [in like manner] maA had-aniI mawotu OaHadK † [The death of any one has not distressed, nor broken, or crushed, me]. (L.) And had-atohu AlmuSiybapu The ‡ calamity debilitated, or enervated, him. (Ṣ, A, L.)
had-a,, aor. _a {yahodadu}, and _i, inf. n. had-N, He (a man) was, or became, weak, (L, Ḳ,) in body; (L:) became extremely aged, or decrepit. (TḲ.)
See 7.
had-a, aor. _i {yahodidu}, inf. n. hadiydN, It (a wall or the like, Ṣ, L, or a part of a mountain, L, by its falling, Ṣ, L) made a noise; (Ṣ;) or, a violent noise. (L.)
had-ato It (the sky) sent forth a noise, or sound, occasioned by the falling of rain. (L.)
had-a, aor. _a {yahodadu}, (L,) inf. n. hadiydN, (Ṣ, L,) It (the sound called haAd-, from the sea,) made a murmuring. (Ṣ,* L.)
had-a, aor. _i {yahodidu}, inf. n. had-N, He (a camel) brayed. (TḲ.) See also R. Q. 1.

mararotu birajulK had-aka mino rajulK I passed by a man who is sufficient for they as a man; (L, Ḳ:) as also had-ika: (Ḳ.) an expression of praise (L:) or it means, the description of whose good qualities would be burdensome to thee: there are two dial. forms used in this case: some use hd- as an inf. n., [in the sense of an epithet, (marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ,) saying, in such a phrase as the above, had-ika,] in which case, it has no fem. nor dual. nor pl. form; (Ṣ, L:) the sing and dual and pl. are the same: (Ḳ:) and some make it a verb, and give it [a fem. and] a dual and a pl, and say, mrrt brjl had-aka mn rjl, as above, (Ṣ, L,) and bQmoraOapK had-anoka mni QmoraOapK, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) like as you say kaf-Aka and kafayoka, (L.,) and birajulayoni had-aAka, and birijaAlK had-uwka, and biQmoraOatayoni had-ataAka, and binisowapi hadadotaka. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

IAar also cites the following ex. [by El-Kattál El-Kilábee, (marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ)]
waliI SaAHibN fiI AlgaAri had-aka SaAHibFA
as meaning. [And I have a companion in the race;] of how great estimation, and how ingenious, and how knowing, is he [as a companion] describing a wolf: (L:) in which he who reads had-aka makes had-a a verb; and as such it has a dual and pl. and fem. but some read had-uka. making it an inf. n. used as an epithet; and as such it has no dual nor pl. nor fem. (Marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ.)

had-a Alr-ajulu also signifies Excellent is the man; (ISd, L:) and Uin-hu lahad-a Alr-ajulu Verily, excellent is the man (L, Ḳ) in hardiness and strength: (L:) and lahad-a Alr-ajulu How hardy is the man! (L.)
In a trad., Aboo Lahab is related to have said, lahad-a maA saxarakumo SaAHibukumo, [meaning How greatly hath your companion enchanted you!]: lahad-a is an expression of wonder. (L.)
fulaAnN yuhad-u Such a one is praiseworthy for hardiness (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and strength. (Ṣ, L.)

entry.sense: 2. hd-dhu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tahodiydN (Ṣ, L) and tahodaAdN; (L:) and thd-dhu↓: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb;) He threatened him; (L;) threatened him with punishment; (Mṣb;) frightened, or terrified, him. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
5: see 2.

7. Anhd- It (a building) [fell down: or] became demolished at once, with a vehement noise: (Mṣb:) and had-a↓, aor. _i {yahodidu}, it (a wall) fell down; mentioned by AḤei; and also by Es-Semeen, who concedes it; (MF;) but this form of the verb is commonly known only as transitive. (TA.)
It (a mountain) broke down. (Ṣ, L.)
10. Asthd-hu He regarded him as weak. (L.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. hadohada, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. hdohadapN, (Ṣ, L,) He (a bird) cooed; syn. qaroqara: (L, Ḳ, TA [in the CK, farofara]:) he (a pigeon) cooed syn. hadara, and hadala: (TA:) or made a murmuring or confused noise in cooing: (Ṣ, L, accord to the explanation of hadohadapN:) and he (a camel, Ṣ, L) brayed: syn. hadara: (Ḳ:) or made a murmuring or confused noise in braying (Ṣ, L,) See also 1.
hadohadato, (inf. n. hadohadpN, L.) She (a woman, Ṣ, L) shook, or rocked, a child (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) in its cradle, (L,) in order that it might sleep. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
hadohada He sent, or threw, a thing down, from a high place to a low one, (L, Ḳ.)

had-N A weak man; (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) i. e., weak in body; (L;) as also hid-N↓: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to IAạr, the latter only, meaning cowardly and weak: (Ṣ, L:) or had-N (Sh, L) and Oahd-u↓ (L, Ḳ) and hadaAdapN↓ (Sh, L, Ḳ) signify a cowardly (and weak, TA) man: (Sh, L, Ḳ:) and qawomN hadaAdN↓ a cowardly people: (Sh, L:) pl. of had-N, had-uwna: (L, Ḳ:) it has no broken pl. (L:) and of hid-N, hid-ewna. (Ḳ.) A man says to another, in threatening him, Uin-iI laEayoru had-K Verily I am not weak. (Ṣ, L.)
had-N Extreme odd age; decrepitude. (Ḳ, TA.) See 1.
had-N A cough, or harsh, sound; as also hadadN↓. (L, Ḳ.)
had-N The braying of a camel. (Lḥ, L, Ḳ.) See 1.
had-N A generous, liberal. beautiful man. (IAạr. Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*)
A strong man. (IAạr. L.)
liI SaAHibN had-uka SaAHibFA, and mararotu birajulK had-ika mino rajulK: see 1.

entry.sense: hid-N and hadarN: see had-N.
had-apN The sound of the fall of a wall or the like: (Ṣ:) or a violent sound occasional thereby, or by the fall of a part of a mountain. (L.)
The sound of rain falling from the sky. (L.)
A sinking, and falling in, of the ground. (L.)
hadohadN The voices, or cries, of jinn, or genii: without a singular. (L, Ḳ)

hudohudN A certain bird, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [namely, the hoopee, or upupa of Linnæus; so this bird is called in the present day; and this, accord. to a common tradition, is the bird mentioned in the Ḳur, xxvii. 20;] as also hudahidN (Ḳ) and hudaAhidN↓: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or the last, a certain bird resembling the pigeon: (Lth, Az, L:) or (in the Ḳ, and) hudohudN signifies a pigeon that cooes much; (IDrd in explanation of v. 20 of ch. xxvii. of the Ḳur., and AḤn, L Ḳ;)
as also hudaAhidN↓: (IDrd, AḤn, L:) and any bird that cooes; that utters the cry called qaroqarap; (L, Ḳ, TA [in the CK, yufarofiru is put for yuqaroqiru]) as also hudaAhidN↓: (Aṣ, L:) pl. (of all, Ḳ) hadaAhidu (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and hadaAhiydu: (Kr, L, Ḳ:) but ISd says of the latter, I know not how this is, unless the sing. be hadohaAdN. (L.) Er-Rá'ee says,
kahudaAhidK kasara Alr-umaApu janaAHahu
[Like a hdAhd whose wing the shooters have broken]: (Ṣ, L:) Aṣ says, he means the faAxitap, or the dubosiI-, or the waraXaAn, or the hudohud, or a man, or camels: and Lḥ says, that Ks asserts him to mean, by hdAhd, the dim. of hudohudN: but Aṣ disapproves of this; and so does ISd; but the latter adds, that it may perhaps be for hudayohidN; as some of the Arabs say duwaAb-apN and XuwaAb-apN for duwyob-apN and Xuwayob-apN; though they are only known to change the I into A before a double consonant. (L.)
hadohadapN [an inf. n. used as a simple subst.] The murmuring or confused sound of the cooing of pigeons, and of the braying of a camel [and of thunder (see zamozamapN)]: pl. hadaAhidu. (Ṣ, L.)
hadaAdN and hadaAdapN: see had-N.
hudaAhidN A stallion-camel that brays much among the she-camels but does not cover them. (L.)
See hudohudN.
hadiydN A voice, cry, sound, or noise. (L.) See also 1.
A threatening from behind one. (Aṣ, L.)

haAd-N A certain murmuring sound from the sea; (Ḳ;) a sound which is heard by people inhabiting the sea-shore, coming to them from the direction of the sea, murmuring over the land, and sometimes followed by an earthquake. (Ṣ, L.)
haAd-apN Thunder. (L, Ḳ.) Ex. maA samiEonaA AlEaAma haAd-apF We have not heard this year thunder. (L.)
Oahad-u: see had-N.

hom.sense: 1. hadaOa, aor. _a {yahodaOu}, inf. n. hadoCN and huduwoCN, He, or it, was quiet, or still, calm, or unruffled; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) was motionless; was silent: (TA:) [and so, app., AhdO↓: see muhodiYN.]
tahodaI and haAdK occur for tahodaOu and haAdiYK. (TA.)
hadaOa Eanohu It [pain or the like] became appeased, and quitted him. (TA.)
See 4.
OataAnaA waqado hadaOati Alr-ijolu ‡ He came to us when the foot (of the passenger by night) had become still. (Ṣ.)
AtAnA baEoda maA hadaOati Alr-ijolu wAlEayonu ‡ He came to us after the foot (of the passenger by night), and the eye, were at rest. (Ṣ, TA.)
hadaOa biAlmakaAni ‡ He stayed, abode, or dwelt, in the place. (Ḳ.)
hadaOa, (inf. n. huduwoCN, TA,) ‡ He died. (Ḳ.)

hadiYa, aor. _a {yahodaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. hadaON, (TA,) i. q. janiYa, He had a curving back, &c.: (Ḳ:) or he had depressed and even shoulders, inclining towards the breast; not erect, or elevated: (Lth, and others:) or he was humpbacked. (Ṣ, TA.)
hadiYa It (a camel's hump) was bent by much lading, (Ḳ,) and had its soft hair (wabar) sticking upon it, without its being wounded. (TA.)
4. AhdO He rendered quiet, still, motionless, silent. (Ḳ, TA.)
laA OahodaOahu Qll-ehu May God not give him rest from his labour, or fatigue! (Ḳ.)

hadaOa↓ AlS-abiI-a, and AhdOhu, [the latter only I find mentioned in one copy of the Ṣ: but both are mentioned in another, as well as in the TA:] He patted the child with his hand, and quieted him, that he might sleep: (Ṣ, TA:) or, accord. to Az, AhdOto Sabiy-ahaA signifies She spoke soothingly to her child, and quieted him, that he might sleep: and muhodaON is a child thus soothed. (TA.)

Accord. to IAạr, mhdO in the following verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, [quoted in the Ṣ,]
XaYizN janobiI kaOan-iI muhodaON
jaEala Alqayonu EalaI Ald-af-i Uibaro
signifies a child soothed in order that he may go to sleep. Others read it as an inf. n. (TA.)
AhdO ‡ He wore out a garment. (A.)
AhdOhu Qll-ehu God made it (a shoulder) to be in the state described in the explanation of the word OahodaOu. (Ḳ.)
AhdOhu It (old age, Ḳ, or beating, TA) rendered him what is termed OahodaOu. (Ḳ.)
hadoCN: see 1.

OataAnaA baEoda hadoCK mina All-ayoli, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and hudoCK↓, (Ḳ,) and hadoOapK↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and mahodaUK↓, and hadiIoCK↓, and huduwoCK↓, (Ḳ; the last is also an inf. n. and pl.; TA,) ‡ He came to us after a period, or portion, of the night; (Ṣ, TA;) or after about a third or fourth part of the night had elapsed, (Ṣ, TA,) when men were asleep, (Ṣ,) or at rest, and the night, and the foot of the passenger, were still: (Sb, Ḳ:) or hadoCN is the first third part of the night; from the commencement to the third, (Ḳ,) when it begins to be still. (TA.)
hadoCN and hadoIN (in which the I is said to be substituted for C, TA.) Way, or manner, of life. (AHeyth, Ḳ.)
mararotu birajulK hadoYika min r-ajulK i. q. had-ika: (see art. hd:) the latter is that which is commonly known and approved. (Ez-Zejjájee.)

entry.sense: hudoCN: see hadoCN.
hadaON Smallness of a camel's hump, occasioned by his being much laden. (Ḳ.) It is less than what is termed Hnb [a word app. incorrectly written, but which I am unable to correct]. (TA.)

hom.sense: hadoOapN Quiet; stillness; rest from motion; silence. (Lḥ.)
See hadoCN, and OahodaOu.

entry.sense: maA lahu hidoOapu layolapK, (Ḳ,) mentioned by Lḥ, but not explained by him: thought by ISd to mean He has not a night's food: (and so accord. to the Ḳ:) i. e., what may quiet his hunger or sleeplessness or anxiety. (TA.)
hadaOapN A kind of run. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: OataAnaA huduwoCFA ‡ He came to us after a sleep: (Ṣ:) after men were at rest, and sleeping. (TA.)
See hadoCN.

entry.sense: hadiIoCN: see hadoCN.
hud-aMCapN A slender horse: (Ḳ:) generally said to be a term peculiarly applied to the male only: but said by some to be common to the male and the female. (MF.)

hom.sense: huwa OahodaOu mim-aA kaAna ‡ He is more quiet, or more at rest, than he was: i. e., he is dead. From a trad. Said by Umm-Suleym to Aboo-Talhah, respecting her son, to comfort the heart of his father. (TA.)

OahodaOu i. q. OajonaOu, Having a curving back, &c.: (Ḳ:) humpbacked: (Ṣ:) or a person having the shoulders depressed, and even, and inclining towards the breast; not erect or elevated: fem. hadoMCu: you also say manokibN OahodaOu a shoulder such as is described immediately above: and OahodaOu a crooked man: (Lth, and others:) also a shoulder of which the upper part is swollen, or filled with fat and flesh, and its strength relaxed. (Ḳ: in some copies of which we read AstrxI Hylh: in others, Hmlh: [the former is the reading that I adopt].)

hadoMCu (so in the CK and a MṢ. copy: in the TA, hadoOapN↓, [which seems to be an error];) A she-camel having her hump bent by much lading, (Ḳ,) and the soft hair (wabar) sticking upon it, without its being wounded. (TA.)

entry.sense: mahodaACN: see hadoCN.
muhodaON: see 4.
muhodiYN Still; motionless. (TA, in art. xmd.)
mahodaOapN State, or condition. (Ṣ.)
tarakotuhu EalaI muhayodiYatihi I left him in the state, or condition, wherein he was: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) dim. of mahodaOapN. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. hadabahu, aor. _i {yahodibu}, He cut it; or cut it off. (Ḳ, TA.) See also hadaba.
hadaba, (aor. _i {yahodibu}, inf. n. hadobN, Ṣ,) He milked a camel: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he milked any animal with the ends of his fingers. (IḲṭṭ.)

hadiba, (inf. n. hadabN, TA;) and Ahdb↓; It (a tree) had long and pendulous branches, or twigs. (Ḳ.) The latter verb is explained by IḲṭṭ as signifying It (a tree) had numerous branches. (TA.) This is not derived from the hadab of the OaroTaI and the like (AḤn.)
hadibati AlEayonu, aor. _a {yahodabu}, (inf. n. hadabN TA,) The eye had long lashes. (Ḳ.)
2: see 1.
hd-b Als-awoTa [?] i. q. Eac-aba, q. v (A, in TA, voce Ec-b. q. v.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1.
Ahdb It (a tree) produced, or put forth, its hadab. (TA.)
5. thd-b [It (a part of a cloud) hung down like the unwoven end, or extremity, of a garment]. (Ṣ.) See hayodabN.
8: see 1.

hudobN and hudubN↓, (Ḳ,) the latter a dial. form of the former, (TA,) coll. gen. ns., and hayodabN↓, (Ḳ,) also a coll. gen. n., (TA,) and hud-aAbN↓ [likewise a coll. gen. n.,] and hudobapN↓, [which is rather the n. un. of hudobN,] (TA,) of a garment, or piece of cloth, i. q. xamolN: (Ḳ: in like manner, hudobapN↓ and hudubapN↓ are explained in the Ṣ by xamolapN:) or rather, The [fringe, or] unwoven end, or extremity, of a garment, or of a piece of cloth; its end, or extremity, that has not been woven: or an end, or extremity, consisting of warp without woof: sometimes it is twisted, and [as it forms a fringe,] it preserves the edge [of the woven part] of the garment, &c.: (whereas xml signifies the “nap, or villous substance,” of a garment, &c.: [such is the meaning of the words mA ytxl-l Alt-wb kl-h kAlz-iYobiri: this is what is generally meant by xml] and this is mostly in what are called qaTaAYifu: MF:) or the extremity of a garment, &c. next [the part called] the Tur-ap: (TA:) or the hdbp of a garment, &c., is the same as the Tur-ap: (Mṣb:) n. un. of the fist word, (hudobN or hudubN,) with p {hudobapN or hudubapN}(Ḳ:) so too of hydb, (TA,) [and of hd-Ab]. The pl. of hudobapN is hudabN. (Mṣb.)

hudobN, (Ḳ,) or hudobu AlEayoni, (Ṣ,) and hudubN↓, (Ḳ,) which is a dial form of hdb, (TA,) coll. gen. ns., The eyelashes; the hairs that grow upon the edges of the eyelids: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) n. un. with p {hudobapN}: (Ḳ:) pl. OahodaAbN. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: hadabN [generally signifies slender spring, like strings, garnished with minute, amplexicant, appressed, acute leaves, overlying one another like the scales of a fish: see EabalN:] the branches, or twigs, of the OaroTaI and similar trees (Ḳ) that have no leaves; a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p {hadabapN}: and the pl., OahodaAbN. (TA.) [The foliage of the cypress and tamarisk, and the like:] leaves of a tree that are permanent, (and that have not a projecting nerve along the middle. TA,) as those of the cypress (Ḳ) and tamarisk and samur. (TA.) Those parts of a plant that are not waraq but that have the place of waraq. (AḤn, Ḳ:) or any waraq that have not middle; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as those of the Oavol and sarow and OaroTaI and TarofaMC; (Ṣ:) as also hud-aAbN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) both of which are coll gen. ns., of which the ns. un. are with p {hadabapN and hud-aAbapN}: pl. OahodaAbN, (Ḳ,) which is a regular pl. of hadabN (TA;) and hud-aAbN↓: (Ḳ, accord. to the TA: but in a MṢ. copy, hud-aAbapN; and in the CK, had-aAbapN,) but in the M, hud-aAbN is said to be a noun signifying the hudob of a garment, &c., and the hadab of the OaroTaI (TA) Az says, that EabalN is precisely the same as hadabN (TA.)
hud-aAbN↓ is also said to signify Inclining branches, or twigs. (TA.)
Also, hud-aAbu↓ Aln-axoli Palm branches; syn. saEafuhu. (Ṣ)
OahodaAbN is said to be used by Aboo-Dhu-eyb, in the phrase sabiTu AlAhdAb, as signifying The shoulder-blades. but ISd, who mentions this, denies its correctness. (TA.)

entry.sense: hadibN A horse having a long forelock. The hdbAn [pl. of hadibN, but whether hidobaAnN or hudobaAnN is not shown,] are among those horses that are held in high estimation among the Arabs, and are distinguished as belonging to different tents, or house. (TA.)

Alhudbu † The lion. (Ḳ.) But accord. to Lth, Oahodabu↓, as an epithet applied to felt and the like, signifies † Having long nap, or villous substance (TA,) and as an epithet applied to a lion, accord. to the A, it signifies ‡ Having long shag [or shaggy hair]: (TA:) whence it is seen that the correct word [applied to the lion] is Oahodabu, [q. v.] and hadibN. (TA.)
hudubN and hudubapN: see hudobN.

hom.sense: hudobapN (TA) and hudabapN↓ (Kr, Ḳ) A certain bird: (Ḳ:) or a small dust-coloured bird, resembling the haAmap. accept in being smaller than this latter. (L.)
