El-Jáhidh says, The Arabs have not a name for that [kind of bird] which sees not in the night: it is that which is called Xbkwr [a Persian word, written Xabokuwro], more frequently than hdbp. (A.)
N, un. of hudobN, q. v.

entry.sense: hdbp [written without the syll. points: probably hudobapN;] A piece, pace, or portion. (TA.)
hudabapN: see hudobapN.
hudub-N: see hayodabN.
hud-aAbN: see hudobN and hadabN and hayodabN.

hinodabN (Ṣ, Ḳ, a word of a rare measure, TA,) and hinodabaACN↓ (Ḳ: [but it is not there said whether it be imperfectly or perfectly declinable: accord. to Ibn-Buzurj, as mentioned in the TA, it is fem., and therefore imperfectly decl.: but from the ns. un. given below, it appears to be masc., and perfectly decl.: probably, therefore, all the forms of the word ending with long or short alif may be correctly pronounced without, and with, tenween:]) and hinodab-aI↓ (ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb) and hinodibaACN and hinodibFI; (Az, Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb;) but the word which is used by most of the Arabs of the desert is the first: (Az;) IḲt only mentions the third form: (Mṣb:) also hanodabaApN↓, (Ṣ;) or [hndbI and hndbAC are coll. gen. ns., and] hinadabaApN is a n. un., (AḤn, Ḳ,) as also hndbACp: (AḤn, TA:) A certain leguminous plant, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) of the description termed OaHoraAr; [i. e., of a slender and soft nature, and eaten crude;] (TA;) [lichorium, intybus and endivia; wild and garden-succory, and endive: also called in the present day Xkuwryap] a plant of middling temperament, (muEotadilapN,) useful for the stomach and the liver and the spleen, when eaten: and for the sting of a scorpion, when applied externally, with its roots: he who cooks it errs more than he who washes it [and so uses it]. (Ḳ.) F mentions the names of this plant in aro. hndb, as though the n were a radical letter, which noone asserts it to be: J [and others], in art. hdb. (TA.)
hinodabFI, hinodibFI, hinodibaACN and hinodabaApN: see hinodabN.
hayodabN: see hudobN.
[Its pl., hayaAdibu, is also applied to Filaments, capillaments, or fringe-like appertenances, of a flower.]

hayodabN; ‡ A cloud or clouds, hanging down, (Ḳ,) approaching [the earth], like the hudob [or unwoven end or extremity,] of a (qaTiyfap: TA:) or the hydb of a cloud is its cayol [or skirt]. (Ḳ:) or what hangs down, of it, like the unwoven and, or extremity, of a garment. (maA tahac-aba minohu.) when it is about to rain, resembling strings (Ṣ)
hayodabN ‡ A pendulous (or flabby. TA,) pubes of a woman: (Ḳ:) likened to the hydb of a cloud (TA.)

hayodabN ‡ Tears flowing in a continued succession. (Ḳ.) On the authority of Lth, who cites the following verse:
bidamoEK ciI HaraAraAtK
EalaI Alxad-ayoni ciI hayodabo
[With hot tears upon the cheeks, flowing in a continued succession]. But it is said in the L, I have not heard hydb used as an epithet applied to rain falling continuously, aor. as an epithet applied to tears; and the verse which Lth adduces as an authority is forged. (TA.)

hayodabN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hudub-N↓ and hud-aAbN↓ (Ḳ) Impotent in speech or actions; syn. EayiI-N; (in one copy of the Ḳ gabiI-N, or unintelligent; TA;) and heavy, or dull: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or hydb signifies impotent in speech or actions; dull of speech and understanding; heavy: and hard, or churlish; heavy, or dull; having much hair: (Az:) or, as some say, one who has upon him dangling strings, or the like, hanging from the suspensory of a sword, or other thing, and resembling the hydb of a cloud: or, as some say, this word signifies stupid; foolish; of little sense: and hdb-↓, weak. (TA.)
hayodabaI A kind of pace of a horse, in which exertion, or energy, is employed; a certain hard pace of a horse. (Ḳ.) See also hayocabaI.
rajulN hayodabiI-u AlkalaAmi † A man of much speech, or talk; of many words. (Ḳ.) App. from the hayodab of a cloud. (TA.)

Oahodabu A man having long, or large, eyelashes. (Ḳ.) Lth explains it by the words Tawiylu OaXofaAri AlEayoni kaviyruhaA; [and J in a similar manner;] but Az disapproves of this expression, because AXfAr AlEyn signifies “the edges of the eyelids,” whence the eyelashes grow: (TA:) Oahodabu AlOaXofaAri, and hadibu↓ AlAXfAr, [the same;] having long eyelashes. (TA.) EayonN hadobaACu An eye having long lashes. (TA.)
XajarapN hadobaACu A tree having long and pendulous branches. (Ḳ.)
OucunN hadobaACu ‡ A pendulous, flabby, ear. (TA, from a trad.)
liHoyapN hadobaACu ‡ A lank, not crisp, beard: and so EuvonuwnN hadibN↓. (TA.)
nasorN Oahodabu ‡ A vulture having long feathers which reach to the ground. (TA.) See hadibN.
muhad-abN Having an unwoven end, or extremity; syn. cuw hud-aAbK: occurring as an epithet applied to the kind of stuff called dimaqosN. (TA.)
hudabidN and hudaAbidN↓ Very thick milk: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) sour and thick milk. (L.) The former word is a contraction of the latter. (Ṣ.)

Also the former, Smallness of the eyes, and weakness of the sight; or nyctalopia, or the seeing better by night than in the day, and in a cloudy day than in a clear one; syn. xafaXN: (L, Ḳ:) or (so in the L, in the Ḳ, and) weakness of the eye, (Ḳ,) or, of the sight: (L:) or (so in the L; in the Ḳ, and) [that weakness of the sight which is termed] EaXFA, [which is a badness of sight by night and day; or the quality of seeing by day but not by night,] (El-Mufaddal, L, Ḳ,) also termed XabokarapN: (El-Mufaddal, L:) or weakness of the sight, with a flowing of the tears at most times; syn. EamaXN: (Ṣ, L:) or this is a mistake: (Ḳ:) or any injurious affection of the eye. (M, F.)
Also, Weak-sighted: (L, Ḳ:) an epithet applied to a man. (L.)
Also, Black gum (L, Ḳ) which flows from trees. (L.)
hudaAbidN: see hudabidN.

1. hadaja, aor. _i {yahodiju}, inf. n. hadajaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hudaAjN (Ḳ) and hadojN, (TA,) ‡ He walked gently, in a weak manner: (TA:) or he walked in the manner of an old man; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and the like: (TA:) or he (an old man) walked with short steps: or walked hastily, without desiring to do so: (TA:) or he walked with unintermitting steps: (Aṣ:) or he walked in a shaking manner, by reason of old age. (IAạr.)
hadaja, (Ṣ,) aor. _i {yahodiju}, inf. n. hadajaAnN; and Asthdj↓; (TA;) He (an ostrich) walked, or went, (or ran, TA,) in a tremulous manner. (Ṣ, TA.)
hadajati Alqidoru ‡ The cooking-pot boiled vehemently. (TA.)

hadajato, (Ṣ,) inf. n. hadajN, (L,) She (a camel) yearned towards her young one; Han-ato EalaI waladihaA; (Ṣ, L;) as also thd-jt↓; (L;) [and, app., uttered the cry produced by yearning towards her young one: see below:] or the latter signifies she was affectionate to her young one. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, inf. n. as above, † It (the wind) made a sound; syn. Han-ato and Saw-atato; from hdjt Aln-Aqp. (L.)
2. hd-jt ‡ She (a camel) became high and big in the hump, so that it bore a resemblance to a hawodaj. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5. thd-j It (the voice, or a sound) became much intercepted, or interrupted, (taqaT-aEa) with a tremulous manner. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See 1.
thd-jwA Ealayohi They made apparent, or manifest, his gracious actions, or qualities, or his favours, or kindnesses. (TA.)

entry.sense: hadajapN, (a subst., L,) The yearning, or the cry produced by yearning towards her young one, of a camel; Haniynu Aln-aAqapi: (Ḳ:) or the yearning of a she-camel towards her young one; Haniynu Aln-aAqupi EalaI waladihaA. (Ṣ, L.)
hadajodajN: see had-aAjN.
haduwjN: see mihodaAjN.
qidorN haduwjN ‡ A cookingpot that boils vehemently: (TA:) or, quickly. (Ḳ.)
had-aAjN and hadajodajN↓ One who walks in the manner termed hadajaAnN: see 1. (Ḳ.)
An ostrich that so walks, or runs. (Ṣ, TA.) One says ZaliymN had-aAjN, and naEaAmN had-aAjN and hawaAdiju: (TA:) [the last is pl. of haAdijapN↓, fem. act. part. n. of hadaja].

Also, ↓the latter, An ostrich: so called because it so walks, or runs: (TA:) [and so haAdijapN↓, pl. hawaAdiju, as in the following example.] naZarotu UilaI AlhawaAdiji EalaI AlhawaAdiji [I looked at the women's camel-litters upon the camels like ostriches]. (A.)
haAdijapN: see had-aAjN.

hawodajN [A kind of camel-vehicle for women;] the vehicle of the Arab women of the desert: (JK:) a kind of vehicle for women, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) having a dome-like top (muqab-abN); and one not having such a top: (Ṣ:) or [a camel-vehicle for women] made with staves, over which are put pieces of wood, and covered with a dome-like top: (M:) or a camel-vehicle (maHomil) having a dome-like top (qub-ap), covered with pieces of cloth, in which women ride: (Et-Towsheeh:) pl. hawaAdiju. (TA.) [See maHomilN and maHaArapN.]
mihodaAjN A she-camel that yearns, or that utters the cry produced by yearning towards her young one: (Ḳ:) or that yearns towards her young one: (Ṣ, L:) as also haduwjN↓. (TA.)
Also, † A wind that has a sound; lahaA HaniynN: (Ṣ, L:) from Han-ati Aln-aAqapu. (L.)
musotahodajN Haste. (Ḳ.)
musotahodijN Hasty. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. hadara, aor. _i {yahodiru} (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yahoduru}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. hadorN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and hadarN, (Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) It (a man's blood, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, or another thing, Ḳ) went for nothing; [meaning, in the case of blood, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulet; as shown below, voce hadarN;] it was, or became, of no account, null, or void; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Ahdr↓. (Mṣb.)

hadarahu, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yahoduru}, (Mṣb,) He (a man, Mṣb, Ḳ, or the Sultán, Ṣ, A,) made it (a man's blood) to go for nothing; [meaning, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct;] he made it to be of no account; (A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Ahdrhu↓; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) which means he made it (a man's blood) allowable to be taken, or shed. (Ṣ, TA.) Thus these two verbs are trans. as well as intrans. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad, mani QT-alaEa fiI daArK bigayori UiconK faqado hudirato Eayonuhu [Whoso looketh into a house without permission, his eye shall be allowed to be put out; or] the putting out of his eye shall go for nothing, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct. (TA.) One says also, hadarotaniI biUisoqaATi AlHad-i Ean-iI [Thou hast made me (meaning my offence) to pass unnoticed, or host taken no account of me, by annulling in respect of me the prescribed castigation]. (Ḳ, art. bhrj.)
And El-ʼAjjáj says,
wahadara Aljad-a mina Aln-aAsi Alhacaro
which El-Báhilee explains as meaning, And the worthless people have made good fortune to become of no account. (TA.)

hacara, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yahodiru} (Ḳ) [and app. _u also], inf. n. hadiyrN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hadorN (Ḳ) and huduwrN, (TA,) said of a camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that is advanced in age, (Ṣ, in art. nqD,) [He brayed; i. e.,] he reiterated his voice in his Hanojarap [or windpipe, or the head of his windpipe]: (Ṣ:) or he uttered his voice, not in a XiqoXiqap [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) and hd-r↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tahodiyrN, (Ṣ,) signifies the same: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) Z mentions also tahodaArN as an inf. n. of hadara said of a stallion, [meaning a stallioncamel.] (TA.)

Hence the saying, (TA,) huwa yahodiru fiI manoTiqihi, and fiI xuTobatihi, ‡ [He is sonorous and fluent in his speech, and in his oration:] and hadarato XiqoXiqatuhu ‡ [His utterance was sonorous and fluent.] (A, TA.)
hadara is also said of a calf, [signifying, † He lowed] (TA, art. kt, from the Nh.)
Also, of a lion, [signifying, † He roared.] (Ṣ, TA, voce qaboqaba.)

Also hadara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yahodiru} (Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yahoduru}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. hadiyrN (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, Mṣb, TA) and hadorN and tahodaArN, (Ḳ,) said of a pigeon ‡ It uttered a cry: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or cooed, syn. qaroqara, (A,) or sajaEa, (Mṣb,) and reiterated its voice, or cry, in its Hanojarap [or windpipe, or the head of its windpipe]: (A:) its cry being apparently likened to the hadiyr of the camel: and hadala signifies the same. (TA.)
Also hadara said of a boy, (Aṣ.) when he desires to speak, being young, or little, (Abu-s-Semeyda',) † He uttered a sound, or cry; as also hadala. (Aṣ, TA.)
It is also said of thunder; inf. n. hadiyrN; signifying ‡ It made a [loud, or rumbling,] sound, or noise, (A.)

You say also, of XaraAb [or wine], hacara, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yahodiru}, inf. n. hadorN and tahodaArN, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning, † It fermented; syn. galaI. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And hadarato jar-apN Aln-abiyci, (TA,) aor. _i {yahodiru}, (A, TA,) inf. n. hadiyrN and tahodaArN, (TA,) ‡ [The jar of nbyc fermented.] El-Akhtal says, describing wine,
kum-ato valaAvapa OaHowaAlK biTiynatihaA
Hat-aI UicaA Sar-aHato mino biEodi tahodaAri
[It was stopped three years with its lump of clay, until, when it became free from froth, after fermenting]. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. hd-r, said of a camel: see 1.

hom.sense: 4. Ahdr: see hadara.
Ahdrhu: see hadarahu.
hadorN: see hadarN:
and see also haAdirN.

entry.sense: hidorN: see haAdirN.

hadorN, a subst. from hadara in the first of the senses explained above. (Mṣb.) You say, cahaba damuhu hadarFA, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) and hadorFA, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) His blood went for nothing, or as a thing of no account, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) unretaliated, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and uncompensated by a mulct. (Ṣ, TA.)

Also, applied to blood, &c., A thing that goes for nothing; [meaning, in the case of blood, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct;] what is of no account, ineffectual, null, or void; (A, Ḳ;) [as also jubaArN.] You say, dimaAWuhumo hadarN bayonahumo Their blood (lit, bloods) is made to go for nothing, or to be of no account, among them; (Ḳ,* TA:) is allowed to be taken, or shed. (TA.)
See also haAdirN.
hudarapN: see haAdirN, in two places.
hidarapN: see haAdirN.
jar-apN haduwrN ‡ [A jar of wine or nabiyc fermenting much]. (TA.)
faHolN had-aArN [A stallion- camel that brays much]. (TA.) See also haAdirN.
raEodN had-aArN ‡ [Loud, or rumbling, thunder]. (A.)

hom.sense: haAdirN, applied to a man, ‡ Low; ignoble; mean; of no account; worthless; (Ḳ;) as also hadorN↓, (Kr, Ḳ,) and hudarapN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which last is also applied to a woman: (Ḳ, TA: [in the former of which it seems to be implied that hadarapN and hidarapN↓ are also applied, each, to a man and to a woman; but it appears from what is said in the TA that this is not the case:]) pl. hadarapN and hudarapN and hidarapN; the first of which is the most agreeable with analogy, like kafarapN, pl. of kaAfirN; the second being of a measure exclusively belonging to words which are unsound [in the last radical letter], as in the instances of guzaApN and quDaApN, [originally guzawapN and quDayapN, pls. of gaAzK and qaADK,] unless, indeed, it be a quasi-pl. n.; and some disapprove it, finding fault with IAạr who relates it: the third, moreover, is not a pl. of a form, [regularly] belonging to a sing. of the measure faAEilN, whether sound or unsound: (ISd, TA:) [or, accord. to Sb, it is a quasi-pl. n.:] or it is pl. of hidorN↓. (TA,) which signifies a heavy man, (Ḳ, TA,) in whom is no good; analogous with qiradapN, pl. of qirodN. (TA:) and hadarN↓ [a quasi-pl. n. of haAdirN, like as xadamN is of xaAdimN,] signifies low, ignoble, or mean, people, in whom is no good. (TA.) You say, humo hadarapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and hidarapN, (IAạr, TṢ, Ḳ,) and hudarapN, (IAạr, ISd, Ḳ,) ‡ They are low, ignoble, or mean, people; of no account, or worthless. (IAạr, Ṣ, A,* Ḳ, &c.)

[A braying camel: fem. with p {haAdirapN} pl. of the latter, hawaAdiru. You say,] UibilN hawaAdirN [Braying camels;] camels reiterating their voices in their HanaAjir. (Ṣ.) See also muhad-irN, and mubaHovirN, and had-aArN.
[Hence the saying,] fulaAnN fuHolN haAdirN ‡ [app. Such a one is a vigorous orator of sonorous and fluent speech]. (A.)

entry.sense: kaQlomuhad-iri fiI AlEun-api [Like the brayer in the enclosure of wood, or canes, or trees]: a proverb: applied to a man who raises a cry and clamour which is followed by nothing, (Ṣ, A,*) or who raises a cry and clamour and does not make his saying or action to have effect: (A, Ḳ) like the camel that is confined in the enclosure of wood or canes or trees, prevented from covering, and brays. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

1. hac-, aor. _u {yahocucu}, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. hac-N (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and hacacN (L, Ḳ) and hucaAcN, (Ḳ, TA,) or hacaAcN, (CK, [which latter is the correct reading, (see hacaAcayoka,) and, accord. to the JK, is a quasi-inf. n.],) He cut quickly, or cut off quickly; as also Ahtc-↓: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or he cut anything. (Ḳ)
hac-ahu biAls-ayofi, inf. n. hac-N, He cut him, or it, in pieces with the sword. (L,)

hac-a.. aor. _u {yahocucu}. (Ṣ, L.) inf. n. had-N (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and hacacN (L, Ḳ) and hucaAcN, (Ḳ, TA,) or hacaAcN; (CK [see above];) and Ahtc-↓, (Ḳ:) ‡ He read, or recited, quickly. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) You say, had-a qiraMCatahu, aor. _u {yahocucu} inf. n. hac-N, ‡ He performed his reading, or recitation, quickly. (Mṣb.) And huwa yahuc-u AlquroMna ‡ He reads, or recites, the Ḳur-án rapidly and uninterruptedly: (Ṣ, A, L:) and in like manner, AlHadiyva the narrative; (Ṣ, L;) and AlX-iEora the poetry. (L.)
8: see 1.
hac-N, or hic-N: see hacuwcN.

hacuwcN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and hac-aAcN (Ḳ) and hac-N↓, (L, CK,) or hic-N↓, (as in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA,) and hacohaAcN↓ and hucaAhicN, (L, Ḳ [the last in the CK hacaAhicN],) Sharp; quickly cutting: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) the first, which is masc. and fem., and the second, applied to a knife; (Ṣ * L;) and the last two, to a sword. (L.)

hacaAcayoka, (as Aṣ says, Ṣ) is said to people when you desire them to refrain, or forbear, or abstain, from a thing; as also hajaAjayoka; supposing [it to be addressed to] two [persons]; (Ṣ, L;) [but it is addressed to one;] meaning Refrain thou! or forbear thou! or abstain thou! (TA, art. hj.) ʼAbd-Beni-l-Has-hás says,
UicaA Xuq-a burodN Xuq-a biQlobrdi mivoluhu
hacaAcayoka Hat-aI layos liloburodi laAbisu
[When a burd (a kind of garment) is rent, the like thereof is rent with the burd - refrain thou - so that there is no wearer of the burd, it having been rent so as to fall off: but it seems more proper to render it here, with rending after rending, which is nearly the original signification, as will be presently shown; and, thus rendered, it does not interrupt the sentence]: the women assert that, when, in the act of concubitus, [app., for the first time,] somewhat of the garment of the man is rent, love continues between the pair; but otherwise, that they desert each other. (Ṣ, L. [This verse is related with several variations: see another reading of it voce dawaAlayoka, in art. dwl.])

DarobFA hacaAcayoka With a beating, or striking, with cutting after cutting; (L, Ḳ;) hac-FA↓ baEoda hac-K, (L,) i. e., qaToEFA baEoda qaToEK: (L, Ḳ:) or with a beating, or striking, successively; uninterruptedly; walaMCF tibaAEFA. (JK.)

In the saying of the poet,
fabaAkara maxotuwmFA Ealayohi sayaAEuhu
hacaAcayoka Hat-aI Oanofaca Ald-an-a OajomaEaA
[in which, for Anfc, in the L and TA, I substitute Anfc,] AHn says, that it signifies hac-F baEoda hac-K, i. e., XurobFA baEoda XurobK; the poet meaning And he applied himself early to a jar full of wine, [with its mud-plaster sealed upon it, with drinking after drinking, until he exhausted all that was in the jar,] and emptied it. (L.)
qarabN hacohaAcN † A long and difficult night journey to water: (L, Ḳ:) or quick. (JK, Ḳ.)
See hcwc.
hac-aAcN: see hacuwcN.
Also, † A camel that outstrips others. (Ḳ.)
1. hacaOa, aor. _a {yahocaOu}, inf. n. hacoCN, He cut a thing (Aṣ. Ṣ, Ḳ) [quickly], with a sword, &c. (TA.) It signifies a quicker act than does hac-a. (Ḳ.)
hacaOa He destroyed the enemy. (Ḳ, TA.)
hacaOhu bilisaAnihi, (Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. hacoCN, (TA,) He hurt, or offended, [or cut,] him with his tongue; (TA;) made him to hear what he disliked. (Ḳ.)
hacaOati AlUibilu The camels fell down, [and, app., died,] one after another: syn. tasaAqaTato. (Ḳ.)
haciYa mina Albarodi, [aor. _?,] He perished of cold. (Ḳ.)
hacaOa AlkalaAma He was loquacious, with error. (TA.)
5. thc-O It (a wound, or an ulcer.) became putrid, or rotten, and dissundered, or ragged. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hacoOapN i. q. misoHaApN [q. v., in arts. sHI and sHw.] (Ḳ.)
hac-aON and hac-aMCN↓ A sharp sword, (TA [but the orthography is not quite clear].) [See also art. hcI.]
hac-aMCN: see hac-aON.
hecaA: see art. cA.

hom.sense: 1. hacabahu, aor. _i {yahocibu}, inf. n. hacobN, He cut it; or cut it off: (A, Ḳ:) like hadabahu. (TA.)
hacabahu, aor. _i {yahocibu}, inf. n. hacobN; (Ḳ;) and hc-bh↓, inf. n. tahociybN; (Ṣ;) He cleansed it; purified it; cleared it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
haciba, aor. _a {yahocabu}, inf. n. hacabN, It was pure, clear. (Ḳ: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.)
maA fiI mawad-atihi hacbN There is no purity in his love. (TA.)

hacabahu, aor. _i {yahocibu}, inf. n. hacobN; and hc-bh↓, (inf. n. tahocybN, TA); He put it into a right, or proper, state; put it to rights; trimmed, adjusted, repaired, mended, amended, reformed, or improved, it. (Ḳ.)
hacaba Aln-axolapa He trimmed the palm-tree by clearing it of the fibrous substance called liyf. (Ḳ.)

MF says, on the authority of the etymologists, that the original signification of tahociybN↓ and hacobN is The clearing, or trimming, of trees, by cutting off the extremities of the branches, in order that they may increase in growth and beauty; that they were then used to signify the cleansing, or purifying, of anything; and putting it into a right, or proper, state; trimming it; or adjusting it; and clearing it of any dirty or filthy things, or the like, mixed with it; so that these became their proper meanings by general acceptation: and that they were then used to signify the trimming and embellishing of verse, and clearing it of whatever might vitiate it in the opinion of the chaste in language, and the philologists: but the truth is what is said in the L; that the original signification of thcyb is the clearing the colocynth of its pulp, and preparing its seeds so that they may lose their bitterness, and become sweet. (TA.)
hacaba, (aor. _i {yahocibu}, inf. n. hacobN, TA,) It (a thing) flowed. (Ḳ.)

hacaba, (aor. _i {yahocibu} TA,) inf. n. hacobN and hacaAbapN; (Ḳ;) and Ahcb↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UihocaAbN; (Ṣ;) and hc-b↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tahociyb; (Ṣ;) and haAcaba↓; (Ḳ;) He (a man, &c., Ḳ, as a horse in his running, and a bird in his flying, TA,) was quick, or swift, (Ḳ,) in his pace or course: (TA:) he was quick in flying, in running, and in speech. (Ṣ.)
hacaba He ran vehemently. (Aṣ.)
yhcb Alr-ukuwEa [app. yuhac-ibu yuhocibu] He makes the inclinations of his head and body [in prayer] in quick succession. (TA, from a trad.)
See also art. hbc.
hacaba Alqawomu The people were very noisy, or clamourous, (Ḳ,) and loquacious. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
hc-b, inf. n. tahociybN, He trimmed an arrow; or shaped it with nicety, by the second operation: the first operation is called taXociybN. (AḤn.)

hac-aba EanohaA i. q. far-aqa, accord. to Es-Sukkaree, who cites the following verse of one of the Hudhalees: (namely Aboo-Khirásh, L, art. Trd:)
fahac-aba EanohaA maA yaliI AlbaTona waQnotaHaI
Tariydapa matonK bayona EajobK wakaAhili [app., He removed from her what was next the belly, and directed himself to a line of the back, between the rump-bone and withers]. (TA.)
3: see 1.
4. Ahcbt Als-aHaAbapu The cloud poured forth its water quickly. (Ḳ.) See 1.

5. thc-b [It became nicely, neatly, or properly, trimmed]: said of a thing from which one has cut off whatever required to be cut off, so that it has become free from everything unseemly. (A, TA, art. Hcf.)
tahad-abotu EalaI yadika [I was, or have been, amended, or improved, by thy agency, or means]. (A, TA, art. vqf.)
HamiymN hacibN, after the manner of a rel. n., A rain following vehement heat, that pours down quickly: see 4: syn. cuw UihocaAbK. (TA.)

hayocabaI A kind of pace of a horse; (Ṣ;) like hayodabaI: (Ḳ:) a subst. from hacaba “he was quick, or swift, in his pace.” (TA.) The former is also mentioned by Az, in the T; IDrd only mentions the latter word. (TA.)
A running with a leaning on one side. Ex. maXaI AlhayocabaI [He went leaning on one side]. (IAmb.) But for this some read mXI AlhawobacaI, which is equivalent to hycbI. (TA.)
muhac-abN ‡ A man of purified natural dispositions, or manners, or morals; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a man of integrity; free from vices, or faults. (L.)
muhac-ibN Quick, or swift, [in pace, &c.]. (TA.)
Almuhac-ibu is also a name of The Devil; who is also called Almucohibu, meaning “he who embellishes, or gives a goodly appearance to, acts of disobedience [to God].” (Fr.)
UibilN mahaAciybu Quick, or swift, camels. (Ḳ.)
1. hacira kalaAmuhu, aor. _a {yahocaru}, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. hacarN, (TA,) His speech, or talk, was much, or abundant, and erroneous and false or vain or frivolous. (A, Ḳ.)

hacara, aor. _u {yahocuru} and _i {yahociru}, He talked much; babbled. was loquacious, or garrulous: (JK:) [or he talked irrationally:] or hacara fiI manoTiqihi. aor. _u {yahocuru} and _i {yahociru}. inf. n. hacorN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tahocaArN, (Ḳ,) which latter has an intensive signification, (TA,) he confounded in his speech, and talked what was not fit or meet or proper: (Mṣb:) or he talked much and badly: or erroneously: (Ḳ:) or he talked nonsense; he talked irrationally, foolishly, or deliriously: (Ṣ;) as also Ahcr↓: (Ḳ:) and Ahcr↓ fiI kalaAmihi he talked much; babbled; was loquacious, or garrulous. (Ṣ, TA.)
4: see 1, in two places.

laA nazorN walaA hacorN Not little nor much: (TA:) or not scanty, so as to indicate impotence, nor much and corrupt: said of the speech of Moḥammad. (Ḳ, art. nzr.) [See hacarN, from which it is altered to assimilate it in form to nazorN.]

hacarN, a subst. from hacara fiI manoTiqihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) Much talk; babble: (JK:) or nonsense; or irrational, foolish, or delirious, talk: (Ṣ:) or confused and improper speech: (Mṣb:) or speech, or talk, that is much and bad: or erroneous: (A, Ḳ:) or that is not regarded as of any weight or worth. (TA.) See also hacorN.
hacurN: see hacirN.

hacirN, an epithet from hacara, applied to a man, [signifying, Loquacious; garrulous; babbling; a great talker; a bubbler. or nonsensical, irrational, foolish, or delirious, in his talk: or one who speaks confusedly and improperly: or who speaks, or talks, much and badly: or erroneously:] (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also, [but in an intensive sense.] hacurN↓ (Ḳ) and hucarapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hucur-pN↓ (Ḳ) and hac-aArN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hayocaArN↓ (Ḳ) and hicoriyaAnN↓ (JK, A, Ḳ) and mahocarN↓ (Ḳ) and mihocaArN↓, (JK, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [signifying, very loquacious,, &c.:] and, [but in a doubly intensive sense.] hayocaArapN↓ (JK, Ḳ) and mihocaArapN↓, (JK, A, Ḳ.) [signifying very very loquacious,, &c.:] fem. hacirapN (Ḳ) and hayocarapN↓ (TA) and mihocaArN↓ [without p]: (Ḳ:) or hicoriyaAnN↓ signifies one who talks badly, or corruptly, and much: (TA:) or light in speech and in service: (Ṣ, TA:) the pl. of mihocaArN↓ is mahaAcyru, not mihocaAruwna. (ISd, TA.)
hucarapN: see hacirN.
hucur-apN: see hacirN.
hicoriyaAnN: see hacirN; in two places.
hac-aArN see hacirN.
hayocarapN: see hacirN.
hayocArN: see hacirN.
hayocaArapN: see hacirN.
mahocirN: see hacirN.
mahocaArN: see hacirN.
mahocaArapN: see hacirN.
Q. 1. hacoraba, inf. n. hacorabapN, He talked much and quickly: (Ḳ:) a dial form of hacorama, or mispronounced for the latter word. (TA.) See also hazorb.
hucayribFI (accord to the TA, hacayorabFI, and so in Golius's Lex.,) Custom; habit Ex. hecihi hcyrbAhu This is his custom, or habit. (Ḳ.)
hucorubaAnN Light, or active, (and quick. TA,) in his speech and in his service. (Ḳ.) See also hicoriyAnN, in art. hcr.
Q. 1. hacolama, inf. n. hacolamapN, He was light, or active, and quick. (Ḳ.) But IDrd and others assert it to be a word mispronounced for hacoram. (MF.)

hom.sense: 1. har-a, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yahir-u, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. hariyrN, (Ṣ, A, &c.,) said of a dog, [He snarled, or howled, or whined;] he uttered a cry less vehement than barking (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) by reason of his little patience of cold; (Ṣ, Ḳ) Uilayohi at him. (Ḳ.) or barked and grinned, displaying his fangs. (L, TA.) It is said in a trad, Uin-a Alkaloba yahir-u mino waraMCi Oaholihi Verily the dog [snarls, or] harks and grins, displaying his fangs, behind his master: meaning, that courage is a quality implanted by nature in a man, so that he engages in wars naturally, and from care to defend what should be inviolable, not reckoning upon a reward, like as the dog naturally barks and grins, displaying his tangs, to defend his masters. (L, TA.)

hariyrN is also applied to other sounds than the cry of the dog; as in the instance of hariyru Alr-HaI † The sound of the turning of the mill-stone. (TA.) You say also har-ati Alqawosu † The bow made a sound. (AḤn, Ḳ.) And the looking of courageous men, one at another, is likened to hariyr. (ISd, Mṣb.)
har-a fiI wajohi Als-aAYili ‡ He grinned in the face of the beggar, showing his teeth, and looking sternly, austerely, or morosely (A, TA.)

[Hence, perhaps,] har-ahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yahur-u and yahir-a, (Ḳ,) [the latter irreg., like har-ahu as aor. of the trans. v. ram-a,] inf. n. har-N (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hariyrN. (Ḳ,) ‡ He disliked, disapproved of or hated, him or it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, har-ahu Aln-aAsu ‡ The people disliked,, &c., his vicinity. (A.) And har-a AlkaAsa. and AlHaroba, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. hariyrN. (Ṣ.) ‡ He disliked., &c., the cup of wine, and war. (Ṣ, A.)

har-ahu Albaroda, (Ḳ,) aor. yahur-uhu, inf. n. har-N, (TA,) The cold made him (a dog) [to snarl, or hand, or whine; or] to cry [in the manner described above]; as also Oahar-ahu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UihoraArN. (TA.) It is said in a proverb, (TA,) Xar-N Oahr-a↓ caA naAbK [It is, or was, an evil thing that made the fanged animal to snarl,, &c.]: alluding to the appearance of the signs and symptoms of evil: the sayer thereof, hearing the cry (hariyr) of a dog, feared the assault of evil, and therefore said this to denote the magnitude of the case in his mind: meaning, nought but an evil thing made the fanged animal to cry: and for this reason, the use of an indeterminate word as an inchoative is well. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. haAr-ah i. q. har-a fI wajohh, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., ‡ He grinned in his face, showing his teeth, and looking sternly, austerely, or morosely. (A) like a dog. (TA.)
4: see 1, last signification, in two places.

hom.sense: hir-N A male cat; syn. sin-aworN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) which latter is uncommon in the language of the Arabs (IAmb, in Mṣb, art. snr;) fem. hir-apN: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or hir-N is applied to the male and the female; and the latter is sometimes called hrapN (IAmb, Mṣb:) the pl. of hr-N is hirrpN: and that of hir-apN is hirarN: and the dim. of hir-apN is hurayorapN. (Mṣb.)

Also, a subst. from har-ahu meaning “he disliked, disapproved of, or hated, him or it.” (Ṣ) It is said in a proverb, (Ṣ,) yaEorifu hir-FA mino br-K (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) meaning He knows not him who dislikes or hates him from him who behaves towards him with goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for his circumstances. (Ṣ, TA.) this is the best explanation of it: (TA:) or the action of him who grins in his face, showing his teeth, and looking steraly, austerely, or morosely, from the action of him who holds loving communion with him. (A:) or the calling of sheep or goats, (Ṣ,) or the calling of them to water. (Ḳ.) from the driving of them: (Ṣ:) or the calling of sheep or goats to provender from the calling of them to water: (IAạr) or the driving of sheep or goats (Yoo, Ḳ) from the calling of them. (Yoo, TA.) It has been explained [more fully] in art. br. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: har-aArN: see haAr-N.

haAr-N A dog [that snarls, or howls, or whines, by reason of his little patience of cold: or] that barks and grins, displaying his fangs: and har-aArN↓ signifies the same [but in an intensive manner; that snarls,, &c., much:] or the latter signifies a dog that grins [much], displaying his fangs: or that barks much: or that barks [much] and grins, displaying his fangs. It is said in a trad., laA OaEoqilu Alkaloba Alhar-aAra↓ [properly signifying, I will not pay a fine for killing the dog that barks much, is expl. as] meaning, I will not impose anything [as a fine] for the killing of a dog that barks much; because such a dog annoys by his barking. (TA, [see art. Eql.])
EaAda lahaA AlmaTiI-u haAr-FA The ridingcamels returned to her, or it, one grinning (yahir-u) in the face of another, showing its teeth, in consequence of fatigue. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. haraOahu Albarodu The cold destroyed him, or, perhaps, debilitated him; i. e., a beast; lit., broke him: syn. ksrh. (TA.) [See also hazaOa.]
hariYa, like EuniIa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] (incorrectly written in the Ṣ hariYa, Ḳ,) It (a camel or sheep, &c., or a man.) perished of cold, or heat. (Ks, Ḳ.)
haraOahu Albarodu, inf. n. haroCN (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and haraMCapN; (Ḳ;) and AhrOhu↓; (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) The cold affected him so severely as nearly to kill him: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or so severely as to kill him. (Ḳ.)
haraOati Alr-iyHu The wind was, or became, intensely cold. (Ḳ.)
haraOa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. haroCN; (TA:) and hr-O↓; (Ḳ;) and AhrO↓, (Fr, Ḳ,) inf. n. UihoraMCN; (TA;) He cooked flesh-meat thoroughly: (Ḳ:) or so that it fell off from the bone. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hariYa, aor. _a {yahoraOu}, inf. n. haroCN and huroCN and huruwoCN; (Ḳ;) and thr-O↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) It (flesh-meat) was thoroughly cooked: (Ḳ:) or was cooked so as to fall off from the bone. (Ṣ,* TA.)

haraOa fiI manoTiqihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yahoraOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. haroCN, (TA,) He was loquacious: or he was loquacious, with incorrectness; (TA;) as also haraOa AlkalaAma: (ISk, Ṣ:) or he was very foul in his speech: or was very incorrect, or faulty, therein: (Ḳ:) or, simply, he was foul, (Ṣ,) or incorrect, or faulty, (TA,) in his speech: (Ṣ, TA:) also AhrO↓ AlkalaAma he multiplied his words but spake not to the point, or correctly. (Ḳ.)
Uin-a manoTiqaha yahoraOu, inf. n. haroCN, [Verily his speech is prolix: or is vitious, and disorderly]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

hom.sense: 4: see 1.
AhrO fiI Alr-awaAHi He entered upon the cool time of the evening: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or properly said only of the evening of the hot season. (Ḳ.) [See also AhzO.]
OahoriYu Eanoka mina AlZ-ahiyrapi Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool. (TA, in this art.; and IAạr, in TA, art. fyH.)
AhrO He slew a person. (Ḳ.)
See 1, last sentence but one.
5. thr-O He (a beast) was destroyed, or, perhaps, debilitated, by the cold; lit., was broken: syn. tks-r. (TA.)
See 1.

entry.sense: hariYN (so in the TA: in one copy of the Ṣ, hariIN: in another, hariI-N:) and muhar-aON↓ (TA) Meat thoroughly cooked: (TA:) or cooked so as to fall off from the bone. (Ṣ,* TA.)
huraON: see huraMCN.
huraMCN, or manoTiqN huraMCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Loquacity: or vitious, disorderly, speech: (Ḳ:) or loquacity with incorrectness. (Ṣ.)
huraMCN, (Ḳ,) fem. with p {huraMCapN}, pl. with wn; (TA;) and huraON↓; (Ḳ;) A great talker of nonsense. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: hiraMCN A young shoot of a palm-tree, (AḤn, Ḳ,) when first plucked from the mother-tree. (Aṣ.)
AlhiraMCu A certain devil whose office it is to suggest foul dreams. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: qir-apN lahaA hariyoYapN Cold that occasions injury and death to men and to cattle, &c. (El-Fezáree, ISk, Ṣ.)
Also, hariyoYapN The time in which cold thus affects them. (TA.)
mahoruwoCN, from huriYa, pl. with wn, [in the CK, for mahoruwWuwna is put mahoraWuna,] Perishing of cold, or heat. (Ks, Ḳ.)
Explained by AḤn [in his book on plants] by the words Oal-aciI qado OanoDajahu Albarodu [meaning, What is nipped, shrunk, shrivelled, or blasted, by the cold: see art. nDj]. (TA.)
muhar-aON: see hariYN.

hom.sense: 1. haraba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yahorubu}; not _a, as some have imagined on account of the measure of the first of the following inf. ns., imagining thence also that the pret. is hariba; nor _a with the pret. haraba, as some have supposed because of the guttural letter; for a guttural letter, when it is the first, is not reckoned as having any influence on the form of the aor.; nor _i, as some have thought; (TA;) inf. n. harabN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mahorabN and harabaAnN; (Ḳ;) He (a man, or any animal, TA) fled; ran away. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Uilayoka minoka Almahorabu [To Thee I flee for refuge from Thee; i. e., from thy punishment: addressed to God]. (TA.)
haraba mina Alwatadi niSofuhu Half of the wooden pin, peg, or stake, disappeared [in the ground]. (Ḳ.)
hariba, aor. _a {yahorabu}, He became extremely aged, old and weak, or decrepit; i. q. harima; (Ḳ;) of which it is a dial. form. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. hr-bh, inf. n. tahoriybu, He made, or caused, him to flee, or run away. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also 4.
4. Ahrbh He forced, or compelled, him to flee, or run away. (Ḳ.) See also 2.
Ahrbti Alr-iyHu The wind raised and carried away the dust, (Ḳ,) causing dust and dry herbage, &c. to accumulate on the ground. (TA.)
Ahrb He (a horse, or other animal that runs, Lḥ) strove, or exerted himself, in going away, or in flight, being frightened, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or not being frightened. (TA.) See jaACa muhoribFA.
Ahrb He went, or travelled, far into, or through, the land. (TA.) [haraba↓ fI AlOaroDi, mentioned also in the TA, seems to signify the same.]
Ahrb fiI AlOamori He immersed himself in the affair; took extraordinary pains in it. (Ḳ.) See jaACa muhoribFA.
6. thArbwA (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, art. fr,) They fled, one from another. (TḲ.)
hurobN The thin integument of fat that covers the stomach and intestines: or the fat [or caul] that is spread over the intestines: i. q. varobu AlbaToni: (Ḳ:) a word of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

maA lahu haAribN walaA qaAribN He has not [of camels, &c.] any that returns from water, nor any that comes to it; i. e., he has not anything; (Kh, Ṣ, Ḳ;) or, he has not anything, nor has he any people; an expression similar to maA lahu saEonapN walaA maEonapN: (Lḥ:) accord. to IAạr, haAribN signifies one who returns from water; and qaAribN, one who seeks, or journeys to, water: (TA:) or the meaning is no one flees from him, nor does any one approach him; i. e., he is a person of no account. (Aṣ, Ḳ.) [In the TA a trad. is quoted which confirms the former signification.] See also art. qrb.
mahorabN A place to which one flees; a place of refuge. (Mṣb.)
fulaAnN lanaA mahorabN † Such a one is a refuge to us. (TA.)
jaACa muhoribFA He came striving, or exerting himself, in the affair: (Lḥ:) or, as some say, he came fleeing and in fright. (TA.)

mihorabN A piece of wood, or wooden implement, which the sower, or ploughman, draws forward and backward [over the ground]. (Ḳ.) [A piece of the trunk of a tree, or of a thick branch, is thus drawn over the soil after sowing.]

hirobicN sing. of haraAbicapN, which signifies The servants, or ministers of the fire (Ṣ, Ḳ) of the Magians; (Ḳ;) the servants, or ministers, (qawamap, L, Ḳ, by which is meant xadam, TA,) of the fire temple of the Indians: (L, Ḳ:) or the judges of the Magians: (L:) or the great men of the Indians: or their learned men: (L, Ḳ:) a Persian word, [originally hirobido,] arabicized. (Ṣ, L.)
harobacapN A pace less quick than that termed xababN. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

hirobicaI A proud and self-conceited manner of walking, or going: (L, Ḳ;) which a (L.) a manner of waking or going like that of the haraAbicap [pl. of hirobicN]. (AʼObeyd, L.) AʼObeyd mentions it in speaking of the paces of camels. and says that it is without a parallel in form. (L.)
EadaA Aljamalu AlhirobicaI The camel ran in clining towards one side. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
1. harata XayoYFA, [aor. _i {yahoritu} and _u {yahorutu},] inf. n. harotN, He rent, or slit, a thing, to widen it. (TA.)
harata Xidoqahu, [aor. _i {yahoritu} and _u {yahorutu},] inf. n. hazotN He drew the side of his mouth towards the ear, (TA)
harita, aor. _a {yahoratu}, (inf. n. haratN, Ṣ,) He was wide, or ample, in the sides of the mouth: he had a wide mouth (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
harata Alv-awoba, (Ṣ,) aor. and _u, inf. n. harotN, (ISd, Ḳ,) He was the garment. (Az, Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ.)

hrt EiroDahu (Ṣ) aor. and _u, inf. n. harotN, (Ḳ,) He wounded his reputation; syn. TaEana fiyhi; (Ṣ:) as also harad and haraTa, (TA.) [Accord. to the Ḳ, harata seems to signify the same as TaEana absolutely: but in the TA the signification is restricted as above.]
harata All-aHoma, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor.: and _u, inf. n. harotN, (Ḳ,) [and har-atahu↓: see muhar-atN;] He cooked the flesh-meat thoroughly: (Ḳ:) cooked it so that it fel off from the bones, (Ṣ,)
2: see 1, last sentence.
Alharitu and Alharuwtu see Alhariytu.

hom.sense: hariytN Wide or ample. (Ḳ.)

Wide, or ample, in the sides of the mouth: (Ṣ:) as also Oahortu↓ AlX-idoqi, and hariytu AlXdq, and mahoruwtuhu↓: and munohrituhu↓. (TA.) A wide-mouthed horse; as also Oahoratu↓; and camel (TA) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce rasanN.]
Hay-pN hariytu AlX-idoq. and mhoruwtatuhu↓. A serpent having a wide mouth. (TA.)
OasodN Oahoratu↓ A lion wide in the sides of the mouth. (Ṣ.)
AjulN Oahoratu↓ A man having a wide mouth. (TA.)
muhoruwtu↓ Alfami Having a mouth wide in the sides. (Ṣ.)
kilaAbN muharotuhu↓ AlOaXodaAqi Dogs wide in the sides of the mouth. (Ṣ.) [See an ex., voce EacabN]
Alhariytu and Alharitu↓ and Alharuwtu↓ and Alhar-aAtu↓ (Ḳ.) and Almuhar-atu↓ (L) The lion. (Ḳ.)
Also hariytN A woman in whom the division between the vagina and the rectum has been broken through. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Sometimes employed in this sense. (Ṣ,)
hariytN A rent garment (ISd.)
hariytN A wounded reputation. (ISd)
rajulN hrytN A man who does not keep a secret, and who talks fault. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Alhar-aAtu: see Alhryitu.

hAruwtu [A certain fallen angel. the companion of maAruwtu] the name of an anger, or of a king. but the former accord. to the more common opinion: generally and most correctly held to be a foreign name (TA.)
Ouhoratu see hariytN throughout.
Oahoratu AlX-iqoXiqapi † an epithetic appellation given to a xaTiyb; pl. hurotN: (TA;) [like cuw XiqoXiqap q. v.]
mahoruwtN: see hrytN.

hom.sense: muhar-atN: see hariytN.
Flesh-meat thoroughly cooked, so that it has fallen in pieces; as also muhar-adN; or this latter [only] is the correct word. (TA, from a trad.)

entry.sense: mutahaAritN Twisting about the sides of the mouth, and drawing them often. or much towards the ears (TA, from a trad.)
mutohawitN: see hariytN.
hirovN An old, worn-out garment. (Ḳ.) [See also hawiyvN.]
1. haraja aor. _i {yahoriju}, inf. n. harojN He did, acted, or occupied himself much in a thing; (Ṣ, L;) expatiated or took a wide range, in it. (L.) This is the original signification. (Ṣ,)

haraja fiI AlHidiyvi, (aor, _i inf. n. harojN. Mṣb.) He launched into, and expatiated in. or was diffuse in discourse talk or narration: (Ḳ:) this is the signification in most frequent use: (TA:) or he made a confusion, or confounded, therein. (Ḳ, Mṣb.)
haraj. aor _i, and _u, inf. n. harojN, Multum inivit (Ṣ. L.) or [simply] inivit an cillam suam (Ḳ.)
haraja, aor. _i {yahoriju}, (inf. n. harojN, TA,) He (a horse) ran much (Ṣ. L:) or ran quickly or swiftly: (Mṣb:) or [simply] ran (Ḳ,)

haraja Aln-aAsu aor. _i {yahoriju}. (inf. n. harojN, Ṣ.) The people fell into a state of trial, or civil war or conflict and faction or discord, or discussion, (fitonap,) and confusion, or disorder, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and slaughter. (Ḳ.)

harija, aor. _a {yahoraju}, (inf. n. harajN, Ṣ,) He (a camel) became perplexed in his sight, by reason of the vehemence of heat, and his being much smeared with pitch, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and being heavily laden. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2. hr-j AlbaEiyra, inf. n. tahoriyjN, and Ahrjhu↓, inf. n. UihoraAjN; He incited, or urged, the camel to journey on (during the hottest time of the day, Ṣ) until he [the camel] became perplexed so his sight by reason of the vehemence of the beat. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hr-j biAls-aboEi, inf. n. tahoriyjN, He cried and to the lion or other beast of prey, and child him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hr-j. inf. n. tahoriyjN. It (beverage of the kind called nabiyc) affected, or took effect upon, a person. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see 2.
Oahoraja The heal reached has (a camel's) inside (L.)
6. thArjwA Iniverunt, ulii alias. (TA.)
7. Anhrj He was, or became, affected by beverage of the kind called nabiyc. (Ṣ, CK)

harojN Trial, or civil war, or conflict and faction, or discord, or dissension. (fitanopN,) and confusion. or disorder: (Ṣ:) vehement and much slaughter (TA:) in a trad. respecting the signs of the last day, conflict, and confusion, or disorder: (TA:) or slaughter; as explained by Moḥammad himself: (Ṣ:) and so, accord to Aboo-Moosa. It signifies in the language of Abyssinia (TA.) Ibn-Keys Fr-Rukeiyát said in the days of the faction of Ibn-Ez-Zubayi.
layot XiEoriI OaOaw-alu Alharoji hecaA
OamN zamaAnN mino fitonapi gayori haroji
Would that I knew whether this be the first of the slaughter predicted as a sign of the last day or whether it be a time of trial, or civil war,, &c., other than the slaughter so predicted. (Ṣ.)
har-aAjN: see mhorajN.
har-aAjapN An assembly, or a company, of men who launch into and expatriate in, or are diffuse in, discourse talk, or narration. (Ḳ.)
muhorijN A man whose camels are affected with the scab, and have therefore been smeared with pitch, and to whose insides the heat has penetrated. (TA.)
mihorajN and har-aAjN↓ A horse that runs much: (Ṣ. Ḳ:) and mihoraAjN↓ a horse that runs vehemently (TA.)
mihorAjN: see mihorjN.
Q. 1. harojaba. inf. n. harojabapN, He was quick. or swift. (IḲṭṭ)
hirojaAbN and hirjab-N Tall, or long, as an epithet of a man, &c. (Ḳ.)
hirojaAbN A tall, or longbodied, (Tawiylap) and bulky, she-camel: (Ṣ:) as also hirjaAlN: pl. haraAjiybu.
hirojaAbN Anything great, large, or bulky: so in the Moajam: or extending long, horizontally. (TA.)
naxolapN hirojaAbN A tall palm-tree. (TA.)

1. harada, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yahoridu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. harodN, (L,) He rent, or tore, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) a garment, or piece of cloth; (Ṣ, L;) as also harata: (Az, L:) he rent, or tore, to injure, or spoil, (L, Ḳ,) not to amend: (L:) he (a puller) rent, or tore, and beat, a garment, or piece of cloth: (L:) and hr-d↓ he rent, or tore, much. (L.)
harada EiroDahu, aor. _i {yahoridu}, (L,) inf. n. harodN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) He wounded his reputation. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

harada, aor. _i {yahoridu}, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. harodN, (L,) He cooked flesh-meat so that it fell off from the bones: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or cooked it much: (Aṣ, L:) or cooked it thoroughly and well: (ISd, L, Ḳ:) and hr-d↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tahoriydN, (Ṣ, L,) signifies the same, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) but with an intensiveness: (Ṣ, L:) or he put flesh-meat into the fire, and cooked it thoroughly. (AZ, L.)

harida, (L, Ḳ, TA,) or harada, (AZ, L, CK,) and thr-d↓, (TA,) It (flesh-meat) became cooked so that it fell off from the bones: or, cooked much: or, cooked thoroughly and well: (L, Ḳ:*) or it, being put into the fire, became thoroughly cooked. (AZ, L.) Irreg. verb. haradotu AlX-aIoCa, aor. Ouhariyduhu, [in the CK, Ouhoriyduhu,] (Lḥ, M, art. rwd; and Ḳ,) inf. n. hiraAdapN, (Lḥ, M in art. rwd,) i. q. Oaradotuhu [q. v., in art. rwd, I willed, wished, or desired, the thing]. (Lḥ, M, art. rwd; and Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 2: see 1.
hr-d, inf. n. tahoriydN, He wore a mahoruwd, (Ḳ,) i. e., a yellow garment, dyed with hurod. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1.

hurodN Certain roots with which one dyes, (L, Ḳ,) of a yellow colour: (TA:) or (so accord. to the L; but in the Ḳ, and) i. q. kurokumN: (L, Ḳ:) or the yellow kurokum: correctly, the roots of the kurokum, or waros: (TA:) and a certain red earth (Ḳ) with which one dyes. (TA.)

hirodaI, (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ, [but in the last it is not shown whether it be with or without tenween]) of the measure faEolaI, (Ṣ, L,) of the fem. gen., (IAmb,) but AḤn says, I know not whether it be masc. [and therefore with tenween] or fem. [and therefore without tenween], (L.) [in one instance in the L, and in a copy of the Ḳ, written hrdA, which is evidently wrong,] and hirodaMC, [i. e. hirodaMCu or hirodaMCN,] (L, Ḳ,) and hirodaAnN↓, (L,) A certain plant; (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) a certain herb, of which AḤn says, that he had not met with a description of it: (L:) and hayorudaAnN↓ is also the name of a certain plant, (Ḳ,) like hirodaI, (L,) or i. q. hirodaAnN. (TA.)
hurodiI-N: see mahoruwdN.
hirodaAnN: see hirodaI.
hayorudaAnN: see hirodaI.
hariydN and mahoruwdN↓ A garment, or piece of cloth, rent, or torn; (L;) as also hariytN. (AZ.)
mahoruwdN: see hariydN.

Also, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed yellow (Ṣ, L) with hurod; (L;) and so muhar-adN↓ (L) and hurodiI-N↓: (Ḳ,* TA,) or, as Sh says, accord. to information given to Aboo-ʼAdnán by an intelligent Arab of the desert, of the people called Báhileh, dyed with waros, and then with saffron, so as to become of a colour like that of the flower of the HawocaAnap: (Az, L:) or of a light yellow colour. (IAmb, L.)
muhar-adN: see mahoruwdN.
Q. 1. harodaba, inf. n. harodabapN, (and hrdb, TA, [a strange form: perhaps a mistake for harodaAbN or hirodaAbN:]) He ran heavily. (IḲṭṭ, &c., and Ḳ.)
hirodab-apN (and hirodab-N, TA) An old woman. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, (as some say, TA,) Having a swollen belly, and cowardly: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or cowardly, bulky, of little sense, swollen in the belly, and having no heart. (TA.)
Accord. to Az, in the T, A large, long-bodied man is called hirodab-apN. (TA.)

1. harasahu, aor. _u {yahorusu}, (IF, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. harosN, (IF, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He bruised, brayed, or pounded, it; crushed it so as to break it; broke it, or broke it in pieces, by beating; (Ṣ, IF, Mṣb, TA;) namely, grain, (Mṣb,) or some other thing: (IF, Mṣb:) or he did so vehemently, or violently: (A, Ḳ:) or with something broad: or with some preservative between it and the ground. (TA.)

hariysN Grain, (Mṣb,) or wheat, (A,) bruised, brayed, or pounded, (A, Mṣb,) vehemently, or violently, (A,) with the mahoraAs, before it is cooked; for when it is cooked, it is termed hariysapN: (Mṣb:) [of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN:] from the verb above-mentioned. (Ḳ.) You say, EinodiI hariysN lilohariysapi I have wheat bruised,, &c., for the hariysap. (A.)

hariysapN Grain, (Mṣb,) or wheat, (TA,) bruised, brayed, or pounded, [vehemently, or violently, (see hariysN,)] and then cooked: (Mṣb, TA:) [or a kind of thick pottage, prepared of cooked wheat and cooked flesh-meats much pounded together: (Golius; app. on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof:) but this is probably one of the kinds of hrysp peculiar to post-classical times; which kinds are many: see De Sacy's Relation de l'Égypte par Abd-Allatif, pp. 307 and 312:] of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (Mṣb:) from the verb above-mentioned: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. haraAYisu. (A.)
har-aAsN A maker, or preparer, of hariysap: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and a seller thereof. (Mgh.)

mihoraAsN [in the M, voce juronN, q. v., accord. to the TA, mhrs, i. e., app. mihorasN,] A stone hollowed out, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) oblong, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and heavy, resembling a [vessel of the kind called] tawor, q. v., (Mgh,) in which one bruises, brays, or pounds, and from which one performs the ablution termed wuDuwoC; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) and it is also made of brass; and grain and other things are bruised in it: (Mṣb:) and sometimes, by a tropical application, ‡ one of wood, (Mgh, Mṣb,) used for the same purpose: (Mṣb:) or a mortar; syn. haAwuwnN; (Ḳ;) or thing in which grain is bruised: (A, TA,) and also, (A, Ḳ,) tropically, (A,) ‡ a hollowed stone, (A, Ḳ,) of oblong shape, (A,) from which one performs the ablution above mentioned; (A, Ḳ;) consisting of a bulky stone, which several men cannot lift nor move because of its weight, capable of holding much water. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. hariXa, aor. _a {yahoraXu}, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. haraXN, (TḲ,) † He (a man, TA) was, or became, evil, or bad, in disposition. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

hraXa Ald-ahoru, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, Ḳ,) and Alz-amaAnu, (A,) aor. _u {yahoruXu} and _i {yahoriXu}, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. haroXN, (TḲ,) ‡ Time, or fortune, was, or became, distressful, or calamitous. (I'Abbád, A, Ḳ.) [In the A, app. by inadvertence, hrX Aldhr is mentioned as proper; and hrX AlzmAn, as tropical.]

entry.sense: 2. har-aXa bayona AlkilaAbi, (A,* Ḳ,* TḲ,) inf. n. tahoriyXN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He excited strife, or quarrel-ling, between, or among, the dogs; syn. Har-aXa: (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ, TḲ:) and hArX↓ bayona AlkilaAbi, (A, Mgh, TA,) or biAlkilaAbi, (Ṣ,) or baEoDa AlkilaAbi EalaI baEoDK, (Ḳ,* TḲ,) inf. n. muhaAraXapN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ) and hiraAXN, (Ṣ, Mgh,) he incited the dogs to attack one another. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] hr-X bayona Alqawomi, (A,) or bayona Aln-aAsi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ He excited discord, dissension, disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, between, or among, the people. (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ.)
3. haAraXaA [They fought and assailed each other]: said of two dogs. (A.) See also 6.
[Hence,] kalobu hiraAXK [An irritable, or a quarrelsome, dog]; like kalobu xiraAXK. (TA.)
See also 2.
hiraAXN is also used to signify The fighting against each other of men. (Mgh.)
6. thArXt AlkilaAbu, and AhtrXt↓, (A, Ḳ, TA,) and haAraXa↓ baEoDuhaA baEoDFA, (A,) The dogs fought and assailed one another. (TA.)
8: see 6.
hiroXab-apN An old woman far advanced in years: (Ḳ:) a worn-out old woman; as also hiroXaf-apN. (T.)

haraAmiytu Wells: (Ḳ;) a pl. that has no sing.; or its sing. is hiromiytN or huromuwtN; or perhaps the t is an augmentative letter: (MF:) or, accord. to the L, it is a name of a certain group of wells in the tract of Ed-Dahma, said to have been dug by Lukmán the son of 'Ád: or, accord. to Aṣ, certain wells on the left of Dareeyeh: if so, F has erred in prefixing to it the art. Al. (TA.)

1. haz-ahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and haz-a bihi, [respecting which see what is said on an ex. below,] (A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yahozuzu}, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. haz-N, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) [He shook it;] he put it in motion, or into a state of commotion; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also hz-zhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and hz-z bihi, (TA,) inf. n. tahoziyzN; (Ḳ;) and hazohazahu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. hazohazapN; (TA;) meaning, he made it move by pulling and pushing; or he made it move to the right and left: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, he did so with violence, or vehemence. (TA.) It is said that haz-a is trans. by itself, and by means of bi, like Oaxaca and taEal-aqa: it is trans. in the latter manner in the Ḳur., [xix. 25,] where it is said, wahuz-iI Uilayoki bijicoEi Aln-axolapi [And shake thou towards thee the trunk of the palm-tree], i. e. Har-ikiI: but ISd says, that the verb is here made trans. by means of b because it is used in the sense of jur-iI: and MF says, that, properly, it is not trans. by means of b. (TA.) You say, haz-a Als-ayofa wagayorahu [He shook the sword,, &c.] (A.) And haz-ati Alr-iyHu AlOagoSaAna, (A,) and AlX-ajara, and haz-azatohaA↓, (Ṣ,) [The wind shook the branches, and the trees,] and haz-ati Aln-abaAta it shook (Har-akat) the plants: but this has also a tropical signification, which see below. (TA.)

You say also, Ouhuz-u katifiI, and manokibiI, ‡ [lit., I shake my shoulderblade, and my shoulder-joint;] meaning, I walk with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait; I behave with pride and self-conceitedness. (Mgh.) And haz-a EiTofayohi likacaA ‡ [lit., He shook his sides at such a thing app. meaning, he was active, or prompt, and brisk, or was moved with alacrity, to do such a thing, or he was rejoiced at such a thing: like Aihotaz-a lahu↓, q. v.]: and in like manner, haz-a manokibayohi. (A.) [In like manner also you say,] haz-a maA raOayotu mino EiTofaI [app. meaning, accord. to a gloss cited by De Sacy in his Anthol. Gr. Ar., p. 309, ‡ What I saw rejoiced me: or, as rendered by him, p. 286, ce dont j'étois temoin, réveilla en moi le courage.] (Z, in his preface to the Keshsháf.) And haz-a AlUibila, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yahozuzu}, inf. n. haz-N (TA) and haziyzN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) ‡ He (a man urging his beasts by singing) made the camels to be brisk, or sprightly, by his singing to urge them. (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ.) And haz-ahaA Als-ayoru ‡ [The journeying made them to be brisk, or sprightly]. (TA.) And haz-a bihi Als-ayoru † The pace brought him on quickly. (TA.) And hazazotu fulaAnFA lixayorK † I made such a one to rejoice [or to be prompt and brisk (see the quasi-pass., 8,) to do good]: said of a generous man: (En-Naḍr, TA:) and hazohazotuhu↓ and hazohazotu minohu [app. signify the same]. (A.) And jaMCa fulaAnN yahuz-u AlmaXoIa, and yahuD-uhu, † Such a one came walking impulsively: (JK in art. hD:) or with a graceful gait, impulsively. (Ibn-El-Faraj, TA, in art. hD.)
You also say, of a plant, or herbage, haz-atohu↓ Alr-iyaAHu waAlOamoTaAru ‡ The winds and the rains made it to become tall. (A, TA.*)
haz-a Alkawokabu: see 8.
[mahaz-apN seems to be an inf. n. of haz-ahu.] You say rumoHN ladonu Almahaz-api (Ṣ, TA, art. ErS,) [app. for Einoda Almahaz-api] A spear that vibrates, or quivers, when shaken. (TA, ibid.)
2: see 1, in two places.
5: see 8.

8. Ahtz-, (inf. n. AihotizaAzN,) quasi-pass. of haz-ahu, (TA,) [It shook; or quivered;] it became in motion, or in a state of commotion; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also thz-z↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) quasi-pass. of hz-zhu; (TA;) and tahazohaza↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) [quasi-pass. of hazohazahu; meaning, accord. to explanations of haz-ahu in the TA, it became moved by being pulled and pushed; or it became moved to the right and left: or it became so moved with violence, or vehemence.]

Ahtz- AlmaMCu fI jazoyihi ‡ [app. the water quivered in its running]: and Alkawokabu fiI QnoqiDaADihi ‡ [the star in its shooting, or darting, down]: (Ṣ, A, TA:) and Ahtz- Alkawokabu ‡ the star shot, or darted, down [app. with a quivering motion]; (O, L, TA;) as also haz-a. (A, Ḳ.)
Ahtz- Almawokibu ‡ The procession, or cavalcade, went quickly: (En-Naḍr, TA:) or made a noise and clamour. (Ṣ.)

Ahtz-t AlUibilu ‡ The camels, being urged on by the singing of their driver, became brisk, or sprightly. (Ṣ,* A, TA.) You say also, Ahtz- liOamorK ‡ He was, or became, active, or prompt, and brisk, or cheerfully excited, at a thing, or to do a thing. (TA.) [Ex.] Ahtz- lixayorK ‡ He rejoiced [or was active or prompt,, &c., to do good]: said of a generous man. (En-Naḍr, TA.) And huwa yahotaz-u lilomaEoruwfi ‡ [He rejoices, or is active, or prompt,, &c., to do what is beneficent, or kind]. (A.) [Hence the saying,] fulaAnN laA yahotaz-u walekin-ahu yakutaz-u ‡ [Such a one does not rejoice,, &c., to give, but he shrinks from giving]. (A, TA, art. kz.) [Hence also,] Uihutaz-a EaroXu Alr-aHomaAni limawoti saEodK ‡ The empyrean of the Compassionate rejoiced at the death of Saạd; (En-Naḍr, IAth, Ḳ, TA;) meaning Saạd Ibn-Mo'ádh; (TA;) i. e., when he [meaning his soul] was taken up; (IAth, TA;) because of the honour in which he was held by his Lord; (Ḳ;) or the inhabitants of the empyrean rejoiced at his death: these words occur in a trad., of which there is another relation, Ahtz- AlEaroXu: and some say, that by AlErX is meant the bier upon which Saạd was removed to his grave. (TA.) You also say, tahazohaza↓ Uilayohi qalobiI ‡ My heart became moved by a cheerful, or joyful, affection towards him. (Ḳ, TA.)
Ahtz- Aln-abaAtu ‡ The plant, or herbage, became tall. (A, TA.)
Ahtz-t AlOaroDu ‡ The land produced plants, or herbage: (A:) or became put in motion, and produced plants, or herbage. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. hazohazahu, and hazohazotuhu, and hazohazotu minohu: see 1.
Also, the first, (inf. n. hazohazapN, TA,) ‡ He subdued him, or rendered him submissive; syn cal-alahu. (Ḳ,* TA.)
R. Q. 2. tahazohaza: see 8, in two places.
Also, ‡ He became subdued, or submissive; quasi-pass. of hazohazahu. (TA.)
haz-apN ‡ Brisk and rejoicing to do evil or mischief; applied to a woman: pl. haz-aAtN. (A, TA.)

hiz-apN ‡ Briskness, or sprightliness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and ‡ briskness, sprightliness, alacrity, or cheerfulness, disposing one to promptness in acts of liberality, kindness, and beneficence; or liberality of disposition; syn. OaroyaHiy-apN; (Ḳ;) and [in like manner] haziyzN↓ ‡ briskness, or sprightliness, of camels when urged on by the singing of their driver. (A, TA.)

‡ A kind of pace, or manner of going, of camels; (Aṣ, Ḳ;) when the train goes quickly: (Aṣ,* En-Naḍr, TA:) or a state of commotion of a train or procession or cavalcade: (ISd, TA.) or the confused sound thereof. (IDrd, TA.)

‡ The sound of the boiling of a cooking-pot: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) † the reiterating sound of thunder; as also haziyzN↓ (Ḳ:) which latter has likewise the following similar significations: † a sound, or noise; (Ḳ:)
as, for instance, a sound, or noise, of turning of a mill; as also Oaziyz-a [inf. n. of Oaz-a]: (TA:) and ‡ the murmuring of the wind (Ṣ, Ḳ) when it shakes the trees: (Ṣ:) or the sound of the blowing of the wind: (TA:) or the lightness of the wind, and the quickness of its blowing. (A, TA.)
haziyzN: see hiz-apN.
hazaAYizu † Difficulties, afflictions, or calamities: [a pl.] having no singular. (Th, TA.)
kawokabN haAz-N ‡ [A star shooting, or darting, down; or quivering in doing so: see 8]. (Ṣ, TA.)
hazohazapN: see R. Q. 1, of which it is the inf. n.: and see hazaAhizu.

hazaAhizu [app. pl. of hazohazapN] Seditions, or discords, or dissensions, (fitanN,) in which people are in a state of commotion: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or wars and difficulties or afflictions or calamities that put into a state of commotion: (A:) or the excitement of commotion in men, by trials, or trying events, and by wars; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also hazohazapN↓. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. hazaOa minohu, (Ḳ,) and bihi; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and haziYa (Ṣ, Ḳ) followed by mnh and bh; (Akh, Ṣ;) but accord. to Yoo, we should say hzY bh only; not mnh; (TA;) aor. _a {yahozaOu}, inf. n. huzoCN and huzuWN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and huzuwoCN (TA) and mahozaOapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and thz-O↓ bh, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AsthzO↓ bh; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

The most approved reading of musotahoziYuwna↓ in the Ḳur, ii. 13, is with the C fully pronounced: some alleviate it: and some read musotahoziyurna: and some musotahozuwna; (but this pronunciation is of weak authority;) and say Uisotahozayotu for UisotahozaOotu. (Zj.)
Als-araAbu yahozaOu biAlr-akobi ‡ [The mirage mocks the company of riders]. (A.)
hazaOa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. hazoCN, (TA,) He, or it, broke a thing. (Ḳ.)

A poet says, describing a coat of mail,
lahaA Eukano tarud-u Aln-abola xanosFA
watahozaOu biAlomaEaAbili waAlqiTaAEi
[It has creases that repel the arrows, making them to recede, and break the broad and long arrow-heads, and those which are small and broad]. The b in bAlmEAbl is redundant. This is the opinion of the lexicologists, except ISd, who thinks that this is an error, and that thzO here means “mocks.” (TA.)

hazaOa Uibilahu (Ḳ; but it is thought that this may be a mistake for haraOa, TA,) inf. n. hazoCN; (TA;) and AhzO hA↓; (Ḳ;) He killed his camels with cold. IAạr says, that AhzOhu Albarodu and AhrOhu both signify The cold killed him. (TA.)
hazaOa He put in motion, [or excited,] the beast on which he rode. (Aṣ, Ḳ.)
hazaOa and haziYa He died (Ḳ) in his place, or on the spot; i. e. unexpectedly, or suddenly: (Z:) improperly objected against by Ibn-Es-Sáïgh. ('Ináyeh, MF.)
4. AhzO He entered upon the time of severe cold. (Ḳ.) See also AhrO, which is the word commonly known. (TA.)
See 1.
AhzOto bihi naAqatuhu His she-camel hastened with him. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1.
huzoOapN One who is mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided; a ridiculous person. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
huzaOapN One who mocks at, scoffs at, laughs at, derides, or ridicules, others. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
gadaApN haAziYapN ‡ A morning intensely cold: as though mocking men when they shrug and shiver. (A.)
mafaAzapN haAziYapN biAlr-akobi, and with huzaOapN for hAzYp, ‡ [A desert that mocks the company of riders]. (A.)

hawozabN A camel strong in running; syn. qawiI-u AljaroIi: (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ:) or a strong and bold camel; syn. qawiI-N jariYN: (so in the Ṣ, in several copies): a strong camel: (El-Jarmee:) a camel advanced in age, and bold. (Aṣ.)
hawozabN A vulture, (Ḳ,) advanced in age. (TA.)
hayozabN Sharp; fierce; syn. HadiydN.
lyovN hayozabu A sharp, or fierce, lion: (Ḳ, accord. to the TA:) or a strong lion. (CK.)
haAzibaI and haAzibaACu A kind of fish. (Ḳ.)

hizaborN and hizobarN and huzaAbirN, (Ḳ,) or the first [only], (TA,) Thick and bulky: and strong and hard or hardy: pl. hazaAbiru. (Ḳ.) You say, naAqapN hizaborapN A hard, or hardy, she-camel. (IAạr.)

Also, the first, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the second and third, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) The lion: (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) accord. to some, because of his thickness and bulkiness. (TA.) Some say that the h is a radical letter: others, that it is augmentative, and that the word is from zaborN, signifying the “act of repelling with strength.” (MF, TA.)

1. hazija, aor. _a {yahozaju}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. hazajN; (L;) He sang in a certain manner, with trilling, or quavering; as also thz-j↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and hz-j↓: (Ḳ:) or thz-j↓ signifies he reiterated, or made to reciprocate, the graceful modulations of his voice: or prolonged his voice, without elevating it: (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, L:) or hazajN does not at all signify trilling, or quavering; and therefore IAạr has applied hazijN as an epithet to a dog that barks much. (L.)
He read, or recited, with a prolonging and trilling of the voice, making the sounds to follow closely, one upon another; as also thz-j↓. (TA.)
2. hz-j AlS-awota, inf. n. thoziyjN, He (a singer [or a reader or reciter]), made the sounds of the voice to be closely consecutive, and uttered in a light and quick manner. (L.)
hz-j Sawotahu, and thz-jhu↓, [the latter app. a mistake for thz-j fiyhi,] He made the sounds of his voice to be closely consecutive, or near together. (TA.)
See 1.
4. Ahzj He (a poet) composed, or uttered, verses of the metre termed Alhazaj. (Ḳ.)
5. thz-jt Alqawosu ‡ The bow twanged, on the archer's loosing the string after drawing it. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
See 1, and 2.

[hazajN ‡ The twanging of a bow, on the archer's loosing the string after drawing it; and of a lutestring: in the TA, i. q. ran-pN: pl. OahozaAjN and pl. pl. OahaAziyju: or perhaps this latter is a pl. of which the sing. is OuhozuwjapN↓, like as OaraAjiyzu is pl. of OurojuwzapN: and the twanging of a bow-string or lute-string may be likened to an ode or a song of the metre termed Alhazaj, which is perhaps, judging from analogy, the proper signification of Ahzwjp.] liloEuwdi waAlqawosi OahaAziyju ‡ [To the lute and the bow there are twangings]. (A.) El-Kumeyt says, [speaking of a bow,]
lamo yaEibo rab-uhaA walaA Aln-aAsu minohaA
gayora UinocaArihaA Ealayohi AlHamiyraA
biOahaAziyja mino OagaAniy-ihaA AljuXi
waUitobaAEihaA Aln-aHiyba Alz-afiyraA
[Neither its owner nor the people imputed a fault to any of its properties, except its warning the (wild) asses of his presence by the twangings of its harsh singings, and its causing a groaning sound to follow the loud, or prolonged, wailing]. (Ṣ.)
hazajN One of the modes of singing (AlOagaAniI-), in which is a trilling, or quavering: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. OahozaAjN. (L.) [But see 1.]
A voice that excites lively emotions of joy or grief. (Ḳ.)
A fine, or delicate, and elevated, voice. (TA.)
A voice in which is hoarseness, or harshness. (Ḳ.)
Any speech of which the component parts are closely consecutive, or near together, (Ḳ,) uttered in a light, or quick, manner: pl. as above. (L.)

AlhazajN The name of a certain kind of metre of verse; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) consisting of four feet, each of the measure mafaAEiyluno: originally of six feet, like the rajaz and the ramal, in each of which, [as in the hazaj,] each foot consists of one element of the kind termed watidN majomuwEN, and of two elements of the kind termed sababN xafiyfN: so called because of the mutual nearness of its component parts. (TA.)
hazajN Lightness, or agility. (TA.)
Quickness in the falling, and putting down, of the legs [upon the ground]. (TA.)
‡ The sound of thunder. (Ṣ.)
† The buzzing of flies. (L.)
hazijN A singer [or reader or reciter] who prolongs his voice, with trilling, or quavering, making the sounds to follow close, one upon another. (A.)

haziju AlEasiI-i, occurring in a verse of 'Antarah, cited voce daf-N, The cat that cries for food at supper-time: (EM, p. 233:) or the dog that barks much in the evening; meaning, in the night: or buzzing flies in the evening. (L.)
hazijN A child, and a horse, whose legs fall, or are put down, quickly [upon the ground]. (TA.)
‡ Sounding thunder, as also mutahaz-ijN↓. (L.)
‡ A twanging lute [and bow]. (A.)
‡ A cloud sounding with thunder. (A.)
haziju AlS-awoti, and huzaAmijuhu↓, One who makes the sounds of his voice to follow close, one upon another. (L.)
hazomajapN Uninterrupted speech or language. (Ḳ.)
Confusion of voice or sound beyond measure; (Ḳ;) as also hazolajapN. (Ḳ, TA, art. hzlj.)
[The m is an augmentative letter: see huzaAmijN.]
huzaAmijN A voice, or the like, of which the sounds are closely consecutive. The m is an augmentative letter. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
SawotN huzaAmijN A confused voice or sound. The sound so called is less than what is termed rugaMCN. (L.)
[See also hazjN.]
OuhozuwjapN: see hazajN.
mutahaz-ijN: see hazijN.

hazaArN [The nightingale;] a certain bird, (Ḳ. TA,) the same that is called EanodaliybN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. Endlb,) of sweet voice; improperly said in the Ḳ to be what is called in Persian hazaAro dasotaAno; for hzAr itself is Persian, and signifies “a thousand,” and daAsotaAno means [as also dasotaAno in that language] “a tale;” as though this bird, in the sweetness of its warbling and the pleasantness of its melody, told a thousand tales; being thus called by way of hyperbole and excessive praise: then they contented themselves by employing the word hzAr alone; and the Arabs used it, and prefixed to it the article Al: (TA:) the pl. is hazaAraAtN. (Mṣb.)
Q. 1. hazoraba, inf. n. hazorabapN, He was light, or active, and quick, or swift. (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ.) A dial. form. of hacoraba. (TA.)
Q. 1. hazolaja, inf. n. hazolajapN, He (an ostrich, or anything,) was quick, or swift. (TA.)
hazal-ajN A quick, or swift, he-ostrich. (Ḳ.)

hizolaAjN Quick, or swift: (TA:) a light, or an agile, (and swift, or quick, TA,) wolf: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. hazaAliju and hazaAliyju. (TA.) Accord. to Kr, it is derived from Alhazaju. (TA.) [See hzomajapN in art. hzj.]
hazomajapN and huzaAmiju: see art. hzj.
hasobN Sufficiency; like HasobN. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. haX-a, aor. yahiX-u; (JK, TA;) or haX-a, secpers. haXiXota, aor. yahaX-u; (Mṣb;) inf. n. haXaAXapN (JK, A, Mṣb, TA) [and huXuwXapN and huXuwXN and haX-N, as appears from what follows]; It, (a thing) was, or became, soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, slack, uncompact, crummy, fragile, frangible, brittle, friable, easily or quickly broken; (JK, A, Mṣb, TA;) syn. kaAna fiyhi raxaAwapN, (JK,) or kaAna rixowFA lay-inFA, (A,* TA,) or laAna waQsotaroxaI. (Mṣb.) You say, haX-a Alxubozu, aor. _i {yahoXiXu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. huXuwXapN (Ḳ) and haX-N, (TA,) meaning, SAr haX-FA; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., The bread became [soft, &c., or] easy to break. (TA.) And haX-a AlEuwdu, (IAạr, Mṣb,) aor. [_i, or] _a, (Mṣb,) inf. n. huXuwXN, (IAạr, Mṣb,) The wood, or stick, broke in pieces: (IAạr:) or became easily or quickly broken. (Mṣb.) And haX-ati AlX-ajarapu, inf. n. haX-N, The tree dropped its leaves, one after another. (Mṣb [in which it seems to be indicated that the aor. of the verb in this sense is _u; but this is contr. to rule in an intrans. verb of this class; and I think it improbable.])

haX-a, inf. n. huXuwXapN, † He (a man) became weak; unable to endure difficulty or distress. (TA.) And haX-a,, aor. _i {yahoXiXu}, † He affected languor, or languidness; syn. takas-ara: and he became old, or aged. (TA.)

haX-a, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) first pers. haXiXotu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yahaX-u; (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and haX-a, first pers. haXaXotu, aor. yahiX-u; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) inf. n. haXaAXapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and haXaAXN; (A, Ḳ;) ‡ He was, or became, cheerful, brisk, lively, or sprightly: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he smiled, and was, or became cheerful, brisk, lively, or sprightly. (Mṣb.) You say, haXiXotu bifulaAnK, (Ṣ, TA,) and haXaXotu bihi, (TA,) ‡ I was, or became, cheerful,, &c. in behaviour towards such a one: (Ṣ:) or I was, or became cheerful in countenance, or joyful, or pleased, at meeting with such a one. (TA.) And huwa yahaX-u UilaI UixowaAnihi, ‡ [He is cheerful,, &c., towards his brethren]. (A.) And daxalotu Ealayohi faQhotaX-a↓ biI ‡ [I went in to him, and he was cheerful,, &c., in his behaviour towards me]; like Uihotaz-a lI. (A,* TA.) And haXiXotu lilomaEoruwfi, (JK, TA,*) and haXaXotu, (TA,) inf. n. haXaAXapN (Ṣ) and haXaAXN, (A,) ‡ I was, or became, cheerful, brisk,, &c., to do what was kind, or beneficent: (Ṣ,* TA:) or I desired to do it: (JK:) and UihotaXaXotu↓ llmErwf I was, or became, cheerful,, &c., and desirous, to do what was kind, or beneficent. (TA.) And huwa cuw haXaAXK UilaI Alxayori ‡ [He possesses cheerfulness, briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, of disposition to do good]. (A.) Accord. to Sh, haXiXotu signifies † He rejoiced, and desired; or was, or became, joyful, and desirous. (TA.) And the phrase haXiXotu UilaI QmoraOatiI, if correct, means either † I inclined towards my wife, or I was, or became, brisk, or sprightly, in disposition towards her. (Mgh.) And accord to ISd, haXaAXu Alqawomi [so in the TA, but accord. to the JK haXaAhiXu,] † The people's being in a state of commotion, or agitation. (TA.)

haX-a Alwaraqa, aor. _u {yahoXuXu}, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and _i, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. haX-N, (Ṣ,) He beat the leaves with a staff, or stick, in order that they might fall; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also haXohaXahu↓. (Z, TA.) It is said in the Ḳur, [xx. 19,] (Ṣ,) waOahuX-u bihaA EalaI ganamiI [And I beat the leaves with it in order that they may fall upon my sheep, or goats]: (Ṣ, A:) or, accord. to Fr, and I beat the dry trees with it in order that their leaves may fall so that my sheep, or goats, may feed upon them; and so says Aṣ: (TA:) Lth says, that AlhaX-u signifies thy drawing towards thee a branch of a tree: and also, thy scattering its leaves towards thee with a staff, or stick: (JK,* TA:) but Az says, that the correct explanation is that given by Fr and Aṣ; not the former of the two explanations given by Lth. (TA.)
[The verb also seems to have a similar application in a more extended sense; for it is said that] haX-a, aor. _u {yahoXuXu}, inf. n. haX-N, signifies He (a man) assaulted (SaAla) with his staff, or stick. (Mṣb.) You say also, haX-a AlhaXiyma He broke in pieces the dry herbage or the like. (TA.)
2. hX-Xhu, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. tahoXiyXN, (TA,) † He deemed him, or reckoned him, weak, or feeble, (JK, Ḳ,*) and soft, or gentle. (TA.)

‡ He, or it, rendered him brisk, lively, or sprightly; and joyful, glad, or happy: (Ḳ:) and AsthX-hu↓ ‡ it (a thing, JK, TA) incited him, or excited him, to briskness, liveliness or sprightliness; syn. Uisotaxaf-ahu. (JK, Ḳ, TA.) You say, fulaAnN maA yasotahiX-uhu↓ Aln-aEiymu ‡ [Such a one, weal, or welfare, does not excite him to briskness,, &c.] (A, TA.)

entry.sense: 8. AhtX- He was, or became, cheerful,, &c.: see 1, in two places.
10: see 2, in two places.
R. Q. 1. haXohaXahu: see 1, latter part.
He moved, or put in motion, or into a state of commotion, him, or it. (IDrd, Ḳ.)

haX-N A thing, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or anything, (JK,) soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, slack, uncompact, crummy, fragile, frangible, brittle, friable, easily or quickly broken; (JK,* Ṣ,* A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA;) syn. rixowN lay-inN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also haXiyXN↓. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, xubozN haX-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and haXaAXN↓, (Ḳ,) Bread that is [soft,, &c., or] easy to break. (TA.) And xubozapN haX-apN A lump of dough, baked in a fire in the ground, that is dry, or hard: asserted by IḲṭṭ to have two contr. significations. (TA.) [But to this assertion it may be replied, that dry bread is easy to break.] And in like manner, Outoruj-apN haX-apN A citron easy to break: or dry, or hard. (TA.) And EuwdN haX-N Wood, or a stick, that is easily, or quickly broken. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] huwa haX-N Almakosiri, (JK, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or Almakosari, (TA, [but this is contr. to all the other authorities that I know,]) and Almukas-ari, (TA,) ‡ He is easy, or compliant, when asked: (A:) or he is of easy nature, or disposition, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) with respect to what is sought, or demanded, of him, of things needed: (Ṣ:) said in praise of a man (Ṣ, TA) when it means [lit.] that he is not one whose wood gives only a sound when one endeavours to produce fire from it; but said in dispraise of a man when it means [lit.] that he is one whose wood is weak. (TA.) [And in like manner] haXiyXN↓ (Ḳ) and haAX-N↓ (TA) signify ‡ One who rejoices, or is glad, when asked. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, huwa haAXN↓ Einoda Als-uWaAli, and haXiyXN↓, ‡ He is one who rejoices, or is glad, at being asked. (TA.)

[Hence also,] rajulN haX-N, (TA,) or rajulN haX-N UilaI UixowaAnihi, and haAX-N↓, (JK,) ‡ A man who is cheerful, brisk, lively, or sprightly, in his behaviour towards his brethren. (JK, TA.) And rajulN haX-N baX-N ‡ A man who is cheerful, brisk, lively, or sprightly: (Ṣ:) or cheerful in countenance; pleasant [therein]. (Ṣ, TA in art. bX.) And OanaA bihi haX-N baX-N ‡ I am cheerful, brisk, lively, or sprightly, in behaviour towards him; (Ḳ;) joyful; happy. (TA.) And rajulN haX-N fuWaAduhu ‡ A man quick, or prompt, to do good. (Aṣ.) And faraXN haX-u AlEinaAni † [A horse that is brisk, lively, or sprightly; lit.,] light of rein. (TA.) And farasN haX-N ‡ A horse that sweats much; (JK, IF, Ḳ;) contr. of SaluwdN; (Ṣ;) or not Slwd. (A.)
haXuAXN: see haX-N, second sentence.
haXuwXN † A ewe, or she-goat, abounding with milk. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: haXiyXN Dry herbage, syn. haXiymN, (Ḳ, TA,) for the horses of the people of AlOasoyaAf [app. meaning the shores of 'Omán] in particular. (TA.)
See also haX-N, in three places.
Also, † A man who is niggardly towards his family, or others, with respect to food; syn. muHotirN. (TA.) [Thus it bears two contr. significations.]

entry.sense: haXiyXapN is thought by ISd to signify Leaves [app. beaten from a tree]. (TA.)
qirobapN haX-aAXapN A water-skin from which the water flows by reason of its thinness. (Ḳ.)
haXohaXapN † Motion; or commotion. (JK.) [haXaAhiXu is app. its pl.: see 1, next before haX-a Alwaraqa.]
haXohaAXN ‡ Good in disposition; liberal, or bountiful. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
haAX-N: see haX-N, in three places.
muhaXohiXapN, in the copies of the Ḳ erroneously written mutahaXohiXap, (TA,) † A woman who manifests love to her husband, and rejoices in him. (Ḳ,* TA.)
1. haSaba, aor. _u {yahoSubu}, inf. n. haSobN, He fled; ran away. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
1. haSarahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and haSara bihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yahoSiru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. haSorN, (A, Ḳ,) He pulled it: and he inclined it: or he pulled and inclined it: (A, Ḳ, TA [but in the last of these, only haSarahu is given in this sense, agreeably with the A:]) he brought it near; (Ḳ;) which is near in meaning to “he inclined it:” (TA:) he took hold of its (a branch's) head and inclined it towards him: (Ṣ:) or he inclined it (a branch) towards him: (A:) or he bent it (a branch) and drew it towards him: (Mgh:) he bent it; namely, a pliant thing, such as a branch and the like: (A, Ḳ:) and he broke it without separating: (Ḳ:) or he bent it, namely, anything: (A,* Ḳ:) as also AhtSrhu↓. (Ḳ.) Imra-el-Ḳeys says, (Ṣ, TA,) using the verb tropically, (TA,)
falam-aA tanaAzaEonaA AlHadiyva waOasomaHato
haSarotu biguSonK ciI XamaAriyxa may-aAli
And when we discoursed together, and she became compliant, I pulled, (TA,) or, laying hold of its head, inclined towards me, (Ṣ,) a branch with fruit-stalks, waving from side to side: the poet meaning, by the branch, her body, because bending, and soft or supple, like a branch, and likening her hair to the fruit-stalks of the raceme of a palm-tree, in respect of its abundance and luxuriance. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., respecting the building of the mosque of Kubà, rafaEa HajarFA vaqiylFA fahaSarahu UilaI baTonihi He raised a heavy stone, and inclined it towards his belly. (TA.) And in another trad., kaAna UicaA rakaEa haSara Zahorahu He used, when he bowed himself [in prayer], to bend down his back towards the ground: (TA:) or haSara Zahorahu signifies he bent his back much, making it even with his neck. (Mgh.)

‡ He pushed him or it; so accord. to all the copies of the Ḳ; but accord. to other authorities, ‡ he pressed or squeezed, him or it: and he pressed, or squeezed, him or it vehemently. (TA.) You say, haSara qironahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, ‡ He pressed, or squeezed, his adversary. (TA.)

Also, (Ḳ,) or haSarahu [alone], (Ṣ,) † He broke it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AhtSrhu↓. (Ṣ.)
