You say of a lion, haSara Alfariysapa, (A, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, ‡ He broke [the neck of] the prey, and inclined it towards him. (TA.) And haSara raOosa Alfariysapi, and biraOosihaA, (A, TA,) ‡ He [broke the head of, or] slew the prey. (TA.)
haSira jad-uhu, aor. _a {yahoSaru}, [inf. n. haSarN,] ‡ His good fortune declined. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 7.

7. AnhSr and AhtSr↓ It became pulled: and it became inclined: or it became pulled and inclined: it was brought near: it (a pliant thing, such as a branch and the like,) bent: it broke, without separating: or it (anything) bent: (Ḳ:) or it (a branch) inclined and bent: (TA:) or fell upon the ground: (AḤn, TA:) and thS-r↓ it (a branch) hung down, or was pendent. (TA.)
[It seems to be implied in the Ḳ that AnhSr and AhtSr↓ are quasi-passives of haSarahu in all its senses.]

hom.sense: 8. AhtSr: see 7.
AhtSrhu: see 1, in two places.
AhtSr Aln-axolapa He placed the racemes of the palm-tree upon the branches, and put them straight or even. (T, Ḳ.)

‡ The lion; as also huSarN↓ and huSarapN↓ (Ḳ) and haSuwrN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and haSowarN↓ and haSaworapN↓ (Ḳ) and haS-aArN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and haASirN↓ (Ḳ) and hayoSarN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ [in the CK hayoSuwrN↓]) and hayoSaArN↓ and mihoSarN↓ and mihoSaArN↓ and mihoSiyrN↓ and muhotaSirq↓: (Ḳ:) or haSuwrN is an epithet applied to a lion, (A, TA,) as also haS-aArN↓ and hayoSarN↓ [&c.], (A,) signifying, that slays and breaks: (TA:) pl. [of haASirN] hawaASiru and [poeticè] hawaASiyru. (TA.)
jad-N haSirN ‡ Declining good fortune. (TA.)

entry.sense: huSarN: see haSirN.
huSarapN: see haSirN.
haSuwrN: see haSirN.
haSowarN: see haSirN.
haSuwrapN: see haSirN.
haS-aArN: see haSirN.
haASirN: see haSirN.
hayoSarN: see haSirN.
hayoSaArN: see haSirN.
hayoSuwrN: see haSirN.
mihoSarN: see haSirN.
mihoSaArN: see haSirN.
mihoSiyrN: see haSirN.
muhotaSirN: see haSirN.

hom.sense: 1. haD-ahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yahoDuDu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. haD-N, (TA,) He broke it; as also AhtD-hu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and haDohaDahu↓; (Ḳ;) inf. n. haDohaDapN. (TA:) and the first, (Ṣ, A,) or ↓all, (Ḳ,) he bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed, it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. q. raD-ahu; i. e. a stone, &c.: (A:) or he broke it in a manner falling short of what is termed had-N, [in the CK, incorrectly Had-,] but exceeding what is termed raD-N: (Lth, Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, the first, he broke it leisurely, or gently: and the ↓last, he broke it hastily. (TA.) You say, AlfaHolu yahuD-u OaEonaAqa AlfuHuwli (Ṣ, A) The stallion breaks, or crushes, the necks of the [other] stallions; as also yuhaDohiDuhaA↓. (TA.) And AlUibilu yahuD-u AlOaroDa The camels bruise the ground. (L.)

Also, haD-ati AlUibilu † The camels hastened, or went quickly. (Ḳ.) And jaMCati AlUibilu tahuD-u Als-ayora, inf. n. as above, † The camels came hastening, or quickly. (TA.) And jaMCa fulaAnN yahuD-u AlmaXoIa, (Ibn-El-Faraj, JK, Ḳ,*) and yahuz-uhu, (Ibn-El-Faraj, JK,) † Such a one came walking impulsively: (JK:) or with a graceful gait, (Ibn-El-Faraj, Ḳ,) impulsively. (Ibn-El-Faraj.)
haD-a is also syn. with HaD-a. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. hD-D He bruised the ground vehemently with his feet. (TA.)
7. AnhD- It broke, or became broken: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it became bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed: (Ṣ:) quasi-pass. of haD-ahu and AhtD-hu. (TA.)
8: see 1, in two places.
AhotaDaDotu nafosiI lifulaAnK † I held myself to have fallen short of my duty to such a one; syn. UisotazadotuhaA. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ [in one copy of the Ṣ, UisotarocalotuhaA.])
UihotaDaDotu mino fulaAnK XayoYFA † I took from such a one a thing. (JK.)
R. Q. 1. haDohaDahu: see 1, in three places.

haD-aMCu A company (Ṣ, Ḳ) of men; of the measure faEolaMCu, like SaHoraMCu; mentioned by Th; (Ṣ;) and by Aṣ; (TA;) or a company of horses, or horsemen: (A, TA:) and a [troop of horse such as is termed] katiybap: because they break things. (TA.)
haDiyDN A thing (Ṣ) broken: bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed: as also mahoDuwDN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and munohaD-N↓. (Ṣ.)

haDaADapN, like saHaAbapN, (Ḳ,) or huDaADapN, (so in the JK,) † What is taken (maA yuhotaD-u [in the CK, erroneously, yahotaD-u,]) from any one. (JK [where it immediately follows the phrase UihotaDaDotu mino fulaAnK XayoYFA explained as above], Sgh, Ḳ.)

faHolN haD-aADN A stallion that breaks, or crushes, the necks of the [other] stallions; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also haDohaADN↓: (JK, Ḳ:) or a stallion that throws down a man, and a camel, then leans, bears, or presses, upon him with his breast. (IDrd.)
haDohaADN: see what next precedes.
mahoDuwDN: see haDiyDN.
munohaD-N: see haDiyDN.
muhaDohiDapN ‡ A woman (TA) who annoys, or molests, her fellow-wife or female neighbour, or her fellow-wives or female neighbours: (so accord. to different copies of the Ḳ:) transmitted by Ṣgh. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. haDabati Als-amaACu, aor. _i {yahoDibu}, The sky rained: (Ḳ:) or rained for some days incessently. (TA.) See haDobapN.
haDabatohumu Als-amaACu The sky rained upon them: (Ṣ:) it wetted them much. (TA.)
yahoDibu biAlX-iEori wabiAlxuTabi ‡ He pours forth verses, and discourses in rhyming prose, or the like. (A.)

haDaba fiI AlHadiyvi and AhtDb↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AhDb↓ (Ḳ, but omitted in the TA,) † He launched into discourse, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and talked much, or launched into discourse time after time, (TA,) and raised his voice. (Ṣ, TA.)
AihoDibuwA yaA qawom Talk, or speak, O people. (Ṣ.)
haDaba and AhDb↓ He talked loud. (AA.)
haDaba He (a man) walked in the manner of a stupid, dull, unexcitable person. (Ḳ.)
haDaba Alqawomu: see Dahaba, and haADibN.

entry.sense: 4: see 1.

hom.sense: 8: see 1.
AhtDb It (the vibrating of a bow-string) produced a twanging. (TA.)

entry.sense: 10. AsthDb It became what is termed haDob, (Ḳ,) or haDobap; (A;) i. e. a mountain of the kind so termed. (A.)

hom.sense:
haDobN A kind, mode, or way. A. Heyth quotes the following verse of El-Kumeyt, describing a horse:
muxay-afN baEoDuhu warodN wasaAYiruhu
jawonN OafaAniynu Uijoriy-aAhu laA haDobu
The poet means, that his running, or usual running, was of different, or various, kinds; not of one hDb, or kind. (L.)
See haDobapN.

entry.sense: haDabN: see haDobapN.

hom.sense:
haDobapN A rain: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a rain consisting of many drops: (IAth:) or a lasting rain, consisting of great drops: or a single fall thereof: (TA:) or hard rain: (Mṣb:) pl. hiDabN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like bidarN pl. of badorapN, (Ṣ,) extr. [with respect to rule], (TA,) and hiDaAbN, (Ḳ,) or this is pl. of haDobN accord. to the Ṣ; (TA;) and pl. pl. OahaADiybu; (Ḳ;) or this is pl. of hiDaAbN, which is pl. of haDobN↓, signifying fine showers of rain after other rain; syn. HalabaAtu qaTorK baEoda qaTorK; (AZ, Ṣ;) and this is what is correct: (TA:) or haDobN↓ signifies a fine rain; or a fine shower of rain; syn. Halobapu qaTorK: it is also said, in the L, that OuhoDuwbapN↓ is syn. with haDobN, [either in one of the last two senses, or as a coll. gen. n. of which haDobapN is the n. un., which it is said to be below,] and that AhADyb is its pl.: huDuwbapN↓ also is the same as AhDwbp: so in the phrase OaSaAbatohumu AlhDwbpu mina AlmaTari [The fine shower, or showers, of rain (or the shower of rain, or of copious rain, or of lasting rain consisting of large drops, or hard rain,) fell upon them]; mentioned in the Ḳ:
it is also said in the L, that haDobN forms in the pl. OahoDaAbN, and then OahaADiybu; like as qawolN forms OaqowaAlN, and then OaqaAwiylu. (TA.) haDobN↓ is also said to be a pl. of haDobapN; but it is rather a coll. gen. n., [of which haDobapN is the n. un.]: and haDabN is also added to the list of the pls. of the same word; but this, accord. to the Ṣ, on the authority of AA, is pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of haADibN, [act. part. n. of 1,] like as tabaEN is of taAbiEN, and baEadN of baAEidN. (TA.)

haDobapN A hill; (IAth:) or a mountain spreading over the surface of the ground: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a mountain composed of one mass of rock: (Ḳ:) or any firm, hard, large mass of rock: (TA:) or a long inaccessible mountain, separate from others; but only of red mountains: (Ḳ:) or a hill, such as is termed Oakamap, with few plants, or little herbage: (Mṣb:) pl. hiDabN and hiDaAbN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and pl. pl. OahaADiybu. (Ḳ, TA.) OahaADibu is used, by poetical licence, for AhADyb, in a poem of one of the Hudhalees: (TA:) [or it is pl. of OahoDubN, which is pl. of pauc. of haDobN]. haDobN is also said, in the Ṣ, and L, to be a pl. of haDobapN; but it is rather a coll. gen. n. (TA.)
An elevated, or overlooking, tract of sand. (TA, art. Twd.)
† A run; a single run. (AHeyth.)

entry.sense: hiDab-N ‡ A horse sweating much; or that sweats much. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Hard, or firm, and strong, or robust. (Ḳ.)
Large, or bulky; as an epithet applied to the kind of lizard called Dab-, and to other things. (TA.)
ganamN haDiybN Sheep or goats having little milk: (Ḳ:) app. form AlhaDobu, signifying Halobapu AlqaTori. (TA.)
huDuwbapN: see haDobapN.

haADibN, used after the manner of a rel. n., signifying cuw haDobK: so in the following expression in a verse of Aboo-Sakhr El-Hudhalee; fiI yawomK mina All-ahowi haADibK; which means In a day when the people had played much, and quickly: explained by the words kaAnuwA qado haDabuwA fiI All-ahowi. (TA.)
OuhoDuwbapN: see haDobapN.
rawoDapN mahoDuwbapN [A meadow, or the like, rained upon: or much wetted by rain]. (TA.)

1. hafata, aor. _i {yahofitu}, inf. n. hafotN; (TA;) and thAft↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) It fell continuously, or successively, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) part by part, (Ṣ,) or part after part, like as snow, or fine rain, falls. (TA.) thAft↓ is mostly used with reference to something evil; (TA;) [as] yatahaAfatuwna fiI Aln-aAri [They shall fall successively into the fire of hell]; (TA, from a trad.;) [and] tahaAfata AlfaraAXu fiI Aln-aAri The moths fell successively into the fire; (Ṣ;) [and] tahaAfaba Alqawomu The people fell down successively dead; (TA;) [and] tahaAfatuwA Ealayohi They fell upon him successively. (TA.)
hafata and tahaAfata↓ It (snow, and fine rain,) fell quickly. (TA.)
hafata, [aor. _i {yahofitu},] inf. n. hafotN, He, or it, fell; fell down. (TA.)
hafata, aor. _i {yahofitu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. hafotN and hufaAtN; (TA;) and Anhft↓; (Ṣ;) It was, or became, depressed, or lowered; syn. UinoxafaDa and Uit-aDaEa. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hafata and Anhft↓ It was, or became, lessened, or diminished. (IḲṭṭ.)
hafata, (aor. _i {yahofitu}, inf. n. hafotN, TA,) It became minute, fine, or slender; syn. daq-a. (Ḳ.)
hafata, (aor. _i {yahofitu} K,) inf. n. hafotN and hufaAtN, It flew about, or became dispersed, by reason of its lightness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hafata, aor. _i {yahofitu}, He talked much, without consideration. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 6. thAft It (a garment) fell in pieces, piece after piece falling off, and became worn out. (TA.)
thAft It was continuous, or successive; syn. tataAbaEa. (Ḳ.)
See also 1.
thAft Aln-aAsu EalaI AlmaACi The people pressed, or crowded, to the water, [one after another, or party after party]. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 7: see 1.

hom.sense: hafotN Rain falling quickly. (Ḳ.)
A depressed, or low, piece of ground: (Ḳ:) like hajolN. (Az.)
kalaAmN hafotN Inconsiderate loquacity. (TA.)
hafotN Abundant stupidity: (Ḳ:) surpassing stupidity. (IAạr.)

entry.sense: hafaAtN Stupid; foolish; of little sense. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [But see its syn. lafaAtN, voce Oalofatu.] Authorities differ respecting this word and lafaAtN, whether they should be written with t or with p or with both. (TA.)
Hab-N hafuwtN Grain that falls to the bottom of the cooking-pot, and swells out quickly. (Lth.)
waradato hafiytapN mina Aln-aAsi There came a party of men whom a year of drought had compelled to emigrate. (Ṣ.)
mahofuwtN Confounded; perplexed; amazed: (Ḳ:) like mahobuwtN. (TA.)
haqobN Width; amplitude; largeness. (Ḳ.)
hiqabo A word by which a horse is checked, or urged. (Ḳ.)
hiqab-N Having a large, or ample, throat, (Ḳ,) swallowing everything. (TA.)
Large, big, or bulky, and tall, or long; an epithet applied to an ostrich, (Lth, Ḳ,) and to other things: (Ḳ:) or long, or tall, as an epithet applied to other things than the ostrich. (TA.)
haqaboqabN Hard, or firm, and strong, or robust. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. haliba, aor. _a {yaholabu}, inf. n. halabN, He had much hair [of the kind termed hulob]; was very hairy. (Ḳ.)

halaba canaba Alfarasi, and halaba Alfarasa, aor. _u {yaholubu}, inf. n. halobN, He shore the tail of the horse: (Mṣb:) shore it, or cut it off, utterly. (TA.) halabahu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and hl-bh↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taholiybN; (TA;) He plucked from him (i. e. a horse, Ṣ,) his hulob [or coarse hair, of the tail, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
huliba It (a tail) was entirely cut off. (TA.)

halaba, aor. _u {yaholubu}; and Ahlb↓, (inf. n. UiholaAbN, TA); He (a horse) prosecuted, or continued, his course, or run, uninterruptedly; syn. taAbaEa AljaroIa: (Ḳ:) and, the latter verb, he (a horse,) was ardent, or impetuous, in his course, or running; as also Oalohaba. (Aṣ, in TA, art. lhb.) [See also Dahaba Alqawomu]

halabati Als-amaACu Alqawoma The sky wetted the people with dew (nadFI): or, with continual rain. (Ḳ.) halabatonaA Als-amaACu The sky wetted us with dew (ndI) or the like; (TA;) as also OaholabatonaA↓: (T:) the sky rained upon us a copious, or an excellent, rain. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
4: see 1.
5. thl-b and Anhlb↓ [He, a horse, had his tail shorn: see 1:] he had his hulob [or coarse hair, of the tail, &c.,] plucked out. (Ḳ.)
7: see 5.
8. Ahtlb He drew a sword from its scabbard. (TA.)

hom.sense: hulobN, [a coll. gen. n.,] Hair, absolutely: or coarse hair; (Ḳ;) as the hair of the tail of a she-camel: (Az:) or hair of the tail: or pigs' bristles, with which skins and the like are sewed: (Ḳ:) J gives this last signification to hulobapN↓: and also, coarse hair of the tail, &c.: (so in the Ṣ:) but hulobapN is the n. un. (TA.)
hulobN, The eyelashes. (TA.)
hulobN, call. gen. n., Hair that one plucks from the tail: n. un. with p {hulobapN}. (TA.)
hulabN [pl. of hulobapN] Tails and manes plucked out. (TA.)
hulobN Continuance, or constant succession, of rain. (TA.)

entry.sense: rajulN halibN [A man having much hair; of the kind called hulob; very hairy: see haliba:] a man whose hulob is growing forth. (TA.)

hom.sense: hulobapN The hair that is above the pubes, extending near to the navel. (TA.) See hulobN.
hulobapN Severity, or pressure, of fortune: like kulobapN and julobapN. (Ṣ.)
Also, and hulub-apN↓, Severity, or intenseness, of winter. (Ḳ.) Oatayotuhu fiI hlbpi AlX-itaACi I came to him during the severe, or intense, cold of winter. (El-Umawee.)

entry.sense: hulub-apN: see hulobapN.

haluwbN A woman who draws near to her husband, or ingratiates herself with him; syn. mutaqar-ibapN mino zawojihaA; (Ḳ, TA;) and is loving, or affectionate, to him; and distant with respect to others. (TA.)

Also, contr., A woman who is distant, or shy, with respect to her husband, or who alienates herself from him, or avoids or shuns him, (Ḳ,) and draws near to, or ingratiates herself with, her special friend. (TA.)

From halabahu bilisaAnihi “he carped at him severely with his tongue;” because a wife carps either at her husband or at her friend: or, accord. to IAạr, in the former sense, from yawomN hal-aAbN↓ “a day of gentle, constant, innocuous rain;” and in the latter sense from the same phrase as signifying “a day of rain attended by thunder and lightning and terrors, and destructive to dwellings.” (TA.)
haliybN and hulayobN: see hal-aAbN.

hulaAbapN The filth that is washed away from the membrane which encloses the fœtus: (Ḳ:) i. q. HuwalaACu: [a word which has two applications, which see:] also called hulaAbapu AlsqAC: (TA:) [but AlsqAC is written by mistake for Als-iqoIi]. [See also hulaAtapN.]

hom.sense: hal-aAbN (Ḳ) and hal-aAbapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) A cold wind, with rain. (Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ.)
yawomN hal-aAbN A day in which is wind and rain: (Ṣ:) a day of rain attended by thunder and lightning and terrors, and destructive to dwellings. (IAạr.)
Also, A day of gentle, constant, innocuous rain. (IAạr.)
Also, A day of dry cold; or dry by reason of cold. (Az, in the T, art. Hlb.)
EaAmN hal-aAbN, and Oaholabu↓, A year of much rain. (Ḳ.)
EAm Oaholabu↓ ‡ A plentiful, or fruitful, year; a year of abundant herbage, or vegetation: like Oazab-u. (Ṣ.)

hal-aAbN and muhal-ibN↓ and haliybN↓, (Ḳ,) or as in one copy of the Ḳ, that of Et-Tabláwee, the last is hulayobN↓, (TA,) and this is the more correct reading, (MF,) [Three] very cold days, in Kánoon el-'Owwal [or January O. Ṣ.]: or in the severe, or intense, cold of winter: (Ḳ:) or in the severe, or intense, cold of the month [above mentioned], in the latter part of it. (L.)
hal-aAbN ‡ One who satirizes [and reviles] much: (ISh:) [who carps much and severely at others with his tongue: see 1].

entry.sense: haAlibu AlX-aEori and mudaHoriju AlbaEori [Two] days of winter. (Ḳ.)
layolapN haAlibapN A rainy night. (Ḳ.)

Oaholabu Having much hair [of the kind called hulob]; very hairy: (Ḳ:) fem. halobaACu. (CK.) A horse having much hair of the kind called hlb: (Ṣ:) a coarse-haired man: (TA:) a man having coarse hair upon the part where are the two veins called AlOaxodaEaAni, and upon his body: (TA:) having much hair upon the head and body. (TA.)
Oaholabu A tail cut off. (Ḳ.)

Also, [accord. to the CK, or,] Having no hair upon it: and, contr., Having much hair: (Ḳ:) [in each sense, as seems to be implied in the Ḳ, an epithet applied to a tail: but, app., accord. to the TA, applied to a horse].
halobaACu, fem., A beast of carriage (TA) having much hair. (Ḳ, TA.)
halobaACu The podex; syn. UisotN: (Ḳ:) used as a subst.; originally an epithet. (TA.)

Uiy-aAka waOaholaba AlEaDoraTi Beware of him who has a hairy podex. Originally said by a woman to her son, who was boasting that he found no one whom he did not overcome, and who was afterwards thrown down by a man answering to this description. A proverb used in cautioning the self-conceited. (Meyd, TA.)
OaroDN halobaACu ‡ Land abounding with plants, or herbage. (TA.)
Also, [contr.,] ‡ Land of which the herbage has been eaten. (TA.)
hulobapN halobaACu (in the CK, halobapN hulobaACu) A severe calamity. (Ḳ.)
See hal-aAbN.

lahu OuholuwbN He [a horse] has ardour, or impetuosity, in his running, &c.: formed by transposition from, or a dial. form of, OulohuwbN. (M.) Eadowuhu cuw OahaAliyba [His (a horse's) running is of ardent, or impetuous, modes, or manners]. (TA.)
OaholuwbN A kind, or way [or speech]: syn. fan-N (Ḳ) and OasoluwbN: (AO:) pl. OahaAliybu. (AO, Ḳ.)
AhlwbN mn Alv-anaACi A kind, or way, of praising, or eulogizing. (TA.)

maholuwbN (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb) and muhal-abN↓ (TA) A horse having his tail shorn: (Mṣb:) having the hair of his tail utterly removed: (L:) having his hulob [or coarse hair, of the tail, &c.,] shorn: (A:) having his hlb plucked out. (Ṣ, TA.)
muhal-abN: see maholuwbN.
muhal-ibN: see hal-aAbN.
hilobaAvN A kind of dates. Said to be the only kind brought form El-Basrah to the Sultán. (AḤn.)
hilobawovN Stupid; foolish; of little sense: or dull of speech and understanding; doltish; heavy; syn. fadomN. (Ṣ, and some copies of the Ḳ.)

hilobaAjapN Stupid; foolish; of little sense: (Ṣ:) or one unsurpassed in stupidity, foolishness, or paucity of sense: or heavy, dull, stupid, and of little use: (TA:) or a heavy, or dull, man: (T:) as also hilobaAjN: (L:) Khalaf El-Aḥmar says, I asked an Arab of the desert respecting the meaning of hlbAjp, and he said, It means a stupid, or foolish, man, or one of little sense, bulky, or corpulent, impotent in speech or actions, and heavy, or dull, or doltish, a great eater, who … who … who …, and he continued to add to his interpretation something each time; after which he said to me, desiring to depart, he is one who comprises every evil quality. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
1. halata, [aor. _u {yaholutu}, and _i?] inf. n. halotN, He peeled a thing; or deprived it of its outer covering, or crust; syn. qaXara. (Ḳ.)
halata Ald-ama, as also salata, He peeled off, or scraped off, (qXara,) the [dried] blood with a knife. (Lḥ, L.)

halta dama Albadanapi, [as also salata,] He scratched the skin of the bdnp [or beast brought to Mekkeh for sacrifice, or there sacrificed, or the right reading is Aln-adabapi, i. e. the sear. (see salata,)] with a knife, so that he made the blood to appear. (Lḥ, L, TA.)
7. Anhlt yaEoduw i. q. Anslt, (in the CK, Anhlt baEuda wAnslt,) He withdrew himself privately, or stole away, without being known to do so, running. (Ibn-El-Faraj, Ḳ.)

halotaI A certain plant; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) when it dries, it becomes red; and when it is eaten, and grows, it is called jamiymN: or, accord. to Az, a certain tree, growing like the Sil-iyaAn, except that its colour inclines to red: or, accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, as AḤn says, a plant of the kind called Tariyfap, growing like the Sl-yAn and the naSiI-, red when fresh and moist, and more red when it has dried: it is watery; and the camels and sheep, &c. scarcely ever eat it when they find any other herbage to serve them in its stead. (TA.)

hulaAtapN The black filth that is washed away from the membrane which encloses a young lamb or kid in its mother's womb. (Ḳ, TA.) [For gusaAlapu Als-axolapi Als-awodaACi, as in the copies of the Ḳ in my hands, I read AlswdACu.]
[See also hulaAbapN.]

halotaAtN [accord. to the TA and a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ: in the CK hulotaAtN:] A company of people staying, or abiding, in a place; and of people journeying. (Ḳ.) So accord. to AZ; but accord. to ISk, with v. (L.)
halovaI An assembly, a company, or congregated body, of men. (IAạr.) [Or perhaps it is halovFI.]

Also, and halovaMCN↓ [or perhaps halovaMCu] and hilovaMCN↓ and halovaMCapN↓ and hilovaMCapN↓ and hulovapN↓ An assembly, a company, or a congregated body, (composed of a great number of men, TA,) whose voices are raised high. (Ḳ.) [That hilovaAC is with tenween is expressly shown by Fr.: but whether halovaAC is so is doubtful.]
Also hilovaOapN↓, with the second syll. short, An assembly, or a company, more in number than what is called waDomap. (Th.)
jaACato hilovaOapN↓ mino kul-i wajohK There came parties from every direction. (Th.)
hulovapN: see halovaI.
hilovaMCN: see halovaI.

hlvACN [app. halovaACN], coll. gen. n., n. un. with p {halovaACapN}, A kind of palm-tree, slender below, and thick at the head; the unripe dates of which are of a reddening yellow, disagreeable in taste; and its fresh ripe dates of the best, or sweetest, kind. (Aboo-Ḥátim, in Mṣb.)
See halovaI.
halovaMCapN and hilovaMCapN: see halovaI and hulaAvN.
hulaAvN and halovaACapN↓ and hilovaACapN↓ Flaccidness, or languor, (UisotiraxoAC,) that comes upon a man. (Ḳ.)
halaAYivu People of the lower, or lowest, class. (TA.)
huwa mino halaAYivihimo, mentioned, but not explained, by IAạr: thought by ISd to signify He is of the dregs of them: or, of their assembly, or company. (TA.)

UiholiylajN (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ) and UiholiylijN, (Fr, Sh, Ḳ,) but this is disapproved by IAạr, who observes that there are no words in Arabic of the measure UifoEiylilN, but there are of the measure UifoEiylalN, as UiholiylajN and UiboriysamN and UiToriyfalN, (Ṣ,) and haliylajN, (L,) but this is disallowed by ISk, (Ṣ,) [a coll. gen. n.,] n. un. with p, (Ḳ,) an arabicized word, (Ṣ,) from Ahlylh, (TA,) [or rather hliylaho, a Persian word,] A well-known fruit, [the fruit of the myrobalan, as well as the myrobalan-tree,] one kind of which is yellow, (Ḳ,) and another kind black, the latter being in the highest state of ripeness, and another kind called kaAbuliI-N: it is useful as a remedy for quinseys, and preserves the intel-lect, and removes the head-ache, (when used made into a conserve, TA,) and is, in the stomach, like an intelligent housewife, who is a good manager, in the house: (Ḳ, TA; but omitted in some copies of the Ḳ:) so is this medicine to the brain and stomach. (TA.) [See also biliylajN, in art. blj.]
hilojaAbN A large cooking-pot. (Ḳ.)
juwEN hil-aqobN Vehement hunger. (AA, T, L.) See also hil-aqotN.
juwEN hil-aqotN Vehement hunger. (Ḳ.) [See also hil-aqosN.]
1. hamaOa, aor. _a {yahomaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. hamoCN; (TA;) and AhmO↓; (Ḳ;) He rent, (Ḳ,) i. e., pulled so that it tore, (TA,) a garment: (Ḳ:) he wore out, or rendered threadbare, [and ragged]. (Ḳ.)
4: see 1.
5: see 7.
7. AnhmO (Ḳ) and thm-O↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) It (a garment) became rent: (TA:) became worn-out, or threadbare, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and ragged. (Ṣ.)
himoCN A worn-out, threadbare, or ragged, garment: pl. OahomaACN. (Ḳ.)
1. hmata, [aor. _u {yahomutu},] It (variyd) became hidden in the grease; (Ḳ;) became overspread by the grease. (TA.)
4. Ahmt AlkalaAma, and AlD-aHika, He made speech, and laughter, low; he spoke, and laughed, low. (Ḳ.) It is said to be from Alhamosu; the s being changed into t. (MF.)
1. hmj, [app. hamija, aor. _a {yahomaju},] inf. n. hamajN, He hungered; was hungry. (L.)
hamajati AlUibilu mina AlmaMCi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yahomuju}, inf. n. hamojN, (Ṣ,) The camels drank of the water at one draught, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) until they satisfied their thirst. (Ṣ.)
4. Ahmj, (inf. n. UihomaAjN, TA,) He (a horse, Ṣ, Ḳ, or other animal that runs, Lḥ,) strove or exerted himself, in his running, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and then ran impetuously, so as to raise the dust. (TA.)

hamajN Hunger: or (in the Ḳ, and) bad management of the means of subsistence. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) hamajN haAmijN↓ [Severe hunger: or very bad management of the means of subsistence:] (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the latter word is added to give intensiveness to the signification; (TA;) or to corroborate; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as in the case of layolN laAYilN. (Ṣ.)

hamajN Small flies, like gnats, that fall upon the faces of sheep or goats, and asses, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and into their eyes: (Ṣ:) or gnats; so called from hamajN signifying “hunger;” because when they are hungry they live, but when they become satiated they die: or SigaAr Ald-awaAb-i: (L: [but this is evidently a mistake for SigaAru Alc-ubaAbi the young ones, or little ones, of flies:]) or any grubs that burst forth from flies or from gnats: (Lth, A:) pl. of hamajapN, (Ṣ,) [or rather this is the n. un. of hamajN, which is a coll. gen. n.].
hamajN Lean sheep or goats: (Ḳ:) [a coll. gen. n.,] n. un. with p {hamajapN}. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hamajN ‡ Stupid, or foolish, men; or men of little sense: (Ḳ:) or stupid, or foolish, young men of the meaner sort: (Ṣ:) or simply young men of the meaner sort: or mixed and low set of men: or disorderly vagabonds: (TA:) you say also rajulN hamajN and hamajapN a stupid, or foolish, man; and rijaAlN hamajN, and OahomaAjN: (TA:) or hamajapN signifies a stupid, or foolish, man, who has not firm command of himself. (Aboo-Saʼeed.)
hamajN Old and weak ewes: (Ḳ:) [a coll. gen. n.,] n. un. with p {hamajapN}: which also signifies simply a ewe. (TA.)
qawomN hamajN A people in whom is no good. (TA.)
hamajN haAmijN↓ Young men of the meaner sort; like hamajN alone: and a mixed set of men who have no intelligence nor manliness. (TA.)

hamiyjN A doe-antelope scared, or frightened, by [the small flies called] hamajN: (Ṣ:) a young doe-antelope, (Ḳ,) of beautiful body: (L:) one lank in the belly: or one that has two streaks of a colour different from that of the rest of the body in [the two parts called] the Tur-ataAni: (Ḳ:) or one that has two such streaks on her back; which is only the case in such as are white; and also applied to the male: (TA:) or one that has been attacked by a pain in consequence of which her face has become flabby. (Ḳ.)
haAmijN: see hamajN.
‡ [A people] left to mix tumultuously, one part with another. (Ḳ.) [The explanation seems to be borrowed from the Ḳur, xviii. 99.]

1. hamadati Aln-aAru, aor. _u {yahomudu}, (Ṣ, A, L,) inf. n. humuwdN, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) The fire became extinguished (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) entirely; went out entirely, (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, L,) none of it remaining: (L:) or lost its heat: (L, Ḳ:) when [only] its flame has ceased, you say of it xamadat. (Aṣ, L.)
hamada, (M, A, L,) aor. _u {yahomudu}, (M, L,) inf. n. humuwdN, (M, L, Ḳ,) ‡ He died; [became extinct;] (M, A, L, Ḳ;) perished; (TA;) like as did Thamood; (Lth, A, L;) as also xamada. (A.)
kaAd yahamodu mina AljuwEi ‡ He nearly perished of hunger. (L.)

hamada, aor. _u {yahomudu}, (Ṣ, A, L,) inf. n. humuwdN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and hamodN, (L, Ḳ,) ‡ It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became dissundered (L, Ḳ) and worn-out, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb,) by being long folded, (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) so that a person looking at it would imagine it sound, but, when he touched it, would find it fall to pieces. (A,* L, Mṣb.*)
hamadat Alr-iyHu † The wind became still. (Mṣb.)
hamadati AlOaroDu, inf. n. humuwdN, ‡ The land became lifeless, without herbage, without wood, and without rain. (L, Ḳ.)
hamada Xajaru AlOaroDi ‡ The trees of the land became worn-out, or wasted; and perished. (L.)
hamadato OaSowaAtuhumo † Their voices became silent. (L.)

hom.sense: 4. Ahmd, inf. n. UihamaAdN, † He stilled, or quieted. (Ḳ.)
He (God, and a man,) killed, or destroyed, a man, or men. (A.)
Ahmd AlOamora ‡ He put an end to the affair. (A.)
Ahmd AlqaHoTu AlOaroDa ‡ Drought rendered the land sterile, so that it contained no herbage but such as was dried up and broken. (L.)
Ahmd, (inf. n. UihomaAdN, Ḳ.) † He kept silence in an unpleasant case. (L, Ḳ.)
Ahmd, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. UihomaAdN, (L, Ḳ,) He remained, continued, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) in a place: (Ṣ, L:) he was still; (Ḳ;) i. e., did not move. (TA.)
Ahmd, (Ṣ, L) inf. n. UihomaAdN, (L, Ḳ,) He hastened, or was quick, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) in going along: (Ṣ, L:) thus it bears two contr. significations: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) he (a dog) ran; syn. OaHoDara. (L.)
AhmdwA fiI AlT-aEaAmi, (inf. n. UihomaAdN, Ḳ,) They fell to eating of the food. (Ibn-Buzurj, L, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: hamidN: see haAmidN.
hamodapN † Apoplexy: caros: syn. sakotapN. (Ṣ, L.)
[A trance. (See raqodapN.)]

hmiydN ‡ Sheep or goats that have died: (L:) or the beasts or the like (mAl) that are registered in the government-accounts as due from a man. (ISh, L, Ḳ.) You say, MxacanaA biAlohamiydi He (the collector) exacted from us taking for the sheep or goats that had died: (L:) or, taking what was registered as due from us in the governmentaccounts. (ISh, L.)
See haAmidN.
haAmidN and hamidN↓ and hamiydN↓ ‡ [In a state of death, or extinction]. (M, L.)
haAmidN ‡ A garment, or piece of cloth, [dissundered and] wornout by being long folded, so as, when touched, to fall to pieces: (A:) or anything old and wornout: (L, Mṣb:) pl. hum-adN. (A.) See 1.

OaroDN haAmidapN ‡ Land in which is no herbage: (Ṣ:) and in the same sense haAmidN is applied to a place: (Ḳ:) or sterile land, (A, L,) the herbage of which is dried up and broken, (A,) or containing no herbage except what is dried up and broken: (L:) dry and dusty: pl. hawaAmidu. (L.)
haAmidN ‡ Old and worn-out or wasted, blackened, and changed, [for the worse]. (Ḳ.)
‡ A tree black and wasted: (L:) or dried up; (A;) as also herbage. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
‡ Fruit black and stinking. (A, L.)
‡ A date just ripe, thickskinned and yellow. (TA.) ramaAdN haAmidN Ashes [in a state of extinction or] wasted, (L,) and compacted together, and changed in appearance. (A, L.)
hamaAciI-N, (Ṣ, L,) or humaAciI-N, (L, in all its senses,) Quickness (L, Ḳ) in running: (L:) or exertion, or haste, in pace, or in going. (Sh, L.)

Violence, of rain: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) and [so in the L: in the TA, as some say,] violent occasions of rain, and of mutual reviling, and of running; which are sometimes violent, and at other times remit: (L:) and violence of heat; (IAạr, L, Ḳ;) as also HumaAciI-N. (IAạr, L.) You say, yawomN cuwhumaAciI-K, and HumaAciI-K, A day of violent heat. (IAạr, L.)
Quick, or swift; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) applied to a she-camel, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and to a he-camel, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L.)

hom.sense: 1. hamarahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yahomuru} (Ṣ, Ḳ) and _i {yahomiru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. hamorN, (Ṣ,) He, or it, poured it; out or forth; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) namely, water, (Ṣ, TA,) and tears, and rain, and the like. (TA.)
hamara maA fiI AlD-aroEi He drew forth all the milk that was in the udder. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hamara lahu mino maAlihi † He gave to him of his property. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hamara AlkalaAma, (Ḳ,) or fI kalaAmihi, (A,) aor. _u {yahomuru}, inf. n. hamorN: (TA;) and Uinohamara↓ biAlkalaAmi; (Ṣ;) ‡ He talked much. (Ḳ.)
hamara, intrans.: see 7. in two places.

entry.sense: 7. Anhmr It poured; poured out or forth; (Ḳ;) said of rain, and of tears; (TA;) as also hamara↓, (Ḳ,) aor. _i {yahomiru}, inf. n. humuwrN; (TA;) [and so, app., Ahtmr↓, q. v.:] it flowed; said of water, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of rain, and of tears; like Anhml: (TA:) and in like manner, hamarato↓ Eayonuhu biAld-amoEi His eye flowed with tears; as also hamalato. (A.)
Anhmr bAlklAm: see 1.
8. Ahtmr: see 7.
‡ He (a horse) ran (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) like a torrent. (TA.)
hamorapN A fall of rain. (Ḳ.)
‡ Angry speech. (Ṣgh, L, Ḳ.)
hamaraI: see ham-aArN.
ham-aArN A cloud pouring forth much rain; as also haAmirN↓. (Ḳ.)

Applied to a man, (Ṣ,) ‡ Loquacious, garrulous; babbling; a great talker; a babbler; or nonsensical, irrational, foolish, or delirious, in his talk; as also mihomarN↓ and mihomaArN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and yahomuwrN↓. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) And xaTiybN↓ mihomarN ‡ An orator copious in speech. (A, TA) And hamaraI↓, applied to a woman, ‡ Clamorous; (Ḳ, TA:) abounding in talk or speech, like a pouring torrent. (TA.)
haAmirN Pouring rain, and tears; as also munohamirN↓. (TA.) See also ham-aArN.
mihomarN: see ham-aArN, in two places.
mihomaArN: see ham-aArN.
munohamirN: see haAmirN.

hom.sense: yahomuwrN: see hamirN:
and see also ham-aArN.

entry.sense: Q. 1. hamoraja Ealayohi Alxabara, (inf. n. hamorajapN, L, Ḳ,) He rendered the news, tidings, or information, confused to him. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*)

hamorajapN Confusion; (Ḳ, L;) as also hamorajN, and hamar-ajN↓, and hamar-ajapN: ex. of the last waqaEa Alqawomu fiI hamar-ajapK The people fell into a state of confusion: (L:) and the third (L) and fourth (TA) signify also civil war, or conflict and faction, or discord, or dissension; syn. fitonapN. (L, TA.)
A confused manner, or state, in walking. (Ṣ.)
A confused noise, or mixture of voices, or unintelligible sounds, of men; as also humorujaAnN↓. (Ḳ.)
Lightness, or agility, and quickness. (Ḳ.)
What is rain, or false; syn. baATilN. (Ḳ.)
Alguwlu hamorajapN mina Aljin-i The Ghool are a mixture of the Jinn. (L.)
hamar-ajN: see hamorajapN.
Penetrating (maADK) in affairs. (Ḳ.)
humorujaAnN: see hamorajapN.

hom.sense: 1. hamazahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yahomizu} (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yahomuzu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. hamozN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He pressed it; squeezed it; pinched it; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as, for instance, a walnut, (A, TA,) or other thing, (Ṣ, TA,) in the hand; (Ṣ, A, TA,) and a man's head; (Ṣ, A, TA;) and a spearshaft, with the mahaAmiz, to straighten it. (TA.)

He pushed, impelled, or repelled, him or it, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) meaning anything; as also lamazahu, &c. (TA.)
You say, hamazatohu Uilayohi AlHaAjapu Want impelled, or drove, him to him or it. (TA.)
He struck, or beat, him; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also lamazahu, &c. (TA.)
He goaded, or spurred, him; (Ḳ, TA;) he urged him on (namely a horse) with the mihomaAz, to make him run. (Mṣb.)
He bit him. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
He broke it. (Ḳ.)

‡ He (the devil) suggested evil to his mind. (JK, A, TA.) You say, OaEuwcu biQll-ehi mino hamozihi; and mino hamazaAti AlX-ayaATiyni; ‡ I seek refuge in God from his [the devil's] evil suggestion; and from the evil suggestions of the devils. (A.)

‡ He blamed, upbraided, or reproached, him; he found fault with him; syn. of the inf. n. EayobN, (Fr, in TA, art. lmz; and IAạr, in TA, in the present art.) as also lamozN: (Fr, in TA, art. lmz; and Ṣ,) or he spoke evil of him, or spoke of him in a manner that he disliked, mentioning vices or faults as chargeable to him, behind his back, though it might be with truth; syn. UigotaAbahu fiI gayobatihi: (Mṣb:) and [so] hamazahu fiI qafaAhu he backbit him. (JK, A.)

hamaza AlHarofa, (Ṣ, O,) or Alkalimapa, aor. _i {yahomizu}, inf. n. hamozN, (Mṣb,) [He pronounced the word with the sound termed hamoz, or hamozap, of which the sign is C,] is from hamazahu in the first of the senses explained above; (Ṣ, Mṣb,) because what is termed hamoz in speech, (Ṣ,) or hamozap, (Kh, TA,) [i. e. the sound so called,] is [as it were] pressed, or squeezed, (Kh, Ṣ, TA,) from its place of utterance [by a sudden emission of the voice forced out after a compression of the passage whereby it has been stopped]. (Kh, TA.) It was said to an Arab of the desert, Oatahomizu AlfaOorapa, [meaning Dost thou pronounce AlfaOorap with hemz, or hemzeh?] and he said, [understanding the words to mean dost thou squeeze the rat, or mouse?] Als-in-aworu yahomizuhaA [The cat squeezes it]. (Ṣ.) See hamozN, below. [And see also nabara.]

entry.sense: Anhmz AlHarofu [The word was pronounced with the sound termed hamoz, or hamozap]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: hamozN, (Ṣ,) and hamozapN, (Kh, TA,) [the former a gen. n., and the latter the n. un.,] The sister of alif; one of the letters of the alphabet; [written thus;] a genuine word, old, heard [from the Arabs of classical times], and well known; so called for a reason mentioned above: see 1, last signification: so says Kh; therefore no regard is due to what is said in certain of the expositions of the Keshsháf, that the term hmzp thus used has not been heard [from any of the Arabs of classical times], and that its name is OalofN: (TA:) several persons say, that the term hmzp is mostly applied to the movent [alif], and Alf to the quiscent letter. (MF, TA.) See the letter A.

sense.ref: n. un. of hamozN, q. v.

entry.sense: hamazaAtu AlX-ayaATiyni ‡ The vain suggestions of the devils, which they inspire into the mind of a man. (Ṣ, TA.) See also 1; and see hamozN.

humazapN i. q. gam-aAzN; (Ḳ;) i. e., (TA,) One who blames, upbraids, reproaches, or finds fault with, others, much, or habitually; (Ṣ, TA;) as also ham-aAzN↓ (Ṣ, TA) and haAmizN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so lumazapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. lmz:) [or rather] the first and second are intensive epithets (TA) [but the third is not intensive]: or one who backbites his brother; as also ham-aAzN↓: (Lth, A, TA:) or one who defames men (yaxolufuhumo mino waraAYihimo wabaOokulu luHuwmahumo); and the action thus signified is like giybapN, and may be [by making signs] with the side of the mouth, and with the eye, and with the head; as also ham-aAzN↓: (TA:) or, conjointly with lumazapN, one who speaks evil of men, or backbites them, and defames them: (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, TA:) or both together, one who goes about much, or habitually, with calumny, or slander, separating companions and exciting enmity between friends: (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, TA:) humazapN is applied to a man and to a woman; (Ṣ, TA;) [like lamuzapN;] for its p is to denote intensiveness, and not the fem. gender: (TA:) hum-aAzN↓ [which is the pl. of haAmizN] signifies persons who blame, upbraid, reproach, or find fault with, others behind their backs, much, or habitually: (IAạr, TA:) [or, more correctly, it has not an intensive signification.] See also lumazapN.
ham-aAzN: see humazapN, throughout.
haAmizN: see humazapN, throughout.
mihomazN: see mihomaAzN.

mihomazapN An instrument for beating, (maqoraEapN, AHeyth, Ḳ, TA,) of copper or brass, [app. meaning a kind of spur, or a goad,] with which beasts of carriage are urged on: pl. mahaAmizu: (AHeyth, TA:) or a staff or stick: (Ḳ:) or a staff, or stick, with an iron in its head, with which the ass is goaded, or urged on. (Sh, Ḳ.) See also mihomaAzN.
[The pl., mahaAmizu, of this word or of mihomazN, is also applied to An instrument, or instruments, with which spear-shafts are pinched and straightened: see 1, first signification.]

mihomaAzN and mihomazN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) A well-known thing; (Mṣb;) [namely, a spur;] an iron which is [attached or fixed] in the kinder part of the boot of him who breaks, or trains, beasts of carriage: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. [of the former] mahaAmiyzu (Ḳ) and [of the latter] mahaAmizu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also mihomazap.

hom.sense: 1. hamas, aor. _i {yahomisu}, (A, TA,) inf. n. hamos (AHeyth, L, TA) and hamiysN and humuwsN, (L, TA,) He spoke inaudibly: (AHeyth, TA:) or in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner, (AHeyth, TA,) so as to be hardly intelligible. (TA.) It is said in a trad. fajaEala baEoDunaA yahomisu UilaI baEoDK And some of us began to speak to others in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner, so as to be hardly intelligible. (TA.) And in another trad., kaAna caA UiSal-aI AlEaSora hamasa biXaIoCK laA nafohamuhu He used, when he performed the afternoon-prayer, to utter something in a low, faint, gentle, or soft manner, we not understanding it. (TA.) You say also, hamasa UilaI-a biHadiyvihi [He uttered his discourse to me inaudibly: or in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner.] (A.) And AlX-ayoTaAnu yahomisu biwasowasatihi Sadora AlUinosaAni [The devil speaks inaudibly in his suggesting vain or unprofitable things into the bosom of man]. (A.) And hamasa AlX-ayoTaAnu fiI AlS-adori The devil suggested vain, or unprofitable things in the bosom; syn. wasowasa. (TA.) See also hamosN below.

Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He made the faintest, or slightest, sound in treading. So in the saying, Uihomiso waSaho and hamosFA waSaho Make thou the faintest, or slightest, sound in treading, and be thou silent: addressed by a thief to his companion. (TA.) And hence the saying of the Rájiz,
fahun-a yamoXiyna bihi hamiysaA
And they walk with him making the faintest, or slightest, sound in treading. (Ṣ.) hamiysN also signifies The walking softly; with a soft-sounding tread: (TA:) [and so hamosN; as in the saying,] samiEotu hamosa AlOaxofaAfi waAlOaqodaAmi [I heard the soft-sounding treading of the feet of camels and of the feet of men]. (A.) See also hamosN below.

hamasa AlS-awota, aor. _i {yahomisu}, inf. n. hamosN, He made the sound, or voice to be low, faint, gentle, or soft. (Mṣb.) And hamasa AlkalaAma, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, [He spoke in a low, faint, gentle, or soft manner; like hamasa alone; lit.,] he made speech, or the speech to be low, faint, gentle, or soft. (A, TA.)

hamasa AlT-aEaAma, (TḲ), [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (AZ, Ḳ,) He chewed the food with the mouth closed: (AZ, Ḳ, TA:) or without opening the mouth. (TA.) You say, huwa yaOokulu hamosFA He eats without opening his mouth. (A.) Hence, a toothless old woman's eating is termed hamosN. (AHeyth.) hamasahu also signifies [simply] He chewed it. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. hAmshu, inf. n. muhaAmasapN, He spoke, or discoursed secretly to him, or with him. (A.) You say also, haAmasuwA, (TḲ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) They spoke, or discoursed, secretly together; as also thAmswA↓. (Ḳ,* TḲ.)
6: see 3.

hamosN A low, faint, gentle, or soft, sound. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) So it has been explained as occurring in the words of the Ḳur, [xx. 107,] falaA tasomaEu Uil-aA hamosFA [So that thou shalt not hear aught save] a low, faint, gentle, or soft, sound, arising from the shifting of the feet from place to place towards the scene of congregation [for the general judgment]: or, as Az thinks, the meaning here is, the sound of the patting, or pattering, of the feet (xafoqa AlOaqodaAmi) upon the ground. (TA.)
The faint, or gentle, sound of the voice in the mouth, of such kind as has no mixture of the voice of the chest, nor loudness of utterance. (Lth, Ḳ.) See also mahomuwsN.

And Anything low, faint, gentle, or soft, (kul-u xafiI-K, Ḳ, TA,) of speech and the like: (TA:) [see again, mahomuwsN:] or the faintest, or slightest, sound of the feet; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., of their tread upon the ground: (TA:) so [accord. to J] in the instance in the Ḳur, [xx. 107,] mentioned above: (Ṣ:) and [in like manner] hamiysN↓ signifies the sound of the shifting from place to place of the feet of camels. (Ḳ.) See also 1.
hamiysN: see 1: and see hamosN.
kalaAmN mahomuwsN [Speech spoken inaudibly: or in a low, faint, gentle, or soft manner, so as to be hardly intelligible: see 1: or] speech not spoken out or openly. (A,* Mṣb.)

HarofN mahomuwsN, (Mṣb,) or Harofu Alhamosi, (IJ,) [A letter which is pronounced with the breath only, without the voice; a non-vocal letter;] a sound with which the breath passes forth, not from the voice of the chest, but passing forth gently; (IJ;) contr. of majohuwrN: (Mṣb:) AlHuruwfu Almahomuwsapu are the letters (ten in number, Ṣ,) which are comprised in the saying Hav-ahu XaxoSN fasakato: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) so called [accord. to some] because the stress is made weak in the place where any one of them occurs until the breath has passed forth with it. (Sb, Ṣ.)

Q. 1. hamolaja, (L, Mṣb,) inf. n. hamolajapN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, &c.,) He (a hackney, or pacing horse, birocawon, Ṣ, L, &c., i. e. a rahawaAn, TA,) went an easy and quick pace; (Mṣb;) he (a hackney, or pacing horse, or a beast,) went a good and quick pace; he went at a good and quick and graceful pace; (L;) he (a beast of carriage) went a good pace. (Abridgment of the ʼEyn.) See naSaba Als-ayora.
hamolajapN, as a simple subst., [An easy and quick, or good and quick, or good and quick and graceful, or good, pace of a hackney, or pacing horse, or beast of carriage:] pl. hamaAliju. (L.)

himolaAjN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) used as the act. part. n. of hamolaja, (Abridgment of the ʼEyn,) whence it would seem that the regular form of the act. part. n., muhamolijN, has not been used, (Mṣb,) an epithet applied to a hackney, or pacing horse, birocawon, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) or a beast of carriage, (L,) both to the male and female, (L, Mṣb,) Going, or that goes, an easy and quick pace; (Mṣb;) a good and quick pace; a good and quick and graceful pace; (L;) a good pace: (Abridgment of the ʼEyn:) syn. muhamolijN: (Ḳ: in the CK muhamolajN:) a man's beast for riding: (L:) pl. hamaAliyju: (Ṣ:) a Persian word, arabicized: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) [but I have not found its original in a Persian lexicon].
XaApN himolaAjN A sheep in which is no marrow, by reason of its leanness. (Ḳ.)
OamorN muhamolajN An affair rendered manageable, or easy. (L, Ḳ.)
An affair proved by experience. (L.)

hom.sense: 1. hanuWa, aor. _u {yahonuOu}, inf. n. hanaMCapN; and haniYa, aor. _a {yahonaOu}; It came, or happened, without inconvenience, or trouble: (Ḳ:) [it was pleasant, or productive of enjoyment: see what immediately follows].

hanuWa AlT-aEaAmu (Ṣ, Ḳ *) aor. _u {yahonuOu}, inf. n. hanaMCapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hanaOapN and hanoCN, (Ḳ,) or hinoCN (as in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the L); epithet haniIoCN; (Ṣ;) and haniYa, (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yahonaOu}, inf. n. hanoCN; (TA;) and hanaOa, aor. _i {yahoniOu}, (Lth,) The food was, or became, pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to the eater: or easy to swallow; not attended by trouble: [agreeable:] or not succeeded by harm, even after digestion. (Z, cited voce maruWa.)

hanaOaniI AlT-aEaAmu, (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ), and hanaOa liIa, aor. _i {yahoniOu} and _a {yahonaOu} (Ṣ, Ḳ) and _u, (Ḳ,) unexampled, says Akh, in the class termed mahmooz, (Ṣ,) [though baraOa and qaraOa are similar with respect to their having damm to the aor.,] inf. n. hanoCN and hinoCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [The food was pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to me: or easy to swallow;, &c.: see hanuWa].
hanaOaniI AlT-EAmu wamarOaniI: see art. mrO.
hanaOahu celika, and hnO lahu clk That (thing) was pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to him;, &c. (TA.) [See hanuWa.]
hanaOaniI xabaru fulaAnK The news of such a one was pleasant to me to hear. (TA.)

haniYa AlT-EaAma, aor. _a {yahonaOu}; and thn-O↓ baAlT-EAmi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and thn-O AlT-EAm, and AsthnOhu, (TA,) [He enjoyed the food; found it pleasant, or productive of enjoyment;, &c.: see hanuWa:] he found the food to be productive of no evil result, and not attended by inconvenience. (TA.)
haniYa, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yahonaOu}, inf. n. hanaON and hanoCN, (Ḳ,) He (a beast) lighted upon a good piece of herbage, but did not satiate himself therewith. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OakalonaA hecaA AlT-aEaAma Hat-aI haniYonaA minohu We ate this food until we were satiated with it. (TA.)
haniYati AlUibilu The camels were satiated with herbage. (TA.)
haniYa bihi He rejoiced in him, or it. (Ḳ.)
hanaOanaA Qll-ehu AlT-aEaAma [God made the food pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to us:, &c.: made us to enjoy it: see hanuWa]. (TA.)
hanaOatoniyhi AlEaAfiyapu [Health made it pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to me:, &c.]. (Ḳ.)

liyahoniYoka AlfaArisu [May the horseman give thee joy: a form of congratulation on the exploits of a horseman; i. e., I congratulate thee on the exploits of the horseman]: also written and pronounced liyahoniyka: lyhnk, though it occurs in a trad., pronounced liyahonika or liyahonaka, (but which pronunciation is to be preferred is disputed,) is said to be a vulgarism, and not allowable. (TA.)
hanaOahu, aor. _a {yahonaOu} (Ḳ) [and app., _i (see haAniYN)], inf. n. hanoCN, (TA,) He fed him; or gave him to eat. (Ḳ.)
hanaOahu, aor. _a {yahonaOu} and _i {yahoniOu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. hanoCN; (Ṣ;) and AhnOhu↓; (IAạr, Ḳ;) He gave him, or bestowed upon him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) gave him plentifully. (TA.)

hanaOa AlT-aEaAma, inf. n. hanoCN and hinoCN (Ḳ) and hanaMCapN (as in some copies of the Ḳ) or hanaOapN (as in others) or hinaOapN (as in others) or hanoOapN (as in the CK), He made the food good; qualified it properly; seasoned it: syn. OaSolaHahu. (Ḳ.)
hanaOa maAlahu, (TA,) and AhtnO↓ mAlh, (Ḳ,) He put his property in a right, or good, state. (Ḳ.)

hanaOa Alqawoma, aor. _a {yahonaOu}, He nourished, or maintained, the people; (Ṣ;) satisfied their wants; bestowed upon them. (TA.) Ex. hanaOahumo Xahorayoni [He maintained them two months]. Hence the proverb quoted in illustration of the word haAniYN, accord. to the second reading. (TA)
hanaOahu He aided, succoured, or defended, him. (Ḳ.)

hanaOa AlUibila, aor. _a {yahonaOu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and _i and _u, (Ḳ: dev. from constant rule as shown above: TA), inf. n. hanaON and hanoCN, (TA,) He smeared the camels with hinaMC, which is tar, or liquid pitch, syn. qaTiraAn, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a kind thereof, (TA,) [as a remedy for, or preservative against, the mange, or scab].

layosa AlhanoCu biAld-as-i The smearing of a camel [all over] with hinaMC is not [merely] smearing the cavities under the shoulders, and the like, which the mange, or scab, more quickly attacks. A proverb, applied to him who does not a thing thoroughly. (TA.)
See 2.

entry.sense: 2. han-aAhu waman-aAhu (in a trad. respecting the prostration for inattention) He (the devil) made him to think of pleasant things, or things productive of enjoyment, and of things wished for, or objects of desire, in his prayer. The former verb is pronounced thus to assimilate it to the latter. (TA.)

hn-Ohu biAlOamori, inf. n. tahoniYapN and tahoniIoCN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and hanaOahu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. hanoCN; (TA;) He congratulated him on the thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) such as the possession of a government, &c.: (Ṣ:) he said to him liyahoniYoka [May it give thee joy]. (Ḳ.)
[When the agent of the verb is God, the meaning necessarily is, He granted him enjoyment in the thing; made him to have enjoyment in it.]
hun-iYota walaA tunokaho: see art. nkO.
4: see 1.
5. thn-O He gave many gifts. (IAạr.)

thn-O bikacaA [unless it be a mistake for thy-O, as IbrD suggests, which I think not improbable, though mentioned in this art. in the TA] He prided himself in such a thing: syn. tmr-O and tgy-Z and tsm-n and txy-l and tzy-n. (TA.)
See 1.
8: see 1.
10. AsthnOhu He asked him for aid, succour, or defence. (Ḳ.)
He asked him for a gift. (Ḳ, TA.)
He conceded to him, or gave him, a part of his dues, or rights. (TA.)
See 1.

hom.sense: hinoCN A gift. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A part of the night. (Ḳ.)
hinoCN subst. from hanaOa AlUibila; (Ḳ;) i. e., The smearing with hinaMC. (MF.)

entry.sense: UibilN hanoOaI Camels which have lighted upon a good piece of herbage, but are not satiated therewith. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: hinaMCN Tar, or liquid pitch; syn. qaTiraAnN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a kind thereof. (TA.) See also nuwrapN; and qAlibN.
hinaMCN dial. var. of UihaAnN, (Ḳ,) or formed from the latter by transposition, (TA,) A raceme of a palm-tree. (AḤn, Ḳ.) [See UihaAnN.]

entry.sense: haniIoCN What comes or happens to one without inconvenience, or trouble: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [what is pleasant, or productive of enjoyment; an unalloyed gratification, i. e., a thing that gives unalloyed enjoyment; see what follows:] as also mahonaON↓, (Ḳ,) a subst., sometimes written and pronounced mahonaA; pl. mahaAniYu, sometimes written and pronounced mahaAnK. (TA.) [See mhnO also below.]
Pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to the eater: or easy to swallow; not attended by trouble: or not succeeded by harm, even after its digestion. (Z, cited voce maruWa.)
haniyoYFA mariyoYFA [May it be, or Eat it, or Drink it, with enjoyment, and with wholesome result: or with ease in the swallowing, and with quickness in digesting:, &c.: see maruWa]. (Ṣ.)
haniyoYFA lahu celika [May that be productive of enjoyment to him!]. (TA.)
haniyoYFA and mariyoYFA are of the number of epithets which are employed after the manner of inf. ns. significant of a prayer or good wish, governed in the acc. case by a verb understood. (Sb.)

hunayoYapN (Ḳ) and hunay-apN and hunayohapN (the second is the most usual; and the third is said to be formed by substituting h for C; but accord. to some, the word is incorrectly written with C, [so says F,] and is a dim. formed from hanowapN, which becomes first hunayowapN, and then hunay-apN: see art. hnw:) (TA:) A little; a little while. (Ḳ.)
haAniYN A servant. (Ḳ.)
haAniYFA occurs in this sense in a trad.; but the reading commonly known is maAhinFA. If right, it is an act. part. n. from hnO “he gave.” (TA.)

Uin-amaA sum-iyta haAniYFA litahoniYa, or litahonaOa; the former is the reading of El-Umawee; the latter, of Ks; Thou art only named Háni (Giver, or Nourisher,) that thou mayest give, accord. to both readings; or that thou mayest nourish, or maintain, and supply people's wants; ltEwl wtkfI: (TA:) [such is said to be the meaning of lthnO here:] and accord. to El-Umawee, lthnY signifies litumoriYa, (Ṣ,) [which is app. the same as ltEwl]. A proverb: said to him who is known for his beneficence, in order that he may continue to do as he has been wont. (TA.)
mahonaON: see haniYN.
laka AlmahonaOu, (Ṣ,) and AlmahonaA, (TA,) [Unalloyed gratification to thee!]

laka AlmahonaOu waEalayohi Alwizoru [To thee be unalloyed gratification, and on him be the burden, or sin]: said, accord. to a trad., to one who asked whether he should accept an invitation to eat the food of one who received unlawful interest or profit; and also said with respect to eating the food of a tyrannical intendant. (TA.)
mahonuwoCN A camel smeared with hinaAC. (Ṣ.)
hanabN [probably an inf. n., of which the verb is haniba, aor. _a {yahonabu},] Weakness of understanding; want of discrimination; stupidity; foolishness; littleness of sense. (Ṣ.)
hanabaI, &c.: see hun-abaACu.

hun-abaACu (incorrectly written by J, in a verse which he quotes, hanobaACu, Ḳ, TA; [but in an old and excellent copy of the Ṣ, I find the word written hanabACu;]) and hun-abaI (Ḳ) and hanabaACu and hanabaI↓ (IDrd, Ḳ) A woman of weak understanding; without discrimination; stupid; foolish; of little sense: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to some, as mentioned in a note by Aboo-Zekereeya, in the Ṣ, in this art., hunabaI signifies an insane woman; or one possessed by a jinnee. (TA.) hun-abaACu is the only word of the measure fuE-alaACu known to Az. (TA.) Accord. to the Ḳ, IDrd writes UimoraOapN hanabaACu and hanabaI: but this is [thought to be] a mistake: he gives the two forms hun-abaACu and hun-abaI, as stated by IM and others; and, app., hanabaI. (TA.)
The first and second of these three words also signify A man who is stupid, foolish, or of little sense. (Ḳ.)
mihonabN Exceedingly stupid, or foolish. (IAạr, Az, Ḳ.)
Q. 1. hanobata, inf. n. hanobatapN, He was languid and sluggish. (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ.) It may be said that the n is augmentative, and that the word is derived from habotapN, signifying “weakness.” (TA.)
Q. 1. hanotaba fiI Oamorihi He was remiss in his affair. (Ḳ.) See also hanobata.

hom.sense: 2. han-adatohu, inf. n. tahoniydN, She (a woman) behaved towards him in a blandishing manner: (IDrd, L:) she enamoured him by blandishment, (L, Ḳ,) and by amatory conversation or conduct: (L:) she enslaved him by amatory conversation, or conduct. (Ṣ, L.) [Thought by Golius to be derived from hinod, a proper name of a woman.]
hn-dt biqalobihi She deprived him of his heart. (Ibn-El-Mustaneer, L.)
hn-d, inf. n. tahoniydN, He made a sword of Indian iron. This is the original signification. (T, L.)
He sharpened a sword. (L, Ḳ.)

hinod a name for A hundred camels; (M, L, Ḳ;) as also hunayodapu↓; (T, Ṣ, M, A, L, Ḳ;) which latter is a determinate noun, imperfectly decl., not admitting the art. Al, [though it is written with it in the Ṣ, and in a verse cited in the Ṣ and L,] nor having a pl., nor a proper sing.: (T, L:) [see an ex. in a verse cited voce sarifa:] or the former is a name for more than a hundred camels and less: (Ḳ:) or a little more and a little less: (M, L:) or two hundred camels: (M, A, L, Ḳ:)
so accord. to Ez-Ziyádee, as mentioned by ISd, who adds that he had not heard it from any other than IJ: (L:) and the latter, a hundred of other things: (Ṣ, L:) or any hundred: (AO, Ṣ, L:) also the former, two hundred years: and the latter, [written with the art. Al,] a hundred years. (Th, ISd, L.)

Alhinodu The name of a well-known nation; (M, L, Ḳ;) or of a country: (Ṣ, L:) [the Indians: and India:] rel. n. hinodiI-N↓: pl. hunuwdN: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) and AlOahaAnidu signifies the men of Alhinod [or India]; as also AlhanaAdiku, (L, Ḳ,) pl. of hinodikiI-N [q. v. in art. hndk]. (L.)
See also OaHomasu.

entry.sense: hinodiI-N: see hinodN.
Also, Indian aloes-wood. (L.)

sayofN hinodiI-N, (L,) and hinoduwaAniI-N↓, [in the CK hinodawaAniI-N,] and hunoduwaAniI-N, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) A sword made in the country of Alhinod, [or India,] and well fabricated: (L:) or, made of the iron of that country: (A:) as also muhan-adN↓, in the latter sense, (Ṣ, A, L,) and in the former: (L:) so termed in relation to the people called Alhinod: (Ḳ:) and sayofN muhan-adN↓ a sharpened, or sharp, sword. (L.)
hinoduwaAniI-N and hunoduwaAniI-N: see hinodiI-N.
hunayodapu: see hinodN.
muhan-adN: see hinodiI-N.
hinodabN and hinodabaACN, &c.: see art. hdb.

hinodaAzN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with kesr, (Ḳ,) found in the work of Az, in several places, written with fet-ḥ, [hanodaAzN,] (TA,) A limit; syn. Had-N: (Ḳ:) [or rather a measure:] an arabicized word, from OanodaAzah, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with fet-ḥ, (Ḳ,) which is Persian: (Ṣ:) the arabicized word is with kesr to the first letter because of the rareness of the measure faEolaAlN in the cases of words not reduplicative. (Ḳ.) You say, OaEaTeAhu bilaA HisaAbi walaA hinodaAzK [He gave to him without calculation and without measure]. (Ṣ.)
hinodaAzapN The cubit with which [certain] cloths and the like are measured; [about twenty-five inches in length:] also a Persian word arabicized. (TA.)

muhanodzN One who determines the measures and proportions of subterranean channels for water, and of buildings: [an architect: and also a geometrician:] from hinodaAzN: but they change the z into s, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and say muhanodisN, (Ṣ,) because there is not in the [genuine] language of the Arabs a z with a d before it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hanodasapN [The art of determining the measures and proportions of subterranean channels for water: and hence, the art of architecture: and the practice, and science, of geometry:] a subst. from muhanodisN, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

muhanodisN One who determines the measures and proportions of subterranean channels for water: [and hence, an architect: and a geometrician:] derived from hinodaAzN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is Persian [in origin], (Ṣ,) arabicized from Mbo OanodaAzo; (Ḳ;) AndAz signifying “the act of measuring,” and Mb signifying “water;” (TA;) the z being changed into s because there is not in the [genuine] language of the Arabs a z after d. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hanoqabN, (Ḳ) by some written hinoqab-N, (TA,) Short: (Ḳ:) but it is not a word of established authority. (IDrd.)

hom.sense: 1. haMCa binafosihi UilI AlmaEaAliI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yahuwoCu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. hawoCN, (TA,) He raised his mind to high things, or objects; purposed, or aspired to, high things. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) The vulgar say, yahowiI binafosihi. (Ṣ.)
maA huWotu hawoCahu I did not know it, nor desire, or mean, [to do it; i. e., I did it not knowingly, nor intentionally]. (TA.)
huWotu bihi xayorFA, (Az, Ṣ, Ḳ) and Xar-FA, (Ḳ,) and HuWotuhu bixayorK, and biXar-K, (Lḥ,) inf. n. hawoCN, (TA,) I thought him to be possessed of good, (Az, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and, of evil. (Ḳ, TA.)
huWotuhu bimaAlK kaviyzK I thought him to be possessed of much wealth. (TA.)
Uin-iI laOahuWoCu bika Eano hecaA AlOamori Verily I exalt thee above this thing; [I hold thee above it]. (Lḥ.)
huWotu bihi I rejoiced in him, or it. (AA, Ḳ.)
hawiYa Uilayohi, aor. yahowaOu, He purposed, or intended, it. (Ḳ.)
haMCi and haMCa and haOo, in imperative senses, and the forms into which they are inflected, see below.

entry.sense: 3. hAwOhu He contended with him for superior glory: like haAwaAhu. (IAạr.) [See also art. hwI.]

hom.sense: haACi, with kesr, is syn. with haAti, Give; [or changed from this verb;] and is thus inflected: sing. masc. haMCi, fem. hAYiI; dual. masc. and fem. haAYiyaA; pl. masc. haAWuwA, fem. haAYiyna: (Ṣ, Ḳ: like haAti, haAtiI; haAtiyaA; haAtuwA, haAtiyna: C holding the place of t: Ṣ.)

But haMCa, with fet-ḥ, is syn. with haAka, Take; [or changed from this word;] and is thus inflected: sing. masc. haMCa, fem. haMCi, without I; dual masc. and fem. haAWumaA; pl. masc. haAWumu, [so in the Ḳ, and so I find it in one copy of the Ṣ: in another copy of the latter, haAWumu, as it is pronounced before a conjunctive A; for instance, in the Ḳur, lxix, 19:] fem. haAWun-a, (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or haAWumona: (L:) [which last does not exactly correspond with the model haAkun-a: but I think it most probable that haAkun-a is changed by idghám from haAkumona; and in like manner, that haAWun-a is changed from haAWumona:] (like haAka, haAki; haAkumaA; haAkumo, haAkun-a: _u holding the place of k: Ṣ:) also, sing. masc. haOo (originally haMCu, Ṣ), fem. haAYiI; dual masc. (Ṣ) and fem. (Ṣ, Ḳ) haAM; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) pl. masc. haAWuwA, (Ṣ,) fem. haOona: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) also, sing. masc. and fem. haOo; dual. masc. haAM, fem. haAYiyaA; pl. masc. haAWuwA, fem. haAWun-a. (TA.)
[See a saying of ʼOmar cited voce ramaMCN, in art. rmI.]

When it is said to thee haMCa Take, thou sayest maA OahaMCu What shall I take? syn. maA Mxucu; and maA OuhaMCu, in the pass. form, What shall I receive, or be given? syn. maA OuEoTaI. (Ṣ.) [Also, in the TA, it seems to be said that OahaMCa signifies OaEoTaI He gave, or made to take: but this is uncertain; as the former verb is there written AhACa, and the latter is without the syll. points].
haMCa is also syn. with lb-ayoka At thy service!, &c.. (Ḳ, TA.)

laA haMC Qll-ehi caA, or, more chastely, laA haA Qll-ehi caA, or the former is a barbarism; originally laA waQll-ehi hecaA: hA and cA are separated, and the name of God is introduced between them; (Ḳ;) and the meaning is No, by God, (I did not) this! (Ṣ, art. hA, q. v.) or No, by God, this (is what I swear by)! (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: hawoCN Mind; purpose; aspiration; desire; ambition. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) Ex. baEiycu AlhawoCi A person of far-reaching aspiration, or ambition. (Ṣ, TA.)
hawoCN Penetrating judgment. (Ḳ.)
waqaEa fI hawoYiI, and huwYiI↓, It occurred to my mind, or imagination. (Ḳ.)
huwoCN: See preceding sentence.
muhowaOan-N (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mahowaYin-N↓ (Ḳ) A wide desert, or wide tract of the kind called SaHoraMC. (Ṣ. Ḳ.)
Custom: syn. EaAdapN. (Ḳ.)
A part of the night. (Ḳ.)

The mention of mhwOn- in this art., by J, says IB, and F after him, is wrong; for its measure is mfwE-l; the w being an augmentative letter. [But if so, F has himself done wrong, in mentioning it, not only here, but also in art. hwn, (where, if the w be augmentative, it is equally inappropriate,) as though it were a quasi-quadriliteral-radical word, of the measure mfEAul-.] ISd gives it as formed by transposition from the root hnO, and explains it as signifying a wide place. (TA.)
muhowaYin-N: see muhowaOan-N.
1. huwba: see art. hyb.

hom.sense: hawobN Distance; remoteness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

tarakotuhu fiI hawobK daAbrK, and huwbK↓ daAbirK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or, accord. to some, as stated in a marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ, in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeya, fI hwbi dAbrK, with hwb as a prefixed n., (TA,) I left him in such a place that it was not known where he was: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) hwb dAyr being the name of a land over which the Jinn, or genii, have obtained ascendancy: (TA:) or the correct reading is [hwt] with t. (Ḳ.)
hawobN A stupid, or foolish, and loquacious, man: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. OahowaAbN. (TA.)
hawobN The heat, or burning, of fire; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and its flaming, or blazing; of the dial. of El-Yemen: also, the heat, or burning of the sun: also of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

entry.sense: huwbN: see hawobN.
mahuwbN: see art. hyb.
2. hw-t bihi, inf. n. tahowiytN, He called out to him; (Ḳ;) saying Hawota Hawota: (TA, art. Hyt:) he cried out to him, and called him. (Ṣ.) A dial. form of hy-t. (TA.) [See hay-ata.]
hawotapN: see what follows.

huwtapN (Ḳ) and hawotapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) A low, or depressed, tract, or piece, of land: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a deep place: (IAth:) or the space between two mountains: (IAạr:) pl. huwatN (as in the CK) or huwt (as in the TA.) It may be said that huwtN and huwatN are coll. gen. ns. [of each of which the n. un. is with p]. (TA.)
Also huwtapN A road, or way, descending to water. (IAạr.)

Sab-a Qll-ehu Ealayohi hawotapa↓ wamowatapF an imprecation, respecting which ISd says, I know not what is hwtp here. [It probably signifies A cry, such as destroyed the tribe of Thamood: see haw-ata.] (TA.)

maDaI hiytaACN mina All-ayoli A certain time, or portion, of the night passed. Accord. to Aboo-ʼAlee, hytAC is of the measure fiEolaACN, and quasicoordinate to sirodaAHN, and belonging to this art. (TA.)
hiytaAh hiytaAh A cry by which the Arabs urge on a dog against the game which they are pursuing. (TA.) [In the L written hayotaAC, and mentioned in art. hyt.]
tarakahumo hawovFA bawovFA He made a great slaughter among them. (TA.) [See art. bwv.]
hawovapN A thirst. (Ḳ.)

1. hawija, aor. _a {yahowaju}, inf. n. hawajN; (L;) and thw-j↓; (A, TA;) He (a man) was characterized by what is termed hawajN, (L, A,) which is similar to hawakN; (L;) i. e., stupidity, foolishness, or paucity of sense: (JK, L:) tallness, combined with hastiness, and stupidity or foolishness or paucity of sense: (Ṣ:) or tallness, with stupidity or foolishness or paucity of sense and levity or fickleness or unsteadiness, and hastiness: (Ḳ:) or tallness, with levity or fickleness or unsteadiness, and hastiness: (TA:) or tallness, (A,) or excessive tallness, (L,) with stupidity or foolishness or paucity of sense. (L.)
4. Ahwjhu He found him to be such a man as is termed Oahowaju. (L.)
5: see 1.
hawajN: see 1.
fI fulaAnK EawajN, and hawajN, are syn., [meaning In such a one is a deviation from rectitude]. (AA, L.)
haAjapN a dial. form of HaAjapN; but of weak authority. (L, from a trad.)

Oahowaju A man characterized by what is termed hawajN; (Ṣ, L, &c.;) stupid, foolish, or having little sense: (JK, L:) or tall, with hastiness, and stupidity or foolishness or paucity of sense,, &c.: (Ṣ, &c.:) fem. hawojaMCu: (A:) [pl. huwjN.]
Oahowaju AlT-uwli ‡ A man exceedingly, or excessively, tall. (A.)
Also Oahowaju ‡ A courageous man, who throws himself into a scene of war. (A.)

Oahowaju ‡ A he-camel that goes quickly, as though characterized by what is termed hawajN: fem. hawojaMCu: [pl. huwjN:] or the fem. epithet only is used, applied to a camel; and you say naAqapN hawojaMCu; (TA;) i. e., a she-camel that goes quickly, &c., as explained above; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and that does not always care where she puts her feet on the ground. (A.)

riyHN hawojaMCu ‡ Any wind that blows violently: (IAạr:) or a wind of which the blasts are closely consecutive, as though characterized by what is termed hawajN: or a wind that carries away the dust, and makes a trace upon the ground like that made by dragging the skirt: (TA:) or a wind that tears up the tents: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. huwjN. (Ṣ.)

1. haAda, aor. yahuwdu, (Ṣ, L, &c.,) inf. n. hawodN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, &c.,) He returned (IAạr, A, L, Mṣb) from evil to good or from good to evil: (IAạr, L:) he repented, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) and returned to the truth; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also thw-d↓: (L:) and the latter, he repented and did righteously. (AO, Ṣ, A, L.)

hudonaA Uilayoka We have turned unto Thee with repentance. [Ḳur, vii, 155.] So accord. to Mujáhid and Saʼeed Ibn-Jubeyr and Ibráheem. (L.) It is made trans. by means of AlI because implying the meaning of rajaEonaA. (ISd, L.)
haAda, (Ṣ, A, L,) aor. yahuwdu, inf. n. hawodN; (L;) and tahw-d↓; (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He became a Jew; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) he became of the Jewish religion. (L, Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 2. hw-duh, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tahowiydN, (Ṣ,) He made him (his son [for instance] Mṣb) a Jew; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb;) he turned him to the religion of the Jews; (L, Ḳ;) taught him that religion, and initiated him in it. (L.)
tahowiydN The talking together of jinn, or genii: (L, Ḳ:) so termed because of the gentleness and weakness of their voices. (L.)
hw-d, inf. n. tahowiydN, He reiterated his voice, or quavered, or trilled, gently. (Ibn-Jebeleh, L, Ḳ.)
hw-d, (L,) inf. n. tahowiydN, (Ḳ,) He sang; syn. gan-aI: (Aboo-Málik, L:) he sang, or gladdened, and diverted; syn. Tar-aba waOalohaI. (Ḳ.) See also muhaw-idN.

hw-d, inf. n. tahowiydN, He went, or proceeded, gently, or in a leisurely manner, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) like the manner termed dabiybN: from AlhawaAdapu. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., OasoriEuwA AlmaXoIa fiI AljanaAzapi walaA tuhaw-iduwA kamaA tuhaw-idu Alyahuwdu wAln-aSaAraI [Make ye your pace to be quick at a funeral, and go ye not in a gentle or leisurely manner like as go the Jews and the Christians]. (Ṣ.) See also 5.
hw-d, (L,) inf. n. tahowiydN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) It beverage, or wine, intoxicated (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) a person: and rendered him languid, and caused him to sleep. (L.)
hw-d, inf. n. tahowiydN and tahowaAdN; (L, Ḳ;) and thw-d↓; (TA;) He uttered a weak, gentle, (L, Ḳ,) and languid, (L,) voice. (L, Ḳ.)
hw-d He (a man) rested; or was still, quiet, or at rest. (Aboo-Málik, L.)
hw-d, inf. n. tahowiydN, He slept. (Ṣ, L.)
Also, The murmuring and gentle sounding of the wind over sand. (L.)
hw-d, inf. n. tahowiydN, He ate of a camel's hump; (Ḳ;) or what is termed hawadap. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. hAwdhu, (A,) inf. n. muhaAwadapN. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) He made peace with him; reconciled himself with him; (A;) syn. of the inf. n. muwaAdaEapN; (A, L;) in the Ḳ, muwaAEadapN, which is a mistake; (TA;) and muSaAlaHapN, (Ṣ, L,) and muhaAdanapN: (TA:) and also muraAjaEapN [app. signifying the restoring a person, or taking him back, into one's favour]. (TA.)
He inclined towards him reciprocally; syn. maAyalahu: and haAwadaA They two inclined each towards the other; syn. maAyalaA: (TḲ:) syn. of the inf. n. mumaAyalapN. (Ṣ, L.)
He returned to him, or it, time after time; syn. EaAwadahu: (TḲ:) syn. of the inf. n. muEaAwadapN. (Ḳ.)
5: see 1 and 2.
thw-d fiI maXoyihi He walked gently, imitating the motions of the Jews in their reciting or reading. (El-Basáïr.) See also 2.

thw-d He became allied, or allied himself, or sought to ally himself, (tawaS-ala, Ḳ, and taqar-aba, El-Basáïr,) by a bond of relationship; or by some other sacred or inviolable bond or tie, or a quality, &c. to be regarded as sacred or inviolable or rendering him entitled to respect or reverence. (Ḳ, El-Basáïr.) See also mutahaw-idN.
Alhuwdu: see yahuwdu.
hawodapN: see hawadapN.
hawadapN A camel's hump: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the base of the hump: (Sh, L:) as also hawodapN↓: (L:) pl. hawadN: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) [or rather, this is a coll. gen. n., and hawadapN is the n. un.].

hawaAdapN Gentleness; lenity; (A, L, Ḳ;) and that kind of conduct whereby one hopes to effect the adjustment of an affair between a people: (L, Ḳ:) quietness: (L:) peace, or reconciliation: inclination, or affection: (Ṣ, L:) favour, or partiality: (L:) facilitation, whereby a person is indulged in an affair. (L, Ḳ.) Ex. laA taOoxucuhu fiI Qll-ehi hawaAdapN Quietness with respect to a restrictive ordinance of God, with favour or partiality towards any one, will not affect him, or influence him. And laA taOoxucuhu fiyka hawaAdapN Favour or partiality with respect to thee will not affect him, or influence him. (L, each from a trad.)

hawaAdapN also signifies A sacred or inviolable bond or tie; or a quality, &c. to be regarded as sacred or inviolable, or rendering one entitled to respect or reverence: and a bond of relationship. (L.)
haAYidN Returning (Mṣb) [from evil to good or from good to evil: see 1:] repenting and returning to the truth: (Ṣ, L:) pl. huwdN, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb,) like as buzolN is pl. of baAzilN. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb.)

yahuwdu and Alyahuwdu and Alhuwdu↓ [the second of which is the most common,] signify the same, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) A certain tribe; [namely, the Jews:] (L:) yahuwdu is said by some to be originally yahuwcu, and arabicized by the change of c into d; but ISd disapproves of this assertion: others say, that it is from haAda “he repented:” (L:) it is imperfectly decl., because it is a proper name and of the measure of a verb; and [of the fem. gen., as it is said to be in the Ṣ and L,] because it means a qabiylap: but it is allowable to prefix to it the art. Al, and to say Alyahuwdu: (Mṣb:) this, however, is allowable only on the ground of its being, with the art. prefixed, for Alyahuwdiy-uwna; for it is of itself determinate: (Ṣ, L:) [thus] yahuwdu is [as it were] pl. of yahuwdiI-N↓; (L;) which is the rel. n. of yhwd, or, accord. to Ṣgh, of yahuwdaA [or Judah], thus written by him with the unpointed d in this instance, the son of yaEoquwb [or Jacob]: (Mṣb:) yahuwdu (sometimes, TA) has yahodaAnN as a pl.: (Ḳ:) this pl. occurs in a poem of Hassán: (TA:) Fr, says, of huwdFA, in the Ḳur, ii, 105, that it is for yahuwdFA [app. a mistake for yahuwda]; or that it may be pl. of haAYidN. (L.)
yahuwdiI-N: see yahuwdu.
Alyahuwdiy-apu The Jewish religion. (L.)
ginaMCN muhaw-idN [in some copies of the Ṣ, muhaw-adN,] A low, not loud, singing. (Ṣ, L.)
muhaw-idN also signifies Gladdening, and diverting; syn. muToribN and mulohK. (IAạr, L.)
mutahaw-idN Allied, or allying himself, or seeking to ally himself, (mutawaS-ilN, IAạr, Sh,) by what is termed hawaAdapN. (IAạr, Sh, L.) See 5.

Alhawocapu, (L, Ḳ,) or hawocapu, [without the art. Al, as a proper name,] (Ṣ, L,) written by Ed-Demeeree with damm, but fault has been found with him for this, (MF,) [The bird called] the qaTaAp: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or, as some say, the female qTAp: (L:) or hawocapu, (as a determinate noun) is the name of a certain bird, (L, Ḳ,) different from the above: (L:) pl. huwacN, (as in the CK and a MṢ copy of the Ḳ) or hawocN, formed by eliding the augmentative letter: (TA:) [and this seems to be the correct reading; for it occurs in a verse, cited in the TA, in which the measure required it to be of one syllable: it therefore appears that hawocN is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p {hawocapN}.]

1. haArah, (Ḳ,) [aor. yahuwruhu,] inf. n. haworN, (TA,) He threw it down; pulled it down; pulled it to pieces; or demolished it; namely, a building; (Ḳ;) and in like manner, a jurof [i. e. an abrupt, water-worn, bank, rising by the bed of a torrent or stream]; (TA [in which huWuwrN is given as an inf. n. of this verb; but it is more probably an inf. n. of the intrans. verb only, agreeably with analogy;]) as also hw-rhu↓, (Ṣ, A,) the pronoun relating to a building, (A,) and to a jurof; (Ṣ;) and hy-rhu [in illustration of which see what is said of thy-r, below]; (Ṣ, art. hyr;) and thw-rhu↓, in which the pronoun relates to the upper part of a jurof, or to the brink of a well. (TA.)

haAra Alqawoma, (Ḳ,) aor. yahuwruhumo, inf. n. haworN, (TA,) ‡ He slew the people, and threw them down prostrate, one upon another, (Ḳ,) like as when a jurof falls down. (TA.) And [in like manner you say,] Daraba fulaAnFA fahaArahu † He smote such a one and prostrated him; as also hw-rhu↓. (Ḳ,* TA.)

haAra, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yahuwru, inf. n. haworN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and huWuwrN, (Ṣ,) It became thrown down, pulled down, pulled to pieces, or demolished; or it fell in ruins, or to pieces; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) said of a building, (Ḳ,) and of a jurof [explained above]; (Ṣ, A;) as also AnhAr↓ and thw-r↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and thy-r, (Ḳ,) which last has I as being interchangeable with w, or it may be of the measure tafayoEala [originally tahayowara]: (TA:) or it fell; it fell, or tumbled, down; it collapsed; broke down; said of a building; (TA;) as also AnhAr↓ and thw-r↓; (Mṣb, TA;) said of a building, (TA,) and of a jurof, (Mṣb,) or of the upper part of the latter, and of the brink of a well; (TA;) [and Aihotawara↓, q. v., probably signifies the same:] or it cracked, without falling; said of a jurof: (Mṣb:) or it cracked in its hinder part, remaining yet in its place; said of a building. (TA.)
2. hw-rhu: see haArahu, in two places.

hom.sense: 5. thw-r: see haAra, in two places; in the former of which, thy-r is also mentioned as syn. with tahw-r.

‡ He plunged, or fell, into an affair with little care [for the consequence thereof]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or thw-r fiI AlOumuwri he plunged, or fell, into affairs without thought, or reflection, or consideration: (A:) or tahaw-urN is a state, or condition, adventitious to the irascible faculty, by reason of which one ventures upon affairs not fit, or meet, to be ventured upon; as the fighting with unbelievers when they are more than double the number of the Muslims. (KT.)
thw-rhu: see haArahu.

entry.sense: 7: see haAra, in two places.
8. Aihotawara: see haAra, last signification.
It (a thing, Ṣ) perished. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

haAYirN and haArK, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter formed by transposition from the former, [first into haAriIN, and then into haArK,] (Ṣ, TA,) like as XaAYiku Als-ilAHi is changed into XaAkiI Als-ilAHi, (Ṣ,) applied to a building, (Ḳ,) and to a jurof, [explained above, (see haArahu,)] (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) Becoming thrown down, pulled down, pulled to pieces, or demolished: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or falling; falling, or tumbling, down: (IAạr:) or cracking, without falling: (Mṣb:) or cracking in its hinder part, remaining yet in its place. (TA.) [See an ex. of the latter voce jaforN: and another in the Ḳur, ix. 110.]
mutahaw-irN A man plunging, or falling, or who plunges, or falls, into an affair with little care [for the consequences thereof]. (Ṣ.) See 5.
hawasN Somewhat of madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) in the head: (A:) or a vertigo, or giddiness, and confused noise, in the head. (A, TA.)
Hence used by the vulgar to signify Hope. (TA.)
mahaw-asN Affected with somewhat of madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
A man who talks to himself. (A.)
Sometimes, One who is affected with melancholy, and with vain, or unprofitable, suggestions. (TA.)
And One who occupies himself with the science of alchemy. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. haAXa, aor. yahuwXu, inf. n. hawoXN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) It (a company of men) was, or became, in a state of conflict and faction, sedition, discord, or dissension: (Mṣb:) he, or it, (a number of people,) fell into a bad state, or state of disorder or disturbance; as also hawiXa, like samiEa; [indicating that its aor. is _a, and its inf. n. as above;] and thw-X↓: (TA:) it (a company of men, Ṣ, A) was, or became, roused, or excited; (A, TA;) in a state of commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance; (Ṣ, A, TA;) and in like manner, haw-aXa↓, said of the belly, it was, or became, in a state of commotion, agitation,, &c., by reason of leanness: (Ṣ:) or hawiXa, like samiEa, [see above,] (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yahowaXu}, inf. n. hawoXN, (TḲ,) he (a man, TḲ) was, or became in a state of commotion, agitation,, &c.; or his belly became small, syn. Sagura, (Ḳ, TA, [or empty, (Sagura being perhaps a mistranscription for Safira, for it is said in another part of this art. in the TA that AlhawoXu signifies “the belly's being empty,”)]) by reason of leanness; from IF: (TA:) or it (the belly) became so. (IF, TA.)
