haAXati AlUibilu, (JK, TA,) or Alxayolu, (A,) fI AlgaArapi, (JK, A,) aor. tahuwXu, (JK,) inf. n. hawoXN, (JK, TA,) The camels, (JK, TA,) or the horses, (A,) took fright, and ran away at random, (JK, A, TA,) and became dispersed, (TA,) or separated themselves, (JK,) and went to and fro, (JK, A,) in the hostile sudden attack made by a party of armed horsemen. (JK, A, TA.)

haXotu UilaI fulaAnK I became agile or brisk, and advanced towards such a one. (TA.) And haAXa Oaholu AlHarobi baEoDuhumo libaEoDK The warriors became agile or brisk, and hastened, one to another; [in like manner] thAwXwA↓. (A.)

Also, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, He collected: and mixed, or confused, or confounded. (TA.) You say, huXotu maAlFA HaraAmFA I collected unlawful wealth. (Ṣgh, TA.) And haAXahumo and haw-aXahumo↓ He mixed, or confused, or confounded, them; and collected them hence and thence. (A.) See also 2.
2. hw-X: see 1, first sentence:
and see 5.

Also, haw-aXotuhumo I occasioned variance between them, or among them. (Mṣb.) And hw-X bayonahumo He created, or excited, disorder, disturbance, discord, or dissension, between them, or among them. (TA.)

And hence, (Mṣb,) hw-X, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tahowiyXN, (Ḳ,) He mixed, confused, or confounded, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) a company of men, (Ṣ, TA,) one with another; (TA;) and general rules; (Mṣb;) and anything. (Ṣ.) See also 1, last sentence: and see Xaw-aXa. [Hence also,] hw-Xt Alr-iyHu biAlt-uraAbi The wind brought the dust of various sorts [mixed together]. (Ṣ,* IF, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. haAwaXahumo He mixed, mingled, or consorted, with them: (Ḳ:) or did so to create, or excite, disorder, disturbance, discord, or dissension; or to make mischief: (TA:) and muhaAwaXapN signifies conflicting; like munaAwaXapN. (TA, art. nwX.)
5. thw-X: see 1, first sentence.
And thw-XwA Ealayohi They collected themselves together against him. (IF, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
6. thAwXwA: see 1, near the end:
and see 5.

hawoXN A large number: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as the women of Temeem say, a multitude of men; and of beasts of carriage; as also bawoXN: (Aboo-'Admán:) and men collected together in war. (TA.) You say, jaMCa biAlhawoXi AlhaAYiXi↓ He came with multitude, or the multitude; (Ḳ;) like as you say, jaMCa biAlbawoXi AlbaAYiXi. (TA.)

hawoXapN Conflict and faction, sedition, discord, or dissension: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) excitement: commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and confusion: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and huwaAXapN↓ is like hawoXapN; (TA;) or signifies war. (JK.) You say, waqaEato hawoXapN fiI Als-uwqi [Conflict and faction,, &c., happened in the market]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., Uiy-aAkumo wahawoXaAti All-ayoli wahawoXaAti AlOasowaAqi (Ṣ, TA) Beware ye of the misfortunes, calamities, or evil accidents, of night; and of the wrong courses, and trickery and robbery, of the markets. (TA.) hawaXaAtu Als-uwqi, thus related by Th, but not explained by him, is thought by ISd to mean The confusion of the market, and the defrauding there practised in buying and selling. (TA.) See also hayoXapN in two places.

hom.sense: huwaAXapN A mixed, or confused, assembly, company, or assemblage, of men; ('Arrám;) as also hawiyXapN↓: (Ḳ,* TA:) and huwaAXaAtN, [the pl. of the former,] collections of men, and of camels, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) mixed, or confounded, together: (Ṣ:) and what is collected of unlawful wealth or property; (Ḳ,* TA;) and of lawful. (TA.) See also mahaAwiXu.
See also hawoXapN.

entry.sense: hawiyXapN: see hawaAXapN.

haw-aAXN and haw-aAXapN Camels unlawfully collected: (JK:) or the latter, camels taken from this and that place: (TA:) and the latter also, camels taking fright and running away at random. (JK.) See also haAYiXN.

hom.sense: haAYiXN: see hawoXN.

UibilN hawaAYiXu, [pl. of haAYiXapN,] Camels taking fright and running away at random, in a state of confusion, attacked by a party of armed horsemen: (Lth:) or taking fright and running away at random, (JK, A,) separating themselves, (JK,) and going to and fro. (JK, A.) See also haw-aAXN.
haAYiXapN A great viper. (TA.)

entry.sense: tahowaAXN: see mahaAwiXu.
tahowiyXN: see mahaAwiXu.
tahaAwuXN and tahaAwiXN: see mahaAwiXu.
mahuwXN: see mahaAwiXu.

mahaAwiXu What is gotten by force or theft: (Ḳ:) or any wealth, or property, (Ṣ,) that is gotten by unlawful means, (JK, Ṣ,) such as force and theft and the like: (Ṣ:) pl. of mahuwXN↓: (A:) or as though pl. of this latter word, as signifying collected; and mixed, confused, or confounded. (TA.)
It is said in a trad., mano OaSaAba maAlFA mino mahaAwiXa Oacohabahu Qll-ehu fiI nahaAbira [Whoso getteth wealth, or property, of such as is unlawfully acquired, God will make it to pass away in places of destruction]: (Ṣ:) but this is variously related; some saying tahaAwiXa↓; and some, tahaAwuXK; and some, nahaAwiXa, with n, which is explained in the Ḳ as signifying maZaAlim: the relation given in the Ṣ is that which is commonly known by the lexicologists; but all are correct, excepting that tahaAwiX, with t, and with a kesreh to the w, is disapproved by some of the lexicologists: (TA:) this last word is a contraction of tahaAwiyXu, pl. of tahowaAXN↓, of the measure tafoEaAlN from AlhawoXu, (Ḳ, TA,) meaning “the collecting”; and “mixing,” “confusing,” or “confounding”: (TA:) or from huXotu maAlFA HaraAmFA. (Ṣgh, TA.) A poet says,
taOokulu maAjamaEota mino tahowaAXi
[Thou eatest what thou hast collected of things unlawfully acquired]. (Ṣgh, TA.)

1. haMCa, aor. yahaMCu and yahiyoCu, (Ḳ; the latter not of respectable authority, Lḥ;) inf. n. hayoYapN, He was, or became, of good, or goodly, form or appearance, or other properties denoted by the term hayoYap, q. v. (Ḳ.)
[hayuWa, accord. to the Ḳ, signifies the same: but see below.]

hayuWa, accord. to IHsh and others, the only verb of this form whose medial radical letter is I: (MF:) accord. to the Ḳ, syn. with haMCa, in a sense indicated above: but IJ states that it has a superlative sense; that it is to be classed with qaDuwa “excellent [or how excellent (see baTuWa voce buTaMna)] is he in his judging!” and ramuwa “excellent [or how excellent] is he in his throwing, or shooting!” [wherefore it signifies Excellent, or how excellent, is he in his form or appearance!, &c.;] and that it is, like qaDuwa [and ramuwa], invariable [as to person, tense, and mood]. He observes that, as a verb of the measure faEula is formed from one whose final radical letter is I, [as qaDuwa and ramuwa from qaDaI and ramaI,] so is this formed on the same measure from a verb whose medial radical letter is I: and that it is invariable [as to person, tense, and mood,] because of its resemblance, in its superlative sense, to the class of verbs of wonder, and to niEoma and biYosa. He further remarks, that they [the Arabs] have abstained from forming a verb on the measure faEula [variable as to person, tense, and mood,] from one whose medial radical letter is I, fearing to make what is difficult to pronounce still more so; for in that case they would be obliged to say OabuwEu buEotu, and buwEaA; and, as would also happen if a variable verb of the same measure were formed from one whose final radical letter is I, the change of I into w, which is more difficult to pronounce, would thus become frequent. (TA.)
haMCa Uilayohi, aor. yahaMCu, inf. n. hiyoYapN, He desired, longed for, longed to see, him or it. (Ḳ.)
2. hy-O, inf. n. tahoyiYapN and tahoyiIoCN, [primarily signifies He invested him with, or made him to have, hayoCap, as meaning garb, guise,, &c. See Bḍ xviii. 9.]
[And hence,] He prepared, provided, disposed, arranged, or put into a right, or good state,, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [And hence, He rendered an affair feasible, or practicable; he facilitated it.]

5. thy-O [He, or it, was, or became, prepared, provided, disposed, arranged, or put into a right or good state,, &c. And hence, It (an affair) was, or became, feasible, or practicable: and it (a thing) was, or became, attainable, or within power or reach.]

thy-O liloOamori; and haMC lahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yahaMCu (Ḳ) and yahiIoCu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. hayoYapN; (Ṣ;) He prepared himself for the thing. (Ḳ.) Ex. waqaAlato hiYotu laka And she said, I have prepared myself for thee: accord. to one reading [for hayota, in the Ḳur, xii. 23]. (Akh, Ṣ.)
[See also thn-O.]
thy-O lahu AlOamoru, (Mṣb, Ḳ, art. AtI, &c.,) or AlX-aIoCN, (Ṣ, art. AtI, &c.,) [The thing, or affair, was, or became, feasible, or practicable, to him; and the thing was attainable.]
thy-O lilobukaMCi [He was ready, or about, to weep: a phrase of frequent occurrence; like OaraAda AlbukaMCa, and ham-a biAlobukaACi.] (Ṣ, art. jhX, &c.)
6. tahaAyaWuwA EalaI celika They agreed together upon that, or to do that. (Ḳ,* TA.)
haIoCN and hiIoCN The calling, or a call, to food and beverage. (Ḳ.)
The calling, or a call, to camels to drink: (Ḳ:) or, [rather,] a call to camels to food, or provender. (TA.)
[See arts. jyO and hO.]

yaA haIoCa maA liI [but see XICN] [Oh! what has happened to me?] an expression of regret; haIoCN being a word signifying regret for a thing that passes away from one, or escapes him: (Ṣ, TA:) or, (as some say, TA,) an expression of wonder: (Ḳ:) see also yaAXaIoCi and yaAfaIoCa, which are syn. with yaAhaIoCa: (TA:) or haIoCa, (accord. to certain of the lexicologists, as related by IB, TA,) is an imperative verbal noun, signifying Attend! (tanab-aho); like Saho, which signifies “Be silent!” (Ḳ;) the interjection yA being put before it in like manner as it is in the saying of Esh-Shemmakh,
OalaA yaA QsoqiyaAniI qabola gaArapi sanojaAli
[Come now! O, give me to drink, before the expedition of Sinjáb!]; (TA;) and hIC being indeclinable, with a vowel for its termination to obviate the occurrence of two quiescent letters, and with fet-ḥah as the final vowel because it is more easy of pronunciation than the others in this case. (Ḳ, TA.)
[See also art. XyO.]

hayoYapN and hiyoYapN↓ Form, fashion, shape, aspect, or appearance; figure, person, mien, feature, or lineaments; (Ṣ, TA;) guise; or external state or condition; (Mṣb;) state with regard to apparel and the like; or garb; (Lth;) state, condition, or case; quality, mode or manner of being: (Ḳ:) pl. hayoMtN and hiyoMtN. (TA.)
Hasanu AlhayoYapi [of goodly form, aspect, or appearance, guise, state of apparel, garb, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
[Also, goodliness of form, &c.: see 1. See also samotN, for an addition.]
[hayoYapN EaAriDapN, in Logic, An accidental mode.]

OaqiyluwA cawiI AlhayoMti EavaraAtihimo, in a trad., signifies, Forgive ye the people of good qualities, &c., who keep to one state and way, their slips. It alludes to those who make a slip unwittingly. (TA.)
hiyoYapN: see hayoYapN.
hayiIoCN: see what next follows.
hay-iYN and hay-iIoCN↓ A person of good, or goodly, form or appearance, or other properties denoted by the term hayoYap. (Ḳ.)
muhay-aON [Prepared,, &c.]
Also i. q. zumaA warodN, q. v. (MF, art. wrd.)
mahaAyaOapN A thing respecting which persons have agreed together. (Ḳ, TA.)
matahay-iYapN A camel that seldom fails of becoming pregnant when she has been covered. (Ḳ.)

1. haAbahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) first pers. hibotu, originally habiyotu, (Ṣ,) aor. yahaAbu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [originally yahoyabu,] and yahiybu, (IḲṭṭ, cited by MF,) imp. habo, originally haAbo, (Ṣ,) inf. n. hayobapN (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb) and mahaAbapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hayobN; (Ḳ;) and AhtAbh↓ and thy-bh↓; (Ḳ;) [He revered, venerated, respected, honoured, dreaded, or feared, him or it;] he regarded him or it, i. e., anything, (TA,) with reverence, veneration, respect, honour, dread, or awe; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* Mṣb, TA;) and fear; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) cautious fear, or caution. (Ḳ, Mṣb.)
habi Aln-aAsa yahaAbuwka Reverence men, [and] they will reverence thee. (TA.)
huwba, in which the original I is changed into w, [He (a man) was regarded with reverence, veneration, or awe; with fear; or with cautious fear, or caution]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
2. hay-abotuhu Uilayohi I made it to be regarded by him with reverence, veneration, or awe; with fear; or with cautious fear, or caution. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
4. AhAb biSaAHibihi ‡ He called his companion. And in like manner, Oahabotu bihi UilaI Alxayori ‡ I called him, or invited him, to what was good. (MF.)
AhAb biAlUibili He called to the camels, in driving them or urging them, by the cry haAbo haAbo. (Ḳ.)

AhAb biganamihi He (a pastor) cried out to his sheep, or goats, in order that they might stop, or return: and AhAb biAlbaEiyri [He cried out to the camel, for the same purpose]. (Ṣ.) AlUihaAbapu is The crying out to camels, and calling them. (As and others.)

AhAb baAlxayoli He called the horses, or called out to them by the cry haAbi, (so in the Ṣ and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ: in the CK, haAbo,) or by the cry of habo and habiI, meaning Come! Approach! or Advance boldly! (Ḳ.) Az remarks his having heard hAb used [as a cry] only to horses; not to camels. (TA.) See habohaba, in art. hb.
5: see 1.

tahay-abaniI It filled me with awe, or fear: (El- Jarmee:) it made me to fear: (Ṣ, ISd, Mṣb:) I regarded it with awe, or fear; i. q. tahay-abotuhu: (Th:) I feared it; i. q. xifotuhu. (Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ.) Ibn-Mukbil says,
wamaAtahay-abuniI AlmawomaApu OarokabuhaA
UicaA tajaAwabati AlOaSodaACu biAls-aHari
[And the waterless desert fills me not with awe, or fear; (or makes me not to fear,, &c.;) I ride over it when the male owls (?) answer one another at early dawn: thy-bnI being for tatahay-abuniI]. (Ṣ, &c.)
8: see 1.
habo (Ḳ) and haAbi↓ and habiI↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [but respecting the second of these words see 4,] Cries to horses, meaning, Come! Approach! (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Advance boldly! (Ḳ.)
haAbi and habiI: see habo.
haAbN † A serpent. (Ḳ.)
haAbN A calling to camels, in driving, or urging, them, by the cry haAbo haAbo. (Ḳ.)
See 4.
hayobaAnN: see haAYibN, and mahiybN.
hayuwbN: see haAYibN, and mahiybN.
hayobapN and mahaAbapN↓: see 1.
[As substs., Reverence, veneration, respect, honour, dread, or awe; fear; cautious fear, or caution.]
Also, great, reverend, or venerable, dignity; a quality inspiring reverence or veneration or respect or honour; venerableness; awfulness; a quality inspiring dread or awe. (MF.)
hay-abN: see haAYibN.
hay-abaAnN: see haAYibN.

hay-abaAnN (Ḳ) or [rather] hay-ibaAnN↓, (TA, [see haAYibN]) A he-goat: (Ḳ:) explained by the word tayosN; but this is a signification not found [by SM] elsewhere, and appears to be a mistake for manotafiXN; for in the L and other lexicons we find the word explained by munotafiXN xafiyfN, Scattered, and light; with a citation of the following verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh:
tamuj-u All-ugaAma Alhay-abaAna kaOan-ahu
janaI EuXarK tanofiyhi OaXodaAquhaA Alhudolu
[She ejects from her mouth the scattered and light froth, as though it were plucked fruit of the 'oshar which the flabby sides of her mouth cast forth:] and we also find, in the R, quTonN hy-bAnN explained as signifying cotton that is plucked, or teased with the fingers, so as to become scattered; syn. mntfX: or hy-bAn signifies, in the abovecited verse, accord. to some, Light, [which signification is also given in the Ḳ, but in the CK displaced; following, instead of preceding, the word Alr-aAEiI, and without w before it;] and separated into small particles: (TA:) [or] the froth of the mouth of camels; (Az, Ḳ;) i. q. lugaAmN: (Mj, Sifr es-Sa'ádeh:) Az cites the above verse; and says, that the fruit of the EuXar [or asclepias gigantea] comes forth like a small pomegranate, and, when burst open, discloses what resembles [white] raw silk; to which the poet likens the froth of the camel's mouth. (TA.)
hay-abaAnN (or hay-ibaAnN, TA,) A pastor. (Ḳ, from Es-Seeráfee.) [Accord. to the CK, a light, or an active pastor: but see above.]
hay-abaAnN (or hay-ibaAnN↓, TA,) Dust, or earth: syn. turaAbN. (Ḳ.)
See haAYbN.
hay-ibaAnN: see hay-abaAnN.
hay-aAbN: see haAYibN.
hay-aAbapN: see haAYibN.
haAYibN [act. part. n. of haAba, Regarding with reverence, veneration, dread, or awe; with fear; with cautious fear, or caution;] fearing men. (Ḳ.) This is the original [simple] epithet. (TA.)

The following, which are explained in the Ḳ in the same manner as the above, are intensive epithets: (TA:) namely hayuwbN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hayuwbapN, (Ṣ, L,) [in which the p is added to strengthen the intensiveness,] and hay-aAbN↓ and hay-aAbapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which p is added for the purpose above mentioned, (TA,) and hay-ibN↓, (Ḳ,) which may be contracted into hayotN, (TA,) and hayobaAnN↓ (Ḳ) and hay-ibaAnN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hay-abaAnN↓; (Ḳ;) of which last two forms, the latter only is admitted by some of the learned; but MF admits only the former of them; asserting fayoEalaAnN to be unknown as the measure of an unsound word, like as fyaEilaAn is unknown as that of a sound word except in extr. instances; (TA;) [Having much reverence, veneration, dread, or awe; much fear; much cautious fear, or caution:] fearing men [much]: (Ḳ:) a coward, who regards men with awe, or fear, &c.: (Ṣ:) [The last of these epithets is also explained in the CK as signifying having much fear, or very fearful; (kaviyru Alxawofi;) and a coward: but in the TA and in a MṢ copy of the Ḳ, Alxwf is omitted; and in the TA is added by the author, after kvyr, the words mn kl- XIu; as though the meaning of the word were “much, or many, of any things:” the correct reading seems to be the former, and the meaning intended by SM, having much fear, or very fearful, of everything: in like manner] hayuwbN↓ signifies a man who fears everything. (TA.)

AlUiymaAnu hayuwbN↓ [Faith is fearful, or very fearful; i. e.,] he who possesses faith fears acts of disobedience: occurring in a trad.: (Ṣ:) in this case, hywb is used in the sense of an act. part. n.: or it signifies [faith is feared; or regarded with reverence, &c.; i. e.,] he who possesses faith is feared, or regarded with reverence, &c.: in which case hywb is used in the sense of a pass. part. n. (TA.)
hecaA AlX-aIoCu mahoyabapN laka [This thing is a cause of awe, or fear, to thee]. (Ṣ.)
mahaAbN: see mahiybN.
mahaAbapN: see hayobapN.
mahuwbN: see mahiybN.

mahiybN and mahuwbN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the former agreeable with rule, (TA,) and hayuwbN↓, (Ḳ) [respecting which see also haAYibN,] and hayobaAnN↓, (Th, IM, Ḳ,) [Regarded with reverence, veneration, respect, honour, dread, or awe; with fear; with cautious fear, or caution;] a man whom others regard with reverence, &c.; (Ṣ;) a man whom others fear. (Ḳ.)

makaAnN mahuwbN, formed from the verb huwba, the original I being changed into w (Ṣ, Ḳ,) A place regarded with awe, or fear; (Ṣ;) a place in which one is impressed with awe, or fear: as also makaAnN mahaAbN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) mahaAbN signifies a place of awe, or fear. (IB.)
Almahiybu and Almahuwbu and Almutahay-abu↓ † The lion: (Ḳ:) because regarded with awe, or fear, by men. (TA.)
Almutahay-abu: see Almahiybu.

2. hy-t bihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tahoyiytN, (TA,) as also hw-t, (Ṣ,) He cried out to him, and called him, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) saying, hayota hayota; or saying yaAho yaAho, which is a cry by which a pastor calls his companion from afar; or, accord. to AZ, saying yaA hayaA [or rather yaAhayaAho: see art. yh]. (TA.)

3. haAt Give me: (Ḳ:) haAti yaA rajulu Give me, O man: (T, Ṣ, M:) i. q. OaEoTiniI: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) to two men, haAtiyaA: to a plurality of men, haAtuwA: to a woman, haAtiI: to two women, haAtiyaA: to a plurality of women, haAtiyna: you say haAti lA haAtayota [Give me: mayest thou not give (hereafter)! an imprecation, of the like of which there are many examples]; and haAti Uino kaAnato bika muhaAtaApN [Give me, if there be in thee (a disposition for) giving]; and maA OuhAtiyka [I do not give thee], like as you say, maA OuEaATiyka; but you do not say haAtayotu; nor do you use this verb in a prohibitive manner: [it is used neither affirmatively nor prohibitively:] accord. to Kh, haAti is from QtaI, aor. yuwtiI; the A being changed into h. (Ṣ.) [But QtaI is of the measure OafoEala; and haAti is the imp. from the measure faAEala. See also art. htI, where it is mentioned again in the Ṣ and Ḳ.]
hayota an exclamation denoting wonder: the Arabs say, hayota liloHilomi [What forbearing mildness, or clemency!] (L.)

hayota laka, (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) and hayoti lk, (Akh, Ḳ,) and hayota lk, (Akh, IB, Ḳ,) and the first letter is sometimes with kesreh; (Ḳ;) as is related on the authority of ʼAlee, (TA,) [so that you say hiyta and hiyti and hiytu, the first of which three forms is mentioned by Fr, Akh, IB, and the third by Fr, IB; but for the second I find no other authority than that implied above;] of all which, the most common is hayota lk, with fet-ḥah to the h and t: (Zj:) hayota is of the dial. of Howrán, whence it became introduced into Mekkeh; and hiyta, of the dial. of El-Medeeneh: (Fr:) [imper. verbal ns.] i. q. halum-a, Come! (Akh, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or taEaAla the same, (Fr, Ks,) or Oaqobilo, the same, or Come forward! (L.) It occurs in the Ḳur, xii. 23; where it is commonly read hayota laka; (Zj;) but ʼAlee and Ibn-ʼAbbás are said to have read hiYotu laka, with hemzeh. [See art. hyO.] (TA.) hayota is itself invariable whether used to denote the sing. or pl. or fem. or masc.; but the difference of number is observed in what follows it; for you say hayota lakumaA [Come ye two!] and hayota lakun-a [Come ye women!, &c.]: (Ṣ:) you also say simply hayota [Come!] and this is also said to signify Hasten! and Set forth journeying through the land, or earth. (TA.) Authorities differ respecting this word; whether it be Arabic or arabicized; and whether it be a noun or a verb;, &c. Accord. to AZ, as related by Az, hyt lk is arabicized in the Ḳur, from the Hebrew hytA kx [app. a mistake for hytA kx, which I suppose to be meant for עַתָה לְטָה “Now, come!” occurring in Gen. xxxi. 44]. (TA.)
hayota hayota: see 2.
hiytN A low, or depressed, piece of ground: (Ḳ:) a piece of ground having a low, or depressed, bottom: (TA:) i. q. huw-apN and huwtapu. (IAạr.)
hiytaACN and hiytaAh: see art. hwt.
hay-aAtN [Clamorous; calling out often, or much]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. haAva lahu, aor. yahiyvu, inf. n. hayovN and hayavaAnN, He gave him a little, or something little in quantity. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also HavaA, in art. Hvw.]
haAva fiI kayolihi, inf. n. hiyovN, He gave little in his measure, or in his measuring; i. q. HavaA, inf. n. HavowN: it is like what is termed jizaAfN. (TA.)
haAva, aor. yahiyvu, inf. n. hayovN, It was in a state of motion, or commotion; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like haAXa, inf. n. hayoXN. (Ṣ.)
haAva birijolihi Alt-uraAba, aor. yahiyvu, He dug up the dust, or earth, with his foot. (TA.)
haAva, aor. yahiyvu, inf. n. hayovN: (TA;) and AsthAv↓; (Ḳ;) He corrupted, or marred; acted corruptly; did mischief; syn. Oafosada. (Ḳ, TA.)

haAva fI maAlihi, aor. yahiyvu, inf. n. hayovN, He acted corruptly (Oafosada) with his property; (Ḳ;) as also EaAva; (TA;) [he scattered and marred his property; squandered it; expended it quickly: see art. Eyv].
Also, [contr.,] He acted rightly with his property. (TA.)
haAva fiI XaIoCK He acted corruptly with a thing; and took it without gentleness; (TA;) [as also EaAva].
haAva Alc-iYobu fiI Alganami The wolf did mischief among [or worried] the sheep, or goats; (TA;) [as also EaAva].
haAva mina AlmaAli, aor. yahiyvu, inf. n. hayovN, He obtained what he wanted of the property. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. haAyavahu, inf. n. muhaAyavahu, He contended, or disputed, with him for superiority in abundance, or multitude; as, for instance, of wealth, or of dependants or followers. (TḲ.) muhaAyavapN is syn. with mukaAvarahN. (Ḳ.)
See 10.
5. thy-v He gave. (Ḳ.) thy-v lahu XayoYFA He gave him a thing. (TḲ.)
6: see 1.
10. AsthAv (and hAyv↓, TA,) He deemed [a thing] much; syn. Uisotakovara. (Ḳ.) AsthAv maA OaEoTaAhu [He deemed what he gave him much]. (TḲ.)
See 1.
hayovapN An assembly, a company, a congregated body, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) of men, or people; like hayoXapN. (Aṣ, Ṣ.)
haAYivapN The clamour, or confused noise, (jalabap,) of a people. (L.)
muhaAyivN Taking much; one who takes much. (Ḳ.)

1. haAja, aor. yahiyju, inf. n. hayojN and hayajaAnN [the most common form]; and hiyaAjN; and AhtAj↓, and thy-j↓; It (a thing, Ṣ) became raised, roused, excited, stirred up, or provoked; syn. vaAra: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) it became so by reason of distress, or difficulty; or of harm, or injury: you say haAja bihi Ald-amu, inf. n. hayojN and hayajaAnN, The blood became roused, or stirred up, in him: (A, L:) and in like manner, Almir-apu the gall, or bile: and AlgubaAru the dust. (A.) See also haAYijN.

haAjato Eayonuhu, (Ṣ, art. mrH; and L, art. rmd;, &c.) inf. n. hayajaAnN, (Ḳ, art. rmd;, &c.) His eye became inflamed; painful and swollen; affected with ophthalmia; (L, art. rmd;) i. q. ramida. (Ṣ, art. rmd; and L, Ḳ,* in the same art.)
haAjN bh fahajaAhu ‡ [He became excited against him, or attacked him, and satirized him]. (A.)
haAja AlhijaMCu bayonahumaA ‡ [Satire was excited between them two]. (A.)
haAjati AlHarobu (inf. n. hayojN, Mṣb) ‡ War became excited, or raised. (A, Mṣb.)
haAja AlX-ar-u bayonahumo ‡ Evil become excited among them. (A.)
haAja, inf. n. hayojN, He, or it, was in a state of commotion. (L.)
haAjati Als-amaMCu famuTironaA The sky became cloudy and windy, and we were rained upon. (TA.)

haAja; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [followed by an accus., and also by b;] and hy-j↓, inf. n. tahoyiyjN, [the most common form;] and haAyaja↓; (Ṣ;) He, or it, raised, roused, excited, stirred up, or provoked, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a thing; (Ṣ;) syn. OavaAra. (Ḳ.) Thus the first of these verbs is trans. as well as intrans. (Ṣ.) All have the same meaning: (Ṣ:) or the second has an intensive signification. (Mṣb.)
haAja AlgubaAra, and hy-jhu↓, [which is more common,] He raised the dust. (TA.)
hy-j↓ AlX-ar-a ‡ He excited evil among a people. (A)
hay-ajotu↓ Aln-aAqapa faQnobaEavato I roused the she-camel, and she became roused. (A.)
hijotuhu fahaAja I roused him, and he became roused. (TA.)
haAjato lahu Ald-aAru AlX-awoqa The dwelling excited his longing desire. (A.)
haAja He, or it, disquieted, and scared, a person. (L.)
haAj AlUibala, inf. n. hayojN, He put the camels in motion, by night, towards the watering-place and pasture. (L.)
haAjati AlUibilu The camels thirsted. (Ḳ.)

haAja, (inf. n. hiyaAjN, Ṣ, and hayojN, TA,) ‡ It (a plant, or herbage,) dried up: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [it withered:] it (a leguminous plant) became yellow: (Mṣb:) or dried up and became yellow: and became tall. (L.)
haAjati AlOaroDu, inf. n. hiyaAjN and hayojN and hayajaAnN, ‡ The plants, or herbage, or leguminous plants, of the land dried up. (L.)
2: see 1 and 4.
3. hAyjhu, (TḲ,) inf. n. hiyaAjN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He fought with him; engaged in a conflict, or combat, with him. (TḲ.)
yawomu AlhiyaAji The day of fight, conflict or combat. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
See 1.
4. OahaAjati Alr-iyHu Aln-abova ‡ The wind dried up, or caused to dry up, the plants, or herbage: (Ṣ, Ḳ *:) and [so] hay-ajatohu↓. (O, Ḳ in art. SwE.)
OahoyajonaA AlOaroDa ‡ We found the land to have its plants or herbage, dried up. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
5: see 1.
6. tahaAyajuwA † They leaped, or sprung up, together, to fight, one against another. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
8: see 1.
hijo: see hiyj.
hayojN Civil war; or conflict and faction; or discord, or dissension; syn. fitonapN. (L.) See hayojaMCu.
Excitement of the blood: or, of coitus: or, of longing desire. (L.)
yawomu hayojK A day of wind: or, of clouds, or mist, and rain. (Ḳ, TA: [but accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, instead of “and rain,” “or, of rain.”])

haAja lahu hayojN HasanN, said with respect to a cloud, or body of clouds, when first rising; (Aṣ;) [meaning, It hath had a good rising, or hath risen well, so as to present, at its first rising, a good, or promising, appearance: an expression like lahu naXoCN HasanN, q. v., art. nXO].
hayojN, † Yellowness: [app. in a plant]: (L:) or a state of drying up. (IAạr, L.) See haAYijN.
hiyji, indecl., with kesreh for its termination, and hijo↓, Cries by which a she-camel is chidden. (Ḳ.) [See also hajohaja, in art. hj.]
haAjapN A ewe that does not desire the ram: as though deprived of excitement. (M.)
haAjapN A female frog. (L, Ḳ.) See an ex. in a verse cited voce SubaArapN.
An ostrich. (L.) Pl. of both, haAjaAtN. (L. Ḳ.) Dim. huwayojapN and huyayojapN. (L.)
hayojaI: see hayojaMCu.
hayojaMCu and hayojaI↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and hayojN↓ and hiyaAjN↓ (L) the third [as also the fourth] originally an inf. n., (Mṣb,) War. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
hay-ijN: see haAYijN.
hiyaAjN: see 1 and 3; and hayojaMCu.

XayoCN hayuwjN, and mihoyaAjN↓, A thing, or person, that raises, rouses, excites, stirs up, or provokes, much: each of these epithets having a trans. signification. The former is also used as a fem. epithet. (L.)

haAYijN ‡ Anger; an ebullition of anger, rage, or passion; syn. faworapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Ex. haAja haAYijuhu ‡ His anger became roused, or excited; (Ṣ;) became violent; (TA;) he became inflamed with anger. (A.) And hadaO haAYijuhu ‡ The ebullition of his anger, rage, or passion, became appeased. (Ṣ.)
haAYijN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and hay-ijN↓ (TA) ‡ A stallion excited by lust; initum appetens. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

OaroDN haAYijapN ‡ Land of which the leguminous plants have dried up, or become yellow: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as in some lexicons, [and as in one copy of the Ṣ in my hands,] and become yellow: (TA:) or, of which the leguminous plants have dried up. (TA.) baqolN haAYijN, and hiyojN↓, ‡ Leguminous plants dried up, or drying up, [and yellow]. (L.)
mihoyaAjN A she-camel that is excited by desire for its accustomed place, and hastens thither. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See habuwjN.
mihoyaAjN A camel that thirsts before [other] camels. (Ḳ.)

1. haAda, aor. yahiydu, inf. n. hayodN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and hy-d↓, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. tahoyiydN; (TA;) He moved, or put in motion, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) a thing, (Ṣ,) or anything: this is the original signification. (L.)
haAdN, aor. yahiydu, inf. n. hayodN and haAdN; (L, Ḳ;) and hy-d↓; (Ḳ;) It frightened, or terrified, and afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, a person. (L, Ḳ.)

haAda, aor. yahiydu, inf. n. hayodN; (L, Ḳ;) and hy-d↓; (Ḳ;) He repaired; put into a right or proper state. (L, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., with reference to the Mosque (of Moḥammad, L), hidohu, (Ṣ, L,) meaning Repair it: (L:) or pull it down, and then repair it: (Ṣ, L:) or pull it down, and recommence the building of it, and repair it, and put it into a right or proper state. (L.)

haAda, (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. yahiydu, inf. n. hayodN, and haAdN; (L;) and hy-d↓; (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, L:) He chid a man; and turned him away, or back, from a thing: (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ:) or yahiydu is only used with a negative in this sense. (Yaạḳoob, Ḳ.)
haAda He removed a person or thing from his or its place. (L, Ḳ.*)
haAda He or it disquieted, disturbed, or unsettled, a person. (Ḳ.)

maA yahiyduniI kacaA Such a thing does not move me; (L;) it does not disquiet, disturb, or unsettle, me; I am not moved by it; do not care for it, or regard it. (Ṣ, L.) Accord. to Yaạḳoob, yhyd is only thus used with a negative. (Ṣ, L.) One says, laAa yhiydan-aka hecaA Eano raOoyika Let not this move thee at all from thine opinion. (TA.)
2: see 1.
haAdN: see hayodN.

hom.sense: hayodN and hiydN↓ and haAdN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and hayodK and hiydi and haAdi (IB, L) and hiydo (L) Cries by which camels are chidden (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and urged. (L.)

Also hayodN A mode of singing to camels, to urge or excite them: (L:) or the commencement of such singing: (TA:) when a man is about to sing to camels for this purpose, he says hydo hydo, and then sings, or prolongs and modulates his voice. (L, TA.)

hayoda maA laka, (T, L, Ḳ,) and hiyda mAlk, (Sh, L,) and hiydo mAlk, (L,) [What is thy state, or condition, or thy affair, or business?] forms of speech used in inquiring of a man respecting his state, or condition, or his affair, or business; (T, L, Ḳ;) like as you say yaA hecaA maA laka. (T, L.) One says, laqiyahu faqaAla lahu hayoda maA laka [He met him, and said to him, What is thy state, &c.?] and laqiytuhu famaA qaAla liI hayoda maA laka [I met him, and he said not to me, What is thy state, &c.?] (Lḥ, L,) and yaA hayoda maA liOSoHaAbiki, and yaA hayoda maA OaSoHaAbuka, [What is the state, &c., of thy companions?] (Ks, L,) and one says, lawo XatamotaniI maA qulotu hayoda maA laka, meaning, [Hadst thou reviled me, or shouldst thou revile me, I had not said, or would not say,] What is thine affair? (Aṣ, on the authority of ʼEesà Ibn-ʼOmar.) When a straycamel passes by a man, and he does not turn him aside, nor does he regard it, you say, mar-a baEiyrN famaA qaAla lahu hayoda maA laka, and, as related by an Arab of the desert, hayodi mA lk, with kesr to the d, [A camel passed by, and he said not to him, What is thy state, &c.?] (AZ, L.)
maA lahu hayodN walaA haAdN↓ He has no motion: (L, Ḳ:) or neither hyd nor hAd is to be said to him; meaning, he is not to be moved, nor withheld from a thing, nor chidden away from it. (Ṣ, L.)
hayodN i. q. hayodabN A flabby pubes. (Fr, in TA, voce kaEotabN.)

entry.sense: hiyod: see hayodN.
hayodaAn [whether with or without tenween is not shown] Cowardly; or a coward: (Ṣ, L;) a heavy, cowardly man; like hidaAnN. (L.)
2. hy-rhu: see hw-rhu.
5. thy-r: see thw-r.

hom.sense: 1. haAXa Alqawomu, aor. yahiyXu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. hayoXN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) The people, or company of men, were, or became, in a state of commotion and excitement, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) EalayonaA against us. (Ṣ.)

haAXa Alqawomu baEoDuhumo UilaI baEoDK The people, or company of men, leaped, or sprang, one, or one portion. towards another, for fight, or conflict: (TA:) and thy-X↓ Aln-aAsu baEoDuhumo UilaI baEoDK The men, or people, leaped, or sprang, one, or one portion, towards another, (JK,) in the slightest kind of conflict. (TA.)
haAXa fiI Aln-aAsi, (JK, TA,) inf. n. hayoXN, (JK, Ḳ,) He created, or excited, disorder, disturbance, discord, or dissension, between, or among, the people; made mischief among them. (JK, Ḳ,* TA.)
haAXa Alr-julu, (JK,) inf. n. hayoXN, (JK, Ḳ,) The man used, or uttered much foul speech or language. (JK. Ṣgh, Ḳ.*)
haAXa, aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Fr, Ḳ,) He collected. (Fr, Ḳ, TA.) [In this sense, as well as the first, it is like hAX having hawoXN for its inf. n.]

entry.sense: 5: see 1.

hom.sense: hayoXapN i. q. hawoXapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) Conflict and faction, sedition, discord, or dissension. (JK, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., (TA,) layosa fiI AlhayoXaAti qawadN, (Ḳ, TA,) or, accord. to one relation, fI AlhawoXaAti, (TA,) There is no retaliation for one slain in cases of conflict and faction,, &c., when the slayer is unknown. (Ḳ, TA.) And hayoXaAt in the phrases hayoXaAtu All-ayoli and hayoXaAtu AlaOasowaAqi is like hawoXaAt. (TA.)
A company of men: (JK, Ṣ:) or a mixed, or confused, company. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 1. haADahu, aor. yahiyDu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. hayoDN, (Ṣ,) He broke it, namely, a bone, after it had become set; as also AhtADhu↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and in like manner, a wing. (TA.)

‡ It (a thing) made him to fall back into his disease; (Ṣ, A, TA;) and so haADahu UilaI maA bihi. (TA.) You say also, hAD AlHuzonu Alqaloba † Grief affected the heart time after time. (TA.) And thy-Dhu↓ AlgazaAmu [Vehemence of desire] returned to him a second time. (A,* TA.)

† It softened him, or it. (TA.) And so IAạr explains the verb as occurring in the saying of ʼÁïsheh, lawonazala biAljibaAli Alr-aAsiyaAti maAnazala biOabiI lahaADahaA † [Had that befallen the firm mountains which befell my father,] it had softened them. (TA.) [See also an ex. of a similar meaning voce ZlE.]
‡ It (drowsiness) made him languid. (A, TA.)

‡ He broke him, or defeated him: as in the imprecation uttered by ʼOmar the son of ʼAbd-el-'Azeez against Yezeed the son of El-Mohelleb, when he broke his prison, and escaped, Aall-ehum-a Uin-ahu qado haADaniI fahiDohu ‡ O God, verily he hath broken me, or defeated me, and encroached on me (Aid-axala EalaI-a), then do Thou break him, or defeat him, and requite him for that which he hath done. (TA.)
2. hy-Dhu † He roused, excited, or provoked, him; and it, namely the heart. (IB.)

hom.sense: 5: see 7:
and see also 1.

entry.sense: 7. AnhAD It [a bone] broke, or became broken, (JK, Ḳ,) after having been set; (JK;) and thy-D↓ signifies the same. (Ḳ.)
8: see 1.
hayoDN † Any pain following upon pain. (Ṣ, TA.) See also hayoDapN.
† Softness. (TA.)
hayoDapN, (Lth, Ḳ,) or hayoDN↓, (JK,) † A disease after a disease: a return of anxiety, or disquietude of mind; and of grief. (Lth, JK, Ḳ.)

bihi hayoDapN † He has a purging and vomiting together; [i. e. the cholera: used in this sense in the present day:] (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a discharge of the belly alone. (TA.) You say also, OaSaAbato fulaAnFA hayoDapN, meaning † A change of his temperament, such as often occasions laxness of the bowels, causing a frequent going to and from the privy, affected such a one, from the disagreement with him of something which he had eaten. (TA.)
bihi hayoDapu AlkaraI ‡ In him is the languor produced by drowsiness. (A, TA.)
mahiyDN A bone broken after having become set; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also muhotaADN↓ (Ṣ) and munohaADN↓. (Ṣ, A.)
muhotaADN: see mahiyDN.
munohaADN: see mahiyDN.

musotahaADN [A beast] that has had a leg broken, and has recovered, and has been hastily laden and driven, and whose bone has consequently broken a second time, after it had become set and nearly well: or, accord. to ISh, one that has been diseased, and recovers, and is hastily put to work, so that he is distressed thereby; or that eats food, or drinks beverage, and in consequence relapses into disease. (TA.)

1. maA zaAla yahiyTu, inf. n. hayoTN; and maA zaAla fiI hayoTK wamayoTK; He ceased not to be engaged in crying out, or vociferating, or calling for aid or succour; and in evil, or mischief; and raising a clamour, or confused noise. (Ḳ.) IḲṭṭ says, that yhyT has no pret. (TA.) [See also 3.]

3. hiyaATN [in the senses assigned to it in what here follows] is an inf. n. of which the verb [haAyaTa] is obsolete. (L.) You say, maA zaAla fiI hiyaATK wamiyaATK He ceased not to be in a state of approaching, or drawing near, and retiring to a distance: (Ḳ:) or hiyaATN signifies the act of advancing: (Lḥ:) or hiyaATN and miyaATN respectively signify the most vehement driving in coming to water, and the most vehement driving in returning from water; and the meaning is, going and coming: (Aboo-Tálib:) or both signify the being in a state of commotion, tumult, or disturbance; as some say, arising from their saying “No, by God,” and “Yes, by God:” (TA:) [it is also said that] muhaAyaTapN [which is likewise an inf. n. of maAyaTa] signifies the act of crying out, or vociferating; and raising a clamour, or confused noise; [(see also 1;) and so, app., hiyaATN; for it is immediately added,] one says, waqaEa Alqawomu fiI hiyaATK wamiyaATK [as though meaning the people, or company of men, fell into vociferating,, &c.]. (Ṣ.) bayonahumaA muhaAyaTapN is also said to signify Between them two is low, faint, or gentle, speaking. (TA.) [See miyaATN.]
Accord. to IAạr, hAyThu signifies He esteemed him weak. (TA.)
6. thAyTwA They came together, or coalesced, and arranged, or adjusted, their affairs; (Fr., Ṣ, Ḳ;) contr. of tmAyTwA. (Fr, Ṣ.)
haAYiT and maAYiTN are explained by IAạr as signifying Going and coming. (TA.)
